name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Thursday 14 December 2017.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Dear colleagues, first of all I want to wish you a happy new year. On the thirtieth anniversary of the Sakharov Prize, we have the duty not only to remember but also to protect the winners of this prize: they are the symbol of all those who fight for human rights in the world. Some of them are in a dangerous situation and we must remember that the deputy Leyla Zana, winner of the Sakharov Prize in 1995, has just been dismissed as a member of the Turkish Grand National Assembly. As President of Parliament I want to express the solidarity of the whole European Parliament to you, because it is not acceptable that, in a democracy, a representative elected by the people is illegally dismissed. (Applause) I also want to express my concern over the repeated human rights violations in Turkey, to the detriment not only of political opponents but also of representatives of civil society, including journalists and academics. Among the many I would like to mention Nuriye Gülmen, Semih Özakça, Osman Kavala, Mehmet Altan and Şahin Alpay. The European Parliament will not fail to support the struggle of these people for freedom and justice. (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: As you know, on Wednesday morning, following the presentation of the Bulgarian Presidency program by Prime Minister Borissov, the first debate on the future of Europe will take place, in which the Taoiseach will speak. This is a very important event for us, and it will be the first in a long series of meetings with numerous other prime ministers, which will place Parliament at the center of the debate on the future of the Union. I inform you that, in order to have a more spontaneous, interactive and inclusive exchange, for this debate it was decided to inaugurate a new format, which provides for an authentic catch-the-eye, so that all Members who wish to do so can ask to speak and have a chance to express yourself. Of course, for reasons of time, not everyone will be able to speak, but I will try to be as balanced as possible and to respect the diversity that exists in this House, it being understood that catch-the-eye will respect the relative weight of the political groups. I thank the Taoiseach for accepting our invitation and for having consented to this innovative format.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The final draft agenda, set by the Conference of Presidents, pursuant to Rule 149 of the Rules, was distributed at the meeting of Thursday 11 January 2018.The following proposed amendments were presented: Monday I have received a request from the GUE / NGL group to postpone the discussion and the vote on the report by the Hon.Mato entitled "Conservation of fishery resources and protection of marine ecosystems through technical measures".This request is supported by the Verts / ALE and EFDD groups.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, our group is indeed asking for the postponement of the vote on the report by our colleague Gabriel Mato. There are many reasons that plead in favor of postponing this vote, but I will retain only one: a few days ago, the press and NGOs revealed that the European Commission had not taken into account the conclusions of an expert report that she herself had requested, a report which concluded that electric fishing was dangerous. However, the European Commission relied on this report to make it say the exact opposite of what it said and to authorize exemptions from the ban on this barbaric fishing method. Has the European Commission deliberately lied to MEPs? That's the question. And this is the question that we have a duty to ask him before we can take a calm decision, in full knowledge of the facts, on a long-awaited report on which our European Parliament is highly regarded, and that is why I am asking you to vote in favor of this postponement of the vote.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, on this issue, because there have been more than 200 amendments and split votes, Rule 175 gives the possibility, if there are so many amendments and so many uncertainties, to send it back to committee. My suggestion to you is to use that Rule 175 because of this enormous inflation of amendments and to send it back to committee. This also gives the possibility of giving some clarity and objectivity on this issue, because I have a very strange feeling when I read scientific evidence of one thesis, and exactly the opposite scientific evidence in the opposite thesis. That is not normal. Normally in science there should be objectivity and rationality. So my proposal is to send it back to committee, because you can do so under Rule 175, so that we can clarify this and have a more objective examination rather than by doing it in a vote here in plenary tomorrow.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr Verhofstadt, thank you for reminding me of this possibility.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: Speaker. - Mr President, indeed, we must see what is rational and reasonable. And in this sense, two different questions have been raised. The first, the issue of electric fishing. I would like to remind all your honorable Members that we have been working on this dossier for 21 months, with 77 meetings and a request to postpone the vote in committee in June, which was accepted. We postponed it in September and postponed it in October. It was scheduled to be voted on in December. Someone suggested that we postpone the vote and we postponed it until this time. And no one, at any time, referred to the first issue that arises today to postpone the vote: the issue of electric fishing. I mean, we've had all that time. Obviously, that does not mean that we cannot debate today and vote tomorrow. If Mr. Omarjee, as he has said, is absolutely against it and considers it an aberration, he has the possibility to vote against that article and the issue is resolved. I mean, we are not going to get anything. Electric fishing has been used as an excuse for some groups that were not satisfied or were not happy with the result of the vote In committee use the formula of table many amendments to change the text.I believe, Mr President, that there is not a single reasonable argument, because there is also nothing new in the reasons that have been put forward for postponing the text.I ask that the debate and the vote be held tomorrow.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: - Thank you for giving me the floor: a point of order based on Rule 151 of the Rules of Procedure. On December 19, some colleagues from this Parliament - including myself - wanted to visit the Estremera prison near Madrid, where our former colleague Oriol Junqueras is imprisoned. In total there are still two leaders of a civilian movement in prison, as well as two former ministers from the Catalan government. Three of them were elected to the Catalan Parliament in the regional elections of Catalonia on December 21. For a month we formally asked to be allowed to visit the prison. This is an unacceptable way of working for an EU Member State, all the more so because we rightly protest when something like this happens in Turkey or other third countries, for example. name: Antonio TAJANI
text: We will check what happened and then let you know.Thursday I communicate that I have received a request from GUE / NGL to add the Commission's statement on collective redundancies in competitive companies in Europe as a second item to the agenda for the morning's discussion: the Siemens case.

name: Martin SCHIRDEWAN
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! Regarding the background to this application: Despite its record profits, Siemens Aktiengesellschaft has announced that it intends to carry out massive job cuts and plant closings in Europe, with up to 7,000 jobs being reported. The Netherlands and Germany are mainly affected. However, this does not include the colleagues in the suppliers and service companies. So we're talking about tens of thousands of people affected. We are talking about the future prospects of entire European regions that are threatened by the reduction plans. Even though the plants are operating profitably, this is supposed to happen, and even though Siemens has received more than EUR 300 million in state subsidies in Germany alone in the last ten years. That is reason enough for our group, for the GUE / NGL, to ask that we deal with this matter here. I am asking for your approval, dear colleagues, so that we can send a strong signal of European solidarity to the employees and so that we can work together to put a stop to the mass layoffs of profitable and publicly funded companies in the future.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: speaker. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, let me be clear: Europe is at stake for its credibility with the world in the energy standards that we are beginning to debate today. Two years ago, in Paris, we pledged to fight climate change, the greatest threat the world has ever faced. And in this fight it is vital to promote a change in the energy model, decarbonize the economy and turn towards a sustainable model that is based on renewable energies. Therefore, the European Parliament has an obligation to honor the word given to Europe, the word that Europe gave to the world, committing ourselves to promoting a new energy model based on renewables. More, if possible, after the denialist Trump has withdrawn the United States from the Paris Agreement. And we have to do it ourselves. We have to do it here, now. The Commission has fallen short in its ambition and the Council has opted for immobility, if not backwardness. Europe cannot remain in empty words, in great rhetorical statements without firm political commitment to curb climate change. Climate change knocks on our doors every day, it hits us deadly. It is urgent to act, and it is urgent to do it decisively. For this very reason, I want to thank the shadow rapporteurs for the work they have done to achieve the agreement that we have presented here today in the proposal we are debating. An agreement with which we raised the renewable target to 35% with reinforced national obligations in the Governance Regulation. We reinforce legal certainty and prevent the adoption of retroactive measures. We shield self-consumption as a right without charges, tolls or fees that impede its development. We introduce more ambition in the heating and cooling sector for greater penetration of renewables. And we are committed to the decarbonisation of transport, promoting electromobility, freezing first-generation biofuels and promoting advanced ones, in addition to excluding oil Palm. The International Renewable Energy Agency has calculated that the European Union can double its share of renewables, from 17% in 2015, to 34% in 2030, in a profitable way. Regrettably, it seems that the Member States are still blind to this reality, based on the position adopted last month by the Council. Maintaining, as the Council maintains, a renewable target of 25% is unambitious. It is also counterproductive and irresponsible. Stopping decarbonisation is stopping the development of Europe. Therefore, I call on Parliament to convey a strong, unequivocal and resounding message in favor of renewable energy, so that no one has any doubt that this House is not going to indulge in whimsy in our commitment to climate change. We have the power of the citizens' vote to change things. Let's exercise it. Responsibly, but let's exercise it. I know there are many interests at stake, but there is one interest that must prevail over all others: the interest of the future of the planet, the interest of our lives.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: rapporteur. - In my opinion, energy efficiency is our largest and most affordable source of energy. It is a clean and cheap source of energy that can be used very quickly throughout the EU by technologies that are already available and widespread. That is why reducing consumption and reducing the energy efficiency of our economy should be one of the EU's main strategic priorities. Savings are also an integral part of the strategy to ensure Europe's long-term energy security. It is proven that any percentage improvement in energy efficiency will bring a much greater reduction in our dependence on imports. In the case of natural gas, this is up to a 2% decrease in the volume of its imports. And only if a very ambitious target is adopted will the current level of import dependence be maintained. Otherwise, if the 30% target were adopted, our dependence would increase to more than 70%. Energy efficiency also lies in the future of our economic competitiveness and our economic development. We should clearly reject the approach that efficiency is an obstacle to economic growth, that European policy in this area will only require private and public spending of hundreds of billions of euros, without any significant economic or social benefits. In my opinion, the opposite is true. If the energy efficiency target of 40% is approved, we will pave the way for an increase in both GDP and employment. In contrast, the 35% target will lead to significantly lower results, in the case of GDP even by 1.5%. Even lower results assume models for goals set at an even lower level. Similarly, a higher target will have an impact on lowering international fuel prices, on the European price of electricity and, last but not least, on the prices of emission allowances. The result will not be, as some are trying to say, that ambitious commitments for energy savings will translate into the lower competitiveness of European industry and have an overall negative impact on it. The European Commission had all this data available. Alone with them worked on the calculations of individual scenarios. She was aware of all the opportunities and benefits that energy efficiency offers. Nevertheless, of all the possible models, it ultimately opted for one of the least ambitious targets for 2030. By setting a target of 30%, maintaining a number of exemptions and flexibility in Article 7 and in many other areas, it unfortunately failed to meet the expectations of the coming decade. I must therefore ask: where does the principle of 'energy efficiency come first'? Is it left with empty declarations only? Because the facts clearly show that even 40% of the target can be achieved at an acceptable cost. Conversely, this will create new opportunities for the construction industry, for the development of energy services, because the potential for energy savings is far from being fully exploited. If less than half of the options in industry have already been exhausted, for example in the case of buildings, 80% of the potential is still untapped. It is in buildings that significant changes can be achieved at a reasonable cost. By accelerating the renovation of European buildings, we will not only achieve a long-term reduction in energy consumption, but we will also help to address the most pressing issues of energy poverty. Today, millions of Europeans have great difficulty paying money for heat, energy or gas. Very often they also live in flats that are not properly heated or that are unhealthy due to poor heating and ventilation. In addition, any percentage improvement in energy efficiency will help these households pay their energy bills. Finally, I would like to emphasize that, by signing the Paris Climate Agreement, we have committed ourselves to taking measures that will lead to a significant reduction in greenhouse gas emissions, so as not to increase the average temperature by two degrees Celsius. Energy savings should make a significant contribution to this. However, the proposal presented by the European Commission is very far from this. Great results require great ambitions. I believe that we will be ambitious enough to achieve such results in the case energy efficiency.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: rapporteur. - Mr President, what will happen in this vote is very important, because it is really consistency between the commitment of the European Union and the Member States vis-à-vis the agreement of Paris and our legislation, and that is why we need ambition and consistency. It was therefore necessary to have a European framework law on climate and energy. These are therefore important objectives and we defined these objectives with a vision, I would say, for 2050. We introduced the concept of a carbon budget, that is to say what can still be emitted into the atmosphere. to comply with the Paris agreement and see after what remains on the contribution of the European Union. If the European Union becomes a low-carbon economy with net zero energy consumption by 2050 at the latest, it has two major levers, energy efficiency and renewable energies, and I agree with my fellow co-rapporteurs who say that the Commission is not sufficiently ambitious, and neither are the Member States, moreover, to be consistent with the Paris agreements. Likewise, what was interesting - I hope my colleagues will support it - is that we introduced, precisely, the fact that the Commission is developing a comprehensive strategy for methane, because it has a very high global warming potential and that, over five years, for example, a ton of methane does as much damage as 101 tons of CO2, so it's very important to integrate it. Now, on the method: how do you set these goals to music by first developing integrated national energy and climate plans for 2030 every five years, with a perspective every ten years? We know that some states are quite hostile to it, but it is very important to encourage it. Likewise, there must be transparency. We need to develop a permanent platform for dialogue to involve the different layers of society, because if we don't involve partners, communities or civil society, we won't get there. Knowing that the objectives are defined by sectoral legislation, whether it is the directive on renewable energies, on energy efficiency, or on buildings, the report on governance refers to linear trajectories for the deployment of renewable energies and energy efficiency over the next decade, and when you look at it, that's a plus for everything. This is a plus for the security of investments, for job creation and for responding to fuel poverty. However, this can only be done if the objectives are binding, when it is precisely here that the Member States are not in favor; It is therefore important that MEPs encourage this European policy so that these objectives are achieved. And if the European Union or a member state deviates from its path, we need to have a recovery mechanism in place, a kind of toolbox for achieving these objectives. I am therefore counting on my colleagues, because we cannot say, on the one hand, that the European Union is somewhat of a leader in terms of the climate, then, from the point of view of legislation, to be below the objectives set by the Paris agreements. There is therefore a very strong European stake in the votes that will take place tomorrow.

name: Claude TURMES
text: Rapporteur. - When we vote on renewables, efficiency and governance on Wednesday, we will decide whether Europe retains its credibility in terms of climate protection or whether it gives it up. Whether we are giving Sunday speeches that we will forget on Wednesday when we vote. It's about two things: One is ambition. Anyone who deals with Paris, with climate protection and modalizes knowledge, knows that 27% renewables, 30% efficiency will lead to the fact that in the next decade Europe will blow so much CO2 emissions into the atmosphere that we will then - to stay in our carbon budget - would have to be zero by 2030 to 2040, which is impossible. That means: We need more ambitions in the votes on renewables and efficiency, otherwise we have actually already given up the “target below 2 degrees”. The other is the frame. And what Michèle has set out, what we have tried to do in our joint report, is to get the EU to build these very bridges where there are still holes and not enough bridges to the Paris Agreement. Paris has a reporting requirement every five years. We are at ten in Europe and we are now trying to make reports every five years so that Europe is coherent internally and externally. Paris also says: Every report actually has to focus more on climate protection, in English we say ratcheting up - this is also not provided for in current EU legislation. In order to make it clear to the people outside and to the economy outside what it's all about, we need a clear target for 2050. That is why we demand a net zero 2050: 2050 will be zero. If we do not do that - and there is an amendment from the PPE which says: We want to be like in the Paris Agreement. What does that mean? Net zero would make it clear to everyone that by 2050 the last oil and gas heating system must have disappeared, that by 2050 the cars and all transport must function without CO2, and the electricity much earlier anyway. That means: Without a clear indication of where we want to go, how do we want to achieve that society, the people outside, the economy fully recognize this challenge? So one thing is this framework. But because, unfortunately, in the report on renewables, we have given up the nationally binding targets that I have always defended as rapporteur - which is of course a simple, unbureaucratic instrument for getting governments to expand renewables - because we have given up on that In governance, we now have to deal with the question of what it means when we have set 35% renewables as the target at European level, and how we can then put that into such a corset the national governments deliver that? That is why we have designed Article 27 in detail and stretched it wider than what the Commission had drafted. One last thing - keyword energy poverty. We've been talking about it for years. Now we have done it - and I would also like to thank the shadow rapporteurs from the Liberals and the EPP - that for the first time we have a binding text, according to which the governments who suffer from energy poverty at home now also take measures in their national plans Need to seize energy poverty. This is also very important progress for the cohesion between the citizens, in some cases also the poorest citizens in Europe, and the European Union project.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to take this first opportunity in plenary to start by expressing my appreciation for the very constructive role that the Parliament delegation played in securing political agreement at the last trilogue meeting on the Energy Performance in Buildings Directive (EPBD), and to the rapporteur, Bendt Bendtsen, and all the shadow rapporteurs involved. Thanks to the strong position taken by the European Parliament, we saw a political agreement that allowed us to maintain the ambition of the Commission’s original proposal on most aspects and even went further than them on many points.   Turning to the three proposals being debated here today, I would first like to address the proposal on governance. It is clear that strong governance rules will be a crucial for ensuring a resilient Energy Union with ambitious energy and climate policies and for making sure that the whole Clean Energy Package sticks together. We need a reliable approach to governance at European level, notably to ensure the effective achievement of the European Union’s 2030 targets for energy and climate. It is essential to provide a solid system that allows progress to be assessed at European Union level, to put in place specific measures to identify shortcomings at an early stage, and to respond adequately in order to close any potential gap. This will be vital in securing the necessary public and private investment. The Commission welcomes the European Parliament’s ambitions to establish effective and reliable governance for the Energy Union. The report adopted by the joint ITRE/ENVI Committee contains several positive elements that will help to keep such an ambitious approach when trilogues with the Council start. Coherence is one of the central assets of the Clean Energy Package, and it is of paramount importance to continue paying particular attention to this in the work ahead. In this regard, the Commission welcomes your decision to set sectoral targets in sectoral legislation but, nevertheless, the mechanisms securing target achievement should remain in the governance proposal. At the same time, the Commission welcomes the latest proposal tabled on the trajectories to be followed by Member States to reach their 2030 national renewables targets and trusts that it will be supported across the House. We believe that it will be a very positive step forward, laying the ground for a solid agreement in the negotiations with the Council, which has made a major step by accepting the introduction of a third reference point, in 2027, on the trajectory towards the 2030 renewables target. Finding a common ground on this will be an essential element showcasing our commitment towards achieving the energy transition. To keep a coherent and integrated approach, a single Energy Union Committee for the implementation of the regulation, across all dimensions, is also essential. Co-existence of two separate committees would not be the optimal solution because of the many linkages between energy and climate, and it would blur clarity about competence. A single committee would create the necessary synergies and ensure a more coherent and integrated framework. It is in line with better regulation principles, streamlines structures and cuts red tape. We further encourage the European Parliament to keep an ambitious position on the deadlines for the draft national plans, which are important to guarantee the effectiveness of the iterative process, to convey early investment signals to the markets and investors, as well as for the Facilitative ‘Talanoa’ Dialogue under the Paris Climate Agreement. Citizens are at the centre of the clean energy transition. Consumers are becoming the real drivers of this energy transition, and this is well reflected in the emphasis put by the Parliament on the role of citizens and civil society in taking part in the process leading to the definition of climate and energy policies. Finally, we also need to promote additional efforts to tackle energy poverty in Europe. The Clean Energy Package proposes several measures contributing to the alleviation of energy poverty, but I welcome that the European Parliament has recognised the importance of this by strengthening the efforts to be made by Member States to reduce energy poverty.  Let me turn now to the proposed revisions to the Renewable Energy Directive. The aim of our regulatory framework is to ensure a continuous flow of investments into renewable sectors and to ensure its competitive development for the benefit of our citizens and our industry. The Commission welcomes the progressive position of the European Parliament, which is generally reinforcing the overall ambition of the proposal, including on such key aspects as consumer empowerment, administrative simplification and investor stability and predictability. Overall, I believe the text adopted in the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy is a reasonable compromise which takes into account the different positions across the European Parliament and reinforces the proposal for a directive. However, specifically regarding the amendments that have been tabled to plenary, I see some merits on those tabled in relation to the cap on conventional biofuels, which establish national caps instead of a Union cap. This could be a compromise in a very divisive issue that brings the text closer to the balanced approach that the Commission initially proposed.  Another issue is the harmonisation of the sustainability criteria for bioenergy, where the text adopted in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety would lead to contradictory interpretations, potentially opening the door to the introduction of national criteria. We need to make sure that we keep the European Union harmonisation of these criteria, which already exists under the current Directive, so that there is no detrimental effect for the internal market. Finally, I would like to underline our concern regarding the amendment tabled to exclude roundwood and stumps from bioenergy raw material. Excluding these feedstocks by default is neither environmentally desirable nor practical, as it would require all forest biomass used in the energy sector to be certified. We count on the Parliament to support an ambitious report on Wednesday and to work with us for the best outcome on the proposal, considering the general approach adopted by Council in December. Let me now address the Energy Efficiency Directive. It is crucial that Parliament maintains its position on an ambitious energy efficiency level, including the binding character of the European Union target and the strong Article 7. These are key elements, not only for reducing key energy consumption, improving competitiveness, strengthening our energy security, improving air quality and quality of life, and reducing energy poverty, but also in the context of achieving our climate objectives. I am glad to see a compromise emerging around a high ambition level, supported by a strong Article 7. It is a comfortable position for the European Parliament in view of entering into interinstitutional negotiations. Indeed, analyses show that the majority of measures under Article 7 – aims of the renovation of buildings through energy efficiency obligation schemes, fiscal incentives or financing schemes – will deliver real benefits to the consumer in the form of reduced energy bills. Without maintaining a strong Article 7, many profitable energy savings will not take place in the next decade. I would like to warn against two specific proposals. First, even if it is decided politically to introduce an ‘adjustment factor’ for the level of the European energy efficiency target, this factor should certainly not be linked to the level of renewable energy consumption. Renewable energy and energy efficiency are partners, not rivals. Second, we will not be able to maintain a strong Article 7 if we allow excess energy savings from the current period to be carried forward after 2020. This would open a significant loophole and would force the Commission into a position where it would need to intrusively monitor the details of implementation in Member States. Finally, you also proposed to amend a number of other articles which are not part of the Commission proposal. Opening new articles without a proper assessment by the Commission and without the Council taking position entails the risk of significantly delaying the negotiations and sending the wrong signal to stakeholders.  I look forward to this debate on these two different proposals but, before we start, let me remind you again that these are part of a bigger package and, while considering these proposals individually, it is vital that you do not lose sight of the need for coherence and maintaining a high level of ambition. I encourage you now to move forward as soon as possible in debating and voting on the market design proposals in order to complete the whole package.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Ladies and gentlemen, our debate today is somewhat unusual.We heard the four rapporteurs.Now we are going to hear the representatives of the six parliamentary committees.I think we will do it just as well, because the speeches are one-minute long.

name: Florent MARCELLESI
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Development. - Mr President, European energy policy is not just a European issue. If we really want to be a sustainable and supportive continent, the energy we consume in Europe cannot have negative effects on other countries: on the rights of its peasants and indigenous peoples, human rights, the environment and animals. To do this, the European Union must eliminate agrofuels from its energy mix. We don't want palm oil in cars, but we also don't want any first-generation fuel that competes with the production of food for people. On the other hand, we regret that the report on renewable sources did not include the recommendation of the Committee on Development. Social sustainability criteria are needed to avoid land grabs and also sustainability criteria on forest biomass to avoid deforestation in third countries. Clean energy, solidarity and global justice must go hand in hand.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. – Mr President, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI), most of the discussion we had was also on the sustainability criteria of bioenergy: for transport biofuels and also for the energy sector, when talking about gaseous and solid biomass. One clear point that the ENVI Committee was pushing for was a total phase-out of palm oil use for biofuels. I am happy to see that in all the proposals, that part has been copied. So that seems to be a consensual issue within this House, and that is a good thing. However, the second point which was important for the ENVI Committee was to make sure that the market will steer away from the food-based crops towards the advanced electricity. Unfortunately, there are not enough proposals going in that direction: for example, the overall transport target that is still in the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE) position, which will push for food based crops again – we will try to make sure that that 12% ambition is maintained, but not as an overall transport target but there where the ambition should go to advance. The third point on bioenergy for the energy industry: really exclude burning whole trees. That is the only thing we are asking and that seems to be the most sensible thing to do.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the AGRI Committee. - Mr President, in achieving the European Union's energy and climate goals, stronger use of renewable energy sources can be an effective mechanism for reducing dependence on energy imports and an incentive to create new jobs. According to a recently published Ernst & amp; Young, in the solar energy sector alone, it is possible to create 94,000 jobs by 2021, and with the set target of a share of renewable energy of 35%, an additional 120,000 jobs by 2030. In order to achieve the ambitious targets, it is necessary to enable Member States to use all the renewable energy sources at their disposal. We in the Committee on Agriculture consider the proposals that go towards the abolition of the use of biomass and biofuels to be contrary to the interests of the European Union. Not only because we now have 100,000 jobs in the biofuel production sector, but also because by producing highly sustainable biofuels we also produce protein-rich animal feed, thus contributing to the reduction of GMO food imports. I therefore call on you to support the amendments that give all renewable energy sectors the opportunity to reach their full potential.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Petitions. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the citizens of Europe, through hundreds of petitions, have denounced the difficulties and obstacles hindering the spread of renewable energies. They clamored for a stable, clear and transparent regulatory framework, not retroactive, to concretely favor the use, self-production and self-consumption of renewable energy. The opinion of the Committee on Petitions put these requests on paper, called for an increase from 27 to 35% for the EU target for the share of renewable energy consumption by 2030, and called for the reintroduction of binding national targets, which are essential if we want to be credible in the Union's energy transition. Binding Union objectives which, unfortunately, were not included in the final text voted in the ITRE committee. However, more courage, more ambition, more consistency and less hypocrisy are needed. For the 5 Star Movement we need an ambitious but achievable 45% goal to quickly project ourselves into the future of energy, which we want to be renewable, for the benefit of the climate, the environment, employment, and conceived as a common good and as everyone's right.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. - Mr President! On Wednesday, we have the chance to greatly improve the rules so that in the future we can use less energy and switch to renewable fuels. More efficient energy use is a huge opportunity for Europe. We have the opportunity for a large profit chain. With more ambition, we can get more innovations and better finances, which in turn leads to more jobs and changes for the climate. At the same time, we get cleaner air in our cities and we benefit human health. So colleagues, what are we waiting for? Be sure to support the S&D Group's ambitious demands for a 40% energy efficiency target. I would also like to say a few words about renewable energy. If we are to reach the Paris Agreement, we must use the best climate tools we have. The bioeconomy is a huge resource. Do not neglect it. Too detailed regulations in this area destroy the forest's opportunities to convert to better climate benefits and thus a sustainable society. Colleagues, do not neglect it on Wednesday. Then we take responsibility for the climate.

name: Jens ROHDE
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. – Mr President, let me catch up on the very good speech by Mr Turmes and the highly relevant question he asked. How can we ensure that Member States deliver on their targets? This is crucial, as governance is the backbone of the Energy Union. Unfortunately, our answer to that question is: we don’t know yet. My proposal, which was adopted by the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, was to change the Commission’s recommendations into requirements when Member States fail to meet their targets. Unfortunately, this proposal was not adopted by the lead committee, and I must say I regret that. It should have been the answer to Mr Turmes’ highly relevant question.

name: Seán KELLY
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, it was a great honour, if challenging, to be the rapporteur for my Group on the renewable energy file. It was much more complex than I could have imagined, but nevertheless very satisfying because of the spirit and cooperation that existed amongst the shadows, for which Mr Blanco López in particular deserves great praise. Indeed I met him so often out here in the new cafe that I am proposing that it should be called the Blanco Bar. For me there were two key points from the outset. Firstly, there was a need to raise ambition but, secondly, to do that without impinging on investor certainty. I think we have got that in the end. Our increased ambition from 27% to 35% is 30% higher than the Commission’s proposals and, indeed, what the Council want as well. We have given investors certainty, albeit trying to drive them and nourish them under this sustainable criteria into the future. For that we will need a strong vote from Parliament if we are to answer Claude Turmes’ question and now urge the Council to come with us so that we can have Europe as the renewable capital of the world.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: By the way, by the way, a note: maybe you get a significant discount in the bar, if not changing the name of the bar?

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues, I don’t know whether there are many people or there were many people in this room who would have believed that it was possible to build an aircraft that can fly around the world in one go solely on solar panels. Well, science companies, together with Bertrand Piccard, have done that. And how did they do it? They tried to get energy on the aeroplane as low as possible and, as it were, threw away everything that was not necessary. So you had a very energy-efficient aeroplane and then it could fly on solar. And that is the philosophy which we need to apply when we vote on Wednesday. Make sure that we have a very high level of energy efficiency, and then it is possible to achieve a high level of renewables, of which in the long run – though not too long –  we will need 100%. That is why I am very proud of my political group with two excellent rapporteurs on energy efficiency and renewables. We fought for the 40%, and I still hope that we can achieve a majority in Parliament in favour because this not only goes together with our achievements and our commitment to the Paris Agreement, but it is also something that can boost our economy, create jobs and ensure that energy poverty is tackled – which is also something very important to my political group. Finally, the transition to a zero-carbon economy must avoid false solutions. We cannot accept solutions which are not contributing to real greenhouse gas reductions or, by doing a sort of collateral damage, have a negative effect on our natural environment and our biodiversity. So it is very important that we all agree on palm oil – OK – but we must also be agreed on forests and on the fact that we cannot use stamps and round wood as a source of green energy; I hope we can find a majority on that very important issue as well. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Adam GIEREK
text: question asked by picking up a blue card.- You were all the time behind very high target ambitions in terms of efficiency, ie 40% efficiency.Assuming that in 2005 this efficiency was 65%, I would like to know what it should be, in your opinion, therefore, in 2030, if we take into account the 40%, i.e. how much will it be?Up to the 60%, how much will come?

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you, Adam, and when I said we had two excellent rapporteurs, I also meant you, because you were also the rapporteur at the beginning and it was a dual job. I’m not sure – because that was one of the difficulties – that I understood your question fully, because we had a lot of discussions in our group on how to calculate the energy efficiency – the primary energy, the end energy – and I know your views on that. I think that would be maybe a good question for the Commission, because every methodology has its advantages and disadvantages. I know Mr Gierek’s efforts to get a good methodology in place, and maybe that is something the Commission can take up. I do not exactly understand your question, but I can assure you that in the philosophy of what our political Group wants, it is the 40% by 2030.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: for the ECR Group. - In December last year, we voted in the ITRE Committee another large part of the so-called winter package. I will not hide the fact that I can imagine completely different conclusions. From the outset, it has been very difficult to find a common compromise in the discussions that would limit the ambitions that go far beyond the Commission's proposal and the position of the Member States, because that will be a problem in the institutional negotiations. I know from my experience that each target must have economically justifiable costs, and I completely miss those, for example, in the voted binding target of 40% for energy efficiency. Such a dramatic intervention in the energy and heating market will require billions of investments not only from citizens and companies, but also from state budgets. I am afraid that the citizens themselves will not pay the most for the parliamentary ambitions in the final billing of electricity and heat. Energy is one of the key sectors affecting the competitiveness of the EU as a whole. If we overestimate the setting of mandatory parameters for efficiency, renewables and the like, we could severely damage the economies of the Member States in the future.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Thank you very much, I can see ALDE is absent.Therefore, on behalf of the Confederal Group of the European United Left, Mrs Paloma López Bermejo.I am sorry, therefore, on behalf of the Liberal and Democrat Group, Mr Frederick Federley.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, it's easy to miss me, I am only 190cm tall - a Swedish Viking. Mr President! First of all, I would like to thank my colleagues for a good collaboration. I would also like to thank the Commission for its assistance during the difficult and lengthy negotiations. I also think that the Commissioner had a good proposal to try to find a more uniform way of dealing with energy issues in the European Parliament. We could see from the fatal failure of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy - which we in the Committee on Industry have had to clean up after - that we have weaknesses in our way of working in parliament. And that is also what we will be voting on a lot. What has passed the Committee on Industry has had a broad and clear majority and we have had a good spirit of consensus in that work, while it has been more difficult in the Committee on the Environment, with more of a poster policy, I would like to say. I see a lot of that here in this House right now, where countries that have 70, 80, 90, 95 percent fossil energy in their system should tell countries that have around 50, 60, 70 percent renewable energy that you are doing wrong, you are abusing the system. Countries that hundreds or thousands of years ago cut down and deforested their forests and have not got them back should tell countries that have cared for their forests responsibly that you must not behave in that way. Countries that have a broad biodiversity are being overtaken by countries that have significantly less of it. We must get away from this and stick to the facts to ensure that we fight the problem: fossil energy, not renewable energy, which is long-term sustainable and creates jobs and opportunities throughout the European Union.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Thank you very much.I apologize again to you, but in what I got here in the printout in front of me, your name was missing and I thought you were not there.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, first of all, I want to thank Mr Blanco for his work, because it has been truly intense, with as many amendments as they have been presented. Unfortunately, we see how the commitment made by the European Union with the Paris Agreement to achieve 100% renewable energy by 2050 can remain a dead letter. Parliament shows more ambition than the Commission, but the 35% target for 2030 is also insufficient if it is not accompanied by binding national targets. But we are already seeing the lack of political will from the Council. Without binding targets, few countries will comply with a firm commitment and favor the necessary investments in clean energy. In addition, setting a 12% target for transportation will increase existing problems, by promoting the use of biofuels, which means accumulation of land and deforestation. And all this with an increase in carbon emissions. If we do not create the foundations for another energy model that is not in the interest of the market, we will have lost essential time to reverse climate change and its serious consequences on the planet and its inhabitants.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, we are at a turning point. A recent internal report of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), leaked by the Tageszeitung today, must finally open our eyes. We are at the last moment to save the Paris agreement. We have to heavily scale up our efforts; otherwise we can say goodbye to all the targets and goals of the Paris agreement. According to the IPCC report, we run the risk of undergoing 1.5° in climate change as early as 2040, instead of the end of the century. Energy efficiency is the best way to take cost-effective steps to avoid that. But for this we need real action. We Greens see the necessity of an even more ambitious Energy Efficiency Directive, but we are open to some compromises to act together in this House. We have tabled our proposals as amendments in plenary, but there is no way to take ourselves and the Paris agreement seriously beyond that level. We cannot support adjustment mechanisms with unpredictable outcomes. Finally, history will look at and judge us. We must stop all hypocritical talk and walk the walk. That is what the climate needs, that is what the economy wants and finally, that is what the people wish from us.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there are many points that are important to us in this energy package. One concerns EU anti-pollution regulations, which exist for all sectors but not for geothermal energy. In Italy, the mercury emissions of the 34 geothermal plants, for example, according to the only official data available for the Tuscany region, are equal to 1.5 tons of mercury per year. The Union banned classical thermometers which contained just two grams each; therefore it is as if around the Italian geothermal power plants, in a small area, 750,000 thermometers break every year. In the same year, 16,000 tons of hydrogen sulphide and 6,000 tons of ammonia are released into the atmosphere. These quantities are not even included in the Union inventories of polluting emissions. In addition, some types of geothermal power plants, in their life cycle, emit more greenhouse gases than fossil gas plants of the same power, but take incentives for EU climate objectives. For the Union, it is as if geothermal energy with a high environmental impact did not exist: a great regulatory vacuum and a paradox that we have a duty to start filling. We have presented amendments (357 and 358) to the report on the directive on renewables so that the European Commission studies the problem of geothermal emissions in order to assess the need or not for an ad hoc legislative proposal on geothermal, for a truly sustainable geothermal energy, without emissions.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Mr President, Commissioner! The clean energy package is an important building block for a successful energy transition and for achieving climate goals. The three reports we are debating today point the way for a sustainable implementation of this package. The specific requirements that we are adopting in the context of the dossiers in the field of renewable energies, energy efficiency and the governance system of the Energy Union will, over decades, namely up to 2050, the structure of the European energy industry, the structure of many industrial sectors, competitiveness , Employment and consumer behavior. It is all the more important that these requirements can also be implemented, and the present 2030 target bundle of 40% greenhouse gas reduction, an improvement in energy efficiency by 40% and an increase in the share of renewable energies to 35% can hardly be implemented from today's perspective. And if so, then only with investments in the four-digit billion range, which are at the expense of the competitiveness of European companies, hamper economic growth and endanger security of supply. A current study by the BDI confirms this for German industry. The tight vote in the ITRE committee on the energy efficiency directive has shown that there is no clear consensus in Parliament with regard to the new climate targets either. Increasing energy efficiency to 40% by 2030 is neither economically nor technically feasible. This is confirmed by an impact assessment by the Commission. Raising the target to 40% would require additional investment of around EUR 500 billion and increase the overall system by EUR 125 billion by 2030. However, efficiency gains are increasingly difficult to achieve with efficiency and therefore cannot be controlled at will. This debate in relation to the three dossiers is in the interests of planning security certainly not beneficial.Rather, trust in a steady and predictable course of European energy and climate policy is being undermined.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: - Mr President, today's societies are at great risk of global warming and everything that can change on such a scale. The first consequences have already begun to be felt and are only a very small part of what will follow if we do not act decisively. Unfortunately, however, this is a problem that cannot be tackled by each state individually, nor by the European Union as a whole. All countries must make a commitment to really reduce harmful emissions, but that is extremely unlikely. In addition, there is a danger that, in the Union's attempt to take action in favor of the environment, it will create even greater problems than those it seeks to solve. It is not enough to impose strict environmental standards on European companies. I believe that we should ban imports from countries and companies that do not comply with our standards, wherever they are. Finally, I am extremely wary of the over-concentration of powers promoted by this report as it has so far proved to be particularly ineffective. (The speaker agreed to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162 (8)))

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: question asked by picking up a blue card.- Renewable energy - very important thing, for example the sun was reaching the Earth.Plants were formed from the sun and carbon dioxide.From this, coal was made.We are burning this carbon now and creating carbon dioxide again.The sun is coming in.It will be new coal again.Don't you think that the ban on burning coal will disrupt the process of creating renewable energy?

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: answer to a question with a blue card.- I agree with you because this is the cycle of nature.But considering the pollution from countries like China and India, I can tell you that Europe pollutes much less than all these countries.

name: Markus PIEPER
text: - Mister President! Regarding energy efficiency, I cannot help but say something about the performance of the S&D, Ms. van Brempt. Rapporteur exchanged, the new rapporteur tweeted that he had reached an agreement with the EPP on 35%. You yourself tabled an amendment that made 30% binding, and today you are calling for 40% in plenary. Do you actually have a look yourself at what the S&D is asking for? At least we don't. A forty percent savings target, as decided by the Industry Committee, is now unrealistic. Firstly, that would undermine emissions trading, and a forty percent saving target would also apply to renewable energies, and secondly, that would counteract the structural change to electromobility and also to electric heat pumps in buildings. Therefore, support the more moderate savings targets, move away from the rigid renovation quotas for the municipalities and also agree to the adjustment to the development of renewables. The better they develop, the fewer savings we have to make. One more word about Mr. Turmes. We have increased gross national product by 53% over the past 25 years, while CO2 emissions have decreased by 23%. That is a fantastic achievement for the European Union. Let's really move on in this direction and not place undue burden on the economy or business. The world will not end tomorrow! (The speaker agreed to answer a question about the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question.- Thank you very much for the opportunity.Dear Mr. PRESIDENT!Dear Representative!Although I think I could adjust the figures here to what cuts we want in different countries and areas of Europe, but also in the regions - you mentioned rural areas - where livelihoods are a problem, I do not think they will be very concerned aboutenergy efficiency, as poorer people will, by implication, buy cheaper products.Moreover, this current vote does not even cover used products.I understand everything that can be said here, but I would be interested in your opinion, namely, do you see any solution to these in addition to communication campaigns and education?

name: Markus PIEPER
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure. - Yes of course. The Commission has made an excellent proposal: 30% binding, combined with a very intelligent link with Article 7, as to how these savings targets can be implemented in the Member States without us burdening them excessively. And if, on the basis of the Commission's proposal, we as Parliament were to support this proposal with a strong opinion, with an 80% majority, then it would end in a similar way in the trialogue. But if we go in here with 40% or whatever, then we get a slim majority here, and then we are nothing in the trialogue, then we are nothing at all, then the Member States will do what they want with us. Therefore: Please, let's come here with a unified opinion and look for a compromise! (The speaker agreed to answer a question about the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Adam GIEREK
text: question asked by picking up a blue card.- Mr Pieper, while I was no longer rapporteur, you tabled two more amendments.One raises the target to thirty-five.This gives an efficiency of eighty-six percent, the efficiency of the European mix.And the Lord fixes one thousand two hundred and twenty according to the agreed fuel.This is quite an interesting number in mega tons, but unfortunately I think that eight hundred ninety three megatons of final energy is probably not enough.Don't you think?Because that's seventy-three percent.Where does this difference in efficiency come from and don't you think that the final energy should not be limited at all?Thank you.

name: Markus PIEPER
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure. - I am pleased that I am so popular as a discussion partner. Nobody else is here. Thank you very much for that. We really cannot be blamed for not looking for a compromise as the EPP. I also know that the 30% that the Commission has proposed and that the ECR supports is the sensible way to go. Nevertheless, we must speak with a strong voice in Parliament. We must be able to find compromises here and we must not go away with a very close vote. Mr Gierek, I know that there is scientific evidence that we are doing a lot of stupid stuff here. But we are politicians, and politicians must also be able to ultimately reach compromises. And in the end, the Commission's impact assessments prove that we are right somewhere that with such a measured target, if we start with 35% and other things and then negotiate in the Council, the bottom line will be a sensible result.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: – Mr President, Wednesday’s votes are an important opportunity to put Europe at the forefront of the fight against climate change and the fight against energy poverty. Friends of the Earth has estimated that 125 million Europeans live in energy poverty, and we know that energy poverty disproportionately affects our most vulnerable people. Our poorest live in the leakiest houses: single-parent households, older people, the long-term sick and children. Three out of four buildings in Europe are energy-inefficient, and account for 36% of our emissions. It is vital that we set a binding energy-efficiency target of 40%. For every 1% target increase, three million homes can be renovated and seven million people lifted out of energy poverty. Forty per cent – not 35 – is 35 million extra people. On 29 January 2017, we launched the European Energy Poverty Observatory. Energy efficiency is the first fuel, and with the 40% binding energy efficiency target and greater ambition on renewables we can lift people out of energy poverty. We can tackle climate change and halve our emissions and have cleaner air. We can put energy efficiency as the driver of jobs and growth. I call on every group to vote for the strongest possible measures for clean energy for the benefit of all our citizens, especially our energy poor. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: a question asked by raising a blue card.- I would like to ask my colleague, when she speaks so nicely here about the socialists' suffering for energy poverty and how many people in the EU suffer from energy poverty, why did they as a socialist faction not support a legal definition in the text but only a very vague definition in a recital?Because we are the legal definition in the text that we could rely on in the subsequent negotiations, as GUE / NGL proposed.You, as socialists, have simply used something vague again, which can actually be interpreted in any way.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you, and thank you very much to our colleagues in GUE for their support of energy poverty throughout this file. We worked our hardest in terms of the definition of energy poverty. I say to the Commissioner that I know it is one of the first tasks of the Energy Poverty Observatory to make sure that we adopt a definition of energy poverty that can be adopted throughout EU Member States. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Peter LIESE
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- I would like to ask the colleague: when you talk about energy poverty, are you aware that the tenants' representatives are warning against rent increases in view of the ITRE compromise on public buildings, which you supported?Shouldn't we be more flexible about that?And the second: the 40% target.I am one of those who supported this goal four years ago.But are you aware that there are recent studies, also because of the development of the oil price, that the 35% target may be more cost-effective, and could we not agree on it?

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: blue-card answer. – Mr President, in terms of the energy governance file we have deliberately included local energy communities and the rental market. It is absolutely essential in this legislation that not just private households are covered, but that we actually reach our poorest people in social housing and rented homes.

name: Gerben-Jan GERBRANDY
text: - (NL) Mr President, it is very nice that I have no less than a minute and a half to talk about one of the most important subjects of this mandate. Because let's face it, energy is what keeps everything in our lives going: not only the economy, but also our daily life. But Europe has three major problems with energy: 1) the price; 2) it is still much too polluting; 3) we are too dependent on imports from outside Europe. Let's face it: 2017 was the year we imported more gas from Russia than ever before. The solution is the same for all three problems: energy savings and an enormous input of renewable energy. That is the way forward! Is Europe aware of this sufficiently? As Seán Kelly said: will Europe indeed become the renewable capital of the world? Not if we start from the Commission proposal or the rather weak behavior of the Council so far. I look at countries like China, but also the United States - even under President Trump: they are moving much faster than Europe. And India also has a much higher growth in this area than Europe. It's unprecedented. So if we as Europe want to move forward in this area, become energy independent, want a lower energy price and also want to stay within the Paris climate goals, more ambition is really needed. And that has been the line of the ALDE Group from the beginning. It is very much needed economically, ecologically and geopolitically.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: - Mr President, the clean energy package represents the contributions of the European Union to the Paris Agreement on Climate Change. And in Paris we have seen, firstly, the Commissioner for Climate Action and Energy, Arias Cañete, and, secondly, also the governments of the European Union taking their photo. But the fight against climate change is decided with works and not just with photos saving whales. Commitments are required. In this House, the EPP has worked hard not to have binding legislation for the Member States. They have preferred to breathe smoke. For example, in renewables, binding targets have been waived, despite the fact that this worked for the 2020 targets. On the other hand, in energy efficiency, luckily, they have opted for an alternative majority that has allowed it. To be ambitious in energy is to want the best for Europe in the fight against climate change. And it is that energy is also a common and necessary good for people and not everything is market, market and market. One in four people in the European Union suffers from energy poverty while wasting energy and while spending public money on mega-projects for large energy companies.

name: Karima DELLI
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Parliament calls for a ban on the use of palm oil, from 2020. Finally! It was time. It is essential to stop deforestation since, let me remind you, 50% of this palm oil is burned in Europe by our trucks and cars in the form of what we dare call biodiesel. However, this report introduces too low a target for renewable energies in transport. He tells us: 12%. I am asking for it to be binding and free from first-generation biofuels. This is a minimum, at a time when Europe must take the lead in the global renewable economy. Another aspect, we know that there will be more electric transport by 2030, and that is generally a good thing, but there is also unclean electricity, such as nuclear. This report is so unambitious that it opens the door to the nuclear car, which no one knows how to recycle. Mr Cañete, you are going in the right direction, but the final message is that 21st century mobility requires political courage and, above all, real renewable energies.

name: Jonathan BULLOCK
text: – Mr President, all reports on the clean energy plan seem to be focused on two sole objectives, decarbonising Europe’s economy and fighting climate change. The rapporteurs propose to decarbonise the economy by 2050 by building a new EU legal framework that would achieve the objectives of the Paris Agreement. We all know it is a pure illusion to believe that these objectives will help Europe’s energy independence by enhancing energy security and energy supply whilst increasing job opportunities. In fact, intermittent renewable energy sources, such as wind power, are unreliable: they create temporary green jobs. Indeed, a study by the Spanish Professor Gabriel Calzada, of Juan Carlos University, shows that every green job created costs 2.2 real jobs in the real economy. This happens by diverting resources from efficient industries into highly inefficient green projects and by raising the cost of electricity for the rest of the economy. Many of the green jobs were temporary and in almost every case, the subsidy necessary to create a green job exceeded the annual salary. Independence and freedom from absurd targets will allow Britain to rejoin the world and help protect the environment sensibly.

name: Christelle LETARD-LECHEVALIER
text: - Mr President, this governance will oblige the Member States to present national energy and climate plans and tries to impose the Commission as a leader in the field of energy by allowing it to judge the policies and the mix energy efficiency, to the detriment of national interests. Failure to respect the recommendations of this technocratic and illegitimate power would expose States to sanctions. This text is a strong attack on national sovereignties and lays the groundwork for the federalisation of the energy market, despite its strategic nature. Finally, this legislation will be binding on renewable energies, whereas it would be necessary to legislate by promoting carbon-free energies, limiting pollution, but including nuclear power - this was moreover the Commission proposal before the harmful modifications of the protractor. In conclusion, I will mention the other two texts in the energy package. We must certainly strengthen energy efficiency and alternatives to fossil fuels, but we reject the forced development of intermittent energies and the permanent desire of the Commission to extend its field of competence. Finally, you legislate on the need to make European industry cleaner, but refuse to take action on imported products, thus inflicting a double penalty on our industry and our jobs.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: – Mr President, first of all, regarding forestry. Let it remain a competence for the Member States, because it is only there that you have the knowledge and the competence to judge what is sustainable. It is only there that you can reduce carbon dioxide emissions via full-scale reliance on bioenergy. Second, energy governance is about making the European energy union a reality and reaching the targets. There are no differences among the main groups in this Parliament about reducing carbon dioxide emissions, and we agree on that target. The difference lies in whether we are to trust more bureaucracy and regulations or more openness towards new innovations and technological breakthroughs. It is a difference between, I would say, rigidity or dynamics. I believe that we can reach the targets, and even go beyond them, by opening up. And, by the way, I would like to thank Mr Turmes, he is always a nice guy to talk with.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: - Mr President, Dear Colleagues and Commissioners, betting on clean energy means more quality of life, less catastrophes and more sustainability for the planet. But it doesn't mean just that. It also means more security, more development, more growth, more jobs, more opportunities for innovation, better living conditions for our citizens and to put technologies at their service. It means even more possibilities to fight energy poverty in Europe and beyond and, through that fight, it means more health, more education, more peace, reducing forced migrations and armed conflicts. So, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, this legislative package has a red line to be credible. Whatever is approved here in the European Parliament and then closed with the European Council must be in line with the commitments made with the Paris Agreement. It was unthinkable that it did not. It would be totally irresponsible for us to take a different position. I welcome the constructive and positive path that we have taken in the European Parliament. I hope that Wednesday's votes confirm and validate the intense work we have done. I also express my pride in the capacity that my country - Portugal - has had to remain at the forefront of this process. The increase in interconnections, up to at least 15% by 2030, will allow Portugal and other countries to continue on the map. Commissioners, ladies and gentlemen, we are on the threshold of a new scientific and technological era. And in energy, the European Union has always known to be at the forefront. And it is on this path that we have to continue.

name: Anneleen VAN BOSSUYT
text: - (NL) Mr President, Wednesday promises to be a chaotic vote.We have rarely been so divided in Parliament and I deeply regret that.We are given the opportunity to set up an ambitious, but realistic energy policy.Unfortunately, common sense is hard to find: sky-high, binding targets threaten to jeopardize the future of our citizens and our businesses.The European Commission's impact assessments are being pushed aside in favor of priceless utopias.Moreover, we must not forget that the ultimate goal is to achieve the climate goals.So what's the point of arguing for 35 or 40 percent renewable energy if the raw materials used are not sustainable?I therefore hope that after a good night's sleep, colleagues will opt for ambitious but realistic goals in the interests of our families and our economy.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues, you know this is not a committee meeting, so I will not speak on one or two issues at the expense of the complexity of other issues which are equally vital. I would say that this is definitely one of the most important proposals, a key proposal, that we have under this mandate. Yes, it is also true that the European Parliament, in comparison to the Council, has done a fairly good job, but let me make two remarks. One is, yes ambition is important, but there are two things which are even more important: one is that we do something that is not doable, and the second is that we might be ambitious in some parts of this Parliament, but we reach a fragmented result which sends an inadequate political message to the other institutions, primarily the Council. I regret on some of the issues we were unable to maintain a broader coalition due to issues which are difficult to comprehend. So let us do a serious vote and let us send out a message and create a good basis for negotiations, because this is key and we do have to be ambitious and realistic.

name: João FERREIRA
text: - Mr President, cleaner or dirtier, greener or grayer, the so-called 'Energy Union' means nothing but the large and liberalized European single energy market. Its consequences will not be different from what happened in other liberalized sectors: monopoly concentration on a European scale, benefiting energy oligopolies and harming consumers, especially the most vulnerable. For us, energy must be seen as a public good. Public, democratic control of the energy sector is, therefore, a prerequisite to ensure its sustainability, with the necessary paradigm shift based on high dependence on fossil fuels and on unsustainable flows of energy and material for satisfaction basic needs of humanity, but also to ensure that no one is excluded from access to this essential good, fighting energy poverty. We intervened in this process, defending the need for ambitious goals, both in terms of energy efficiency and renewables, within the framework of respect for national sovereignty over this strategic sector and the necessary break with a production method that is fundamentally unsustainable and irrational .

name: Jakop G. DALUNDE
text: - Mr President! We are now discussing the conditions for Europe's energy policy. This week we will make decisions that will affect energy policy for a long time to come, decisions that are crucial for the climate if we are to have a planet in the future that our grandchildren will be able to live on. Renewables are growing all over the world and we will accelerate the green transition by investing in sun and wind, at the same time as we transfer coal and nuclear power to the history books. We Greens want to see increased targets for the share of renewables to at least 35 percent and that these targets should be binding on the member states. It should not be possible for any country to evade our common responsibility. We must also place high demands on energy efficiency, and we want the EU to guide energy policy with regional energy markets that favor renewables and with legislation that requires reduced emissions. We now have the opportunity to revolutionize the EU's energy policy, and we Greens will fight for that.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I join in the desire to take into account the emissions of methane, a greenhouse gas much more powerful than CO2. However, the goal of an "all renewable" by 2050 raises the question of the sustainability of structures such as wind farms, whose energy costs are very high to manufacture and the components are unsustainable. This source of energy is intermittent, interferes with electromagnetic waves and can kill many protected birds. At sea, wind power scares fish away, threatening coastal fishermen. Marine corrosion makes it not very durable and its maintenance is extremely expensive. As for photovoltaic plants, their components are not very ecological, and the repercussions on the price of energy, considerable. Also, the threat of US withdrawal from the Paris Agreement forces us to be clear-headed. Action within the framework of major international organizations will remain more effective than the European Union alone.

name: Olaf STUGER
text: - (NL) Mr President, wonderful stories about clean energy are once again circulating in the audience today.But what is not talked about: the examples that the people who tell those stories themselves give.Those examples are important, because they make yourself credible.Because sincerity is in the sacrifice.My question is, what sacrifice do the people in the room make to save their ideals, a good environment?I'm not talking about buying a Toyota Prius, on which you don't have to pay tax.I am not talking about free solar panels or subsidized LED lamps either.That's easy.No, I'm talking about real sacrifice, things that hurt a little.For example, taking a cold shower every day or no longer going on holiday by plane to sunny places.That kind of thing!If that doesn't happen, then the words here are gratuitous and unbelievable.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the observation is shared. We must build an energy Europe that guarantees our independence and allows us to be competitive in the global concert. We must meet the energy and climate targets set by the Paris agreements. The balance achieved on these texts, the basis for negotiations with the Council, masks differences in approach between the groups. Follower of the carrot more than the stick, we are neither interventionist nor normative, but on the contrary we tend to encourage; this is our vision of governance. Member States, businesses and citizens must be supported so that they can reduce their energy consumption; we need to develop more efficient and sustainable energy sources, products and buildings. The market must be allowed to secure medium and long-term investments through clear and stable policies - this was not the case for first-generation biofuels. We are therefore dependent on importing protein from other parts of the world. Also, to guarantee our independence from GMO proteins and limit deforestation, we need to develop protein crops in Europe, the co-products of which are oils that can be used as biofuels. Here is the illustration of what the circular economy is.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, investing in renewables does not only mean thinking about the planet, it also means saving European industry, jobs and our growth prospects. Alongside the astonishing advances in technologies, the paradigm of politics has finally changed - some speeches already said - from environmentalism to economic competitiveness. Years ago renewables were seen as an investment with certain losses, today they are a very concrete challenge over which world powers such as the United States, China and Japan are battling. We in Europe have many technological and industrial excellences, we have one of the richest markets on the planet to absorb and grow these excellences. We just have to be careful not to throw this heritage away in pursuit of false neoliberal myths.
