Technological revolutions are made with massive and courageous public investments, with ambitious choices, as we of our group here in Parliament want, and with careful public policies, made up of incentives and commercial protections. Just look at the exploit of Chinese photovoltaics to understand what is happening. Protesting against Chinese anti-dumping practices is right but it is not enough: we too in Europe must have a globally competitive industrial policy and, to do so, we need to create an ecosystem that favors a real industrial revolution towards this transition.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: - Mr Chairman! I have the impression that while working on this package, there was a kind of competition or auction going on. Whoever will be more ambitious will do better to save the planet and humanity. We are forgetting that this is an energy package, not a climate package. Unfortunately, ambitions do not always go hand in hand with scientific realism, as Professor Gierek mentioned here many times, in political and economic terms. For example, the German Energiewende shows that excessive ambitions can often painfully collide with reality. Unfortunately, the proposals in these three reports are not realistic, and it will therefore be difficult for us to support them. However, when it comes to the political consequences, I will only mention two. Well, my colleague, Federley, spoke of instructing some countries by others, so it will cause greater tension in the European Union. However, it is even more disturbing that we are forgetting that the Union is a community of law. Therefore, I would like to ask Commissioner Cañete whether Article 194, paragraph two, of the Treaty on the Functioning of the Union, which deals with the sovereignty of states in selecting the energy mix, is still in force.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: - At this point, I would normally like to thank the rapporteurs on Governance for their excellent work and call on you to support the report. Before us, however, lies a document that lacks any deeper relationship and balance towards the documents that it necessarily covers. The current concept of Governance has resigned itself to addressing the issue of overlapping policies and documents, such as the interaction of energy efficiency with the ETS, which is exactly the problem it was intended to address. Only a vague definition of energy poverty, which is plaguing more and more people in the EU, has been included in the document. The regulation contains unattainable linear trajectories for achieving goals that not only do not reflect the economic capabilities of states, but even the elementary laws of physics. Instead of being a balancing tool for achieving the objectives set out in other legislation, this regulation has been misused to push the ambitious goals of the rapporteurs, which are set to turn out exactly as the emission reduction targets for the car industry have turned out. For this reason, I do not intend to support this report in any way.

name: Peter LIESE
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! First of all, I would like to congratulate José Blanco López and the EPP shadow rapporteur on renewables Seán Kelly. Because at this point, with regard to renewable energies, the Commission proposal was - if you may, Commissioner - very weak, and colleagues have worked out a very good compromise. I urge you to support this compromise on renewable energies. There is still room for improvement in the reports on governance and energy efficiency. We as the EPP cannot support the committee text here, and we have serious concerns that the text will be accepted in this way, particularly with regard to energy efficiency and public buildings. That will cause trouble in the municipalities and that will not ensure that we find a large majority here. I therefore ask that we think again and agree on compromises that are realistic and ambitious. Then on Wednesday we can send a signal to the world with a large majority: We want to implement the Paris Climate Agreement. We want to be ambitious. But we also take seriously the concerns raised by the municipalities. (The speaker agreed to answer a question about the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Claude TURMES
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Peter, the Commissioner previously proposed a compromise: at least 35% without conditionality and a strong Article 7. But Mr Pieper, who has unfortunately left us, absolutely wants the following: more ICT, less efficiency.A data center is now being built by Google in Luxembourg, which needs more electricity than the entire Luxembourg steel industry.Well, this is total bullshit.More ICT means more power consumption.So we have to do more efficiency.And the second conditionality on renewables: what would that mean?That would mean that if Germany, France and another third large country made a little more renewables than the weak target, then the European efficiency target would go down by 3 or 4%.Do you agree with me that we need an unconditioned goal of at least 35%?Wouldn't that be the compromise we have to find between now and Wednesday?

name: Peter LIESE
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- Mister President!First of all, I can agree with Gunnar Hökmark's words: It's always nice to have discussions with Claude Turmes, but we don't always have to agree.In the case of renewables, the compromise is also so good because we have a certain degree of flexibility, which is why the EPP has decided to give flexibility in its amendment on efficiency.We can talk about the details, but we want flexibility.The Commissioner also said something about public buildings.If the Greens and the Socialists are ready to withdraw the amendment to Article 5, we would be one step further.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: – Mr President, the clean energy package, which we are dealing with today, is our opportunity to decarbonise the economy while keeping energy affordable for all. I will be dealing with all the different reports because I believe that to reach this target, we need to be ambitious and we need to understand that business as usual this time round will not work. Ensuring clean energy will help our climate and safeguard the wellbeing of our citizens. If we are both ambitious and realistic, we can understand that the way forward is to reduce drastically greenhouse gas emissions, improve energy security, reduce energy bills and eradicate energy poverty, if we are smart enough. We have to ensure investor certainty and accountability. This will lead to the creation of jobs and a marked reduction in air pollution. This is our opportunity. Over the past months, we have worked hard in the various committees to reach a progressive position that can effectively transform our energy landscape, make the transport sector cleaner and fight energy poverty. Today, and in the months to come, we need to send a strong signal – to businesses, citizens and all stakeholders – that this is the time to be competitive, invest further in new economies and ensure clean energy for all.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: - Mr Chairman, Commissioner.The Clean Energy project proves once again that Parliament puts ideological thinking, unfortunately, over common sense.When it comes to energy efficiency, Professor Gierek's proposal to calculate it in relation to primary energy is rational and scientifically justified.Taking the report from the professor compromises the left wing scientifically.The target of thirty five percent renewable energy may be realistic, ladies and gentlemen, but only if we have a full range of energy sources at our disposal.Therefore, I am not in favor of limiting biomass and biofuels.As for the management of the Energy Union, I do not agree with the tendency to limit the competences of the Member States to shape the energy mix.

name: Jerzy BUZEK
text: - Mr Chairman! First of all, thank you to Commissioner Cañete and the committee for preparing the package, and to all my fellow Members for a great, good discussion for over a year in the European Parliament. It was an important discussion. Ladies and gentlemen, we have been talking about realistic goals all the time. There was also a question here: how to convince the Member States to implement this package? Of course, the simplest answer is to keep your goals realistic. It seems to me that these targets are not realistic at the moment: 40 or 35%, especially as the European Commission may in some cases impose a renewable energy target that is unattainable for many countries. But I would like to emphasize very strongly that in this package the vast majority of resolved issues are very positive things, for example system heating, heating. If we want to fight smog, let us support them as in this package. Many other solutions are very positive, so you can generally be in favor of this package.

name: Edouard MARTIN
text: - Mr President, "To your good heart, ladies and gentlemen", that could be the title some would like to give to the energy package. We wouldn't impose anything; States, therefore companies, would do what they could, or rather what they wanted, but what would be their choice if we let them? Finance or the planet, the CO2 market or more breathable air? We can see it clearly, our interests are not the same, some have a short-term vision and we must look beyond tomorrow. But if we are talking about finance, remember that the energy bill of the European Union is 400 billion euros per year, of which 160 billion only to heat public buildings and, obviously, it is a fossil energy, therefore imported. . So we have no other choice than to impose a paradigm shift to gain energy autonomy, to lower the bills for the most precarious families and above all, yes, to save the planet. The text voted in the ITRE committee last December responds to these major challenges. Energy efficiency will make us more competitive, renewable energies less dependent and more in line with the Paris Agreement, and therefore I would like us to remain consistent with what we voted in December in the interest of all .

name: Adam GIEREK
text: - Energy efficiency is the percentage of energy obtained each time it changes from one state to another. It can be a percentage of final energy in relation to primary energy, or useful in relation to final energy. I expressed this, inter alia, as the rapporteur for the draft report, introducing a definition of energy and the need to cover the entire energy flow chain. I also introduced a definition of energy efficiency in the energy mix. I found that primary energy should be limited, not final energy. The draft directive promises energy efficiency as a key topic. However, it deals with limiting the use of final energy, why is this distortion? What is needed is a better than the current mechanism and method of counting in the form of a correct system of primary energy indicators in order to correctly convert primary energy into final energy and vice versa. Primary energy factors are the goal of energy efficiency.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the debate we are having is very complicated because it crosses an enormous number of objectives to find a synthesis, and the work of the political side is immeasurable. Funny sometimes we confront each other by bringing the technical analyzes biased, and often these technical analyzes document different positions even within the technical discussion. Fortunately, there is a place of political synthesis, and this is that place. The work done so far is excellent and is faithful to the balance obtained within the Paris accords. Let's not turn the Paris Accords into a weapon of mass destruction; we keep the best part of these agreements, namely the attempt to ensure a fair balance between the reasons for the environment and the reasons for development. There are examples, such as the case of renewables on biofuels, where we have sinned by excessive zeal: the transition from first generation to second generation biofuels must also take into account the social reasons of sustainable development.

name: Jo LEINEN
text: - Mister President! I have just come back from the annual meeting of IRENA, the International Renewable Energy Agency, and it is absolutely clear: Europe can do more and Europe must do more in energy policy in order to achieve the climate targets. IRENA has done a study for Europe - the REmap study - which clearly shows that it is cost-effectively possible to achieve 35% renewable energies by 2030. IRENA has also calculated what we will save in energy costs and health costs, the astonishing sum of between 50 and 130 billion euros. So we not only invest, but on the other hand we also have a benefit, which is why I am delighted that this 35% target has been achieved. Seár Kelly and Blanco López, congratulations that at least that has been achieved. We thought it could be 40%, but at least we achieved that. Regarding biofuels: They are part of the energy mix, but they have to be sustainable. There are good and bad: promoting the good and getting the bad out of the market - especially palm oil.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. We know that no one can work if he does not eat. Nor can our economy develop without energy. Our factories, our businesses, our transport, our households, our agriculture need energy - everyone needs energy. Unfortunately, we in Europe do not produce enough energy, we do not have it, and we are forced to import mainly from Russia (gas, oil products). We can improve this situation rapidly, that is, we can not only make more efficient use of the energy we have, but also make more use of the very sources we have, i.e. s. renewable - so it is wind energy, solar energy, hydropower, biomass energy. Colleagues, by supporting these two pieces of legislation, we will not only reduce our CO2 emissions and do something good for the environment, but we will also significantly reduce our dependence on imports, which is vital for the whole of Europe. Thank you for your attention!

name: Peter KOUROUMBASHEV
text: - Mr President, let us ask ourselves the question, when we set targets for renewable energy and energy efficiency, whether we have the necessary infrastructure to make this energy revolution happen. We have the example of Germany, which set its serious ambitious goals and then it turned out that it did not have the necessary infrastructure. In terms of interconnectedness, you know that many countries are below the 10% target, and very large and important countries for the European Union, such as Poland or the United Kingdom or Spain. This was noted in the third report of the Energy Union. We also need to set more ambitious targets for interconnection, because without good interconnection we will not be able to pursue our serious energy efficiency and renewable energy targets. And in terms of the fact that a lot of electricity is spent in Luxembourg, not only Google but also Amazon spends a lot of electricity in Luxembourg, but the reasons are not only electrical and sometimes tax, but for this Mr. Turmes can turn for more details to Mr Juncker.

name: Pilar AYUSO
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, today we are debating three proposals that are crucial to meeting the European commitments on energy and climate linked to the agreements on reducing emissions: a target of 27% renewable energy, a target of 40% energy efficiency and a framework for the coordination of energy policies as a necessary instrument to guarantee the fulfillment of these objectives. The objectives are ambitious and reasonable, and achievable if we find adequate instruments to achieve them. In Spain we consider the following instruments essential. First, interconnections, in order to meet the renewable energy target. It is important that the Council's agreements are complied with to reach 10% in 2020 and 15% in 2030. Look, Commissioner, at the beginning of the century, when Mrs. Loyola de Palacio was Commissioner, 10% interconnections were agreed. Eighteen years have passed and we have done nothing. I hope that in the years that remain to meet these objectives this time they will be truly met. And, secondly, the protection of investments already made to produce biofuels before 2020. It is necessary to maintain 7% of first-generation biofuels.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: - (FI) Mr President, climate change has appeared so often in keynote speeches that now that we have time to take action, we must be ambitious. Firstly, the directive on energy efficiency. The purest kilowatt is the kilowatt saved and it is still domestic. Most painlessly, it saves energy efficiency! The ambitious 35% target is in line with the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive, which we completed on the trilogues just before Christmas. Emissions need to be reduced now and in the long term! When we talk about energy, don’t fall for just talking about electricity. We also have transport and heating to take with us. In Europe, unfortunately, cars will not turn into electric cars in three years. Yet we need to tackle almost 40% of transport emissions and energy consumption. That is why sustainable bioproducts and biofuels now play a role in climate work. We will regulate forests with LULUCF and we must therefore support sustainable forest use as part of climate work. The ITRE floor plan also has a good definition of sustainability for new biofuels. It supports raw materials that do not come from food production or feed-backed products.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the meantime I want to thank the rapporteurs because they have done a really great and excellent job. As regards the development of renewables, I am delighted that Parliament is moving towards supporting a target of 35% in 2030. I find that this goal, supported in the first instance by the S & amp; D group, is both ambitious and realistic. and I hope that this result can be confirmed in the trilogue negotiations. I find it necessary, however, given that in this Chamber there is no general consensus on the targets, that they are binding at national level and that in the text to be voted on Wednesday we therefore arrive at a formulation that rigorously guarantees the duty of every country to do everything possible to achieve the objectives. Turning to the energy efficiency directive, I believe that the result obtained is really very important, that in the ITRE committee, and that it must be preserved as much as possible during the vote on Wednesday, confirming the ambition of this Parliament. In particular, I believe it is necessary to speak out for a binding European target - and I hope it will be 40% - and that the strong commitment to reduce energy poverty be maintained.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: - Commissioner Cañete, the renovation of buildings to increase energy efficiency is a great tool that we can use directly and compulsorily to tackle both energy poverty and job creation. We can actually reduce the $ 350 billion bill from fuel imports. At the same time, however, we must reach a realistic goal and, for this reason, compromise between the major political groups is necessary. We need to start, not only with public buildings but also with areas affected by energy poverty. I will tell you only two numbers: in Thessaloniki, last year, in a survey I conducted, 53% of households have difficulty meeting the cost of heating and 7% are unable to pay. It is therefore important that we enable the Member States to define energy poverty until we reach a common definition from the Observatory. At the same time, it is important to implement strong fiscal and growth incentives for energy upgrade projects that will mobilize investments using all available resources.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union currently imports 53% of all the energy it consumes, at a cost of over EUR 1 billion per day. In a context where the cost of renewable energy technologies is falling, the time has come to exploit the potential of all those involved in the energy transition: cities, regions, citizens, cooperatives, investors and businesses. I agree with the choice of a governance able to mobilize and coordinate all these actors to stimulate energy efficiency and the spread of renewable energies. It is essential to reduce the geopolitical risk by limiting our dependence on imports and to stimulate green growth, but some details need to be revised: in particular, in relation to the Energy Efficiency Directive, by providing binding targets for Member States and, in relation to the Directive on promotion of energy from renewable sources, ensuring that it allows the development of an agricultural and industrial chain centered on an entirely renewable and programmable energy source.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, at a time when we are discussing clean energy here, citizens in Greece with demonstrations, rallies and strikes are resisting the new memorandum measures of the bill that reduces the allowances for three and more children, restricts the right to strike, launches electronic increases indirect taxes and sells out 34% of the shares of the Public Electricity Company, PPC, in the occupation fund controlled by the lenders. In addition, the sale of 17% of PPC shares through the HRDH is underway, while the sale to individuals of 40% of the lignite reserves as well as lignite units of PPC and their mines begins. So instead of PPC being exempted, like the Polish and Bulgarian PPCs, from paying gas emission allowances, thus saving 400 million euros a year, eventually the lignite plants are sold to the select lenders. In addition, 100,000 households face the spectrum of energy poverty and there have been 35,000 power outages in poor households due to debt. What do you say, Mr Cañete, about these matters?

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: - Mr President, the issue, I think we all know, is of great importance because it concerns the whole planet and I think it obliges each of us, but also every citizen of this planet, to know, to believe that the homeland of each of us is not are the geographical borders of our homeland. I will not even say that our homeland is the planet. I will go one step further to tell you and the world that the homeland of every human being today is the future. To imagine the future as a geographical space and to define it as our homeland. Only then will we work towards the survival of humanity on this rock. Recently, Mr. Trump, the leader of one of the world's largest powers, saw the snow in America and mocked those who believe there is an environmental issue and climate change. Man can not understand the difference between climate change and whether it rained or snowed somewhere. We must resist him. I close with energy poverty: it is not possible in Europe - let's just talk about Europe since we are here - for some to get cold and some to get hot.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: - Mr President, (start of speech off mic) ... which underlies the Energy Union is worthy of the Soviet Union, and the Energy Union should be abandoned in its entirety. Not only is the European Union forcing states to change their energy policies, it is also harmful to all citizens of the Union. The most tragic aspect of this Energy Union is the so-called security of supply, which seeks to cut off European Union countries from cheap supplies from our European neighbor, Russia, under the pretext of escaping a fantasized geostrategic threat. The economic and ecological absurdity of your policy is that European countries are pressured into buying liquefied natural gas from the United States and Qatar, that is, from across the planet and from a higher cost to consumers. Is this your globalism? Create more carbon footprint with supertankers? What then is the point of making the Paris climate agreements? But the European Union is not with an inconsistency, provided that the private lobbies get richer to the detriment of the Europeans.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: - Mr President, clean energy policy, especially the use of renewables, is another proof of a multi-speed Europe, as is the case with the economy and growth. The EU binding target of a 35% share of renewable energy, with parallel national participation, is not horizontally achievable for all Member States. The reasons are many and heterogeneous. They mainly concern the lack of infrastructure technology and financial resources, making it extremely difficult to implement, manage and monitor uniform support schemes. The protection of ecosystems of biodiversity and the environment in general - directly linked to the production and exploitation of energy - has a cross-border dimension given that environmental pollution knows no borders and the effects of pollution are, over time, multiplicative. In the light of the above, I can say that, especially for energy alone, Europe can and needs to take a more active role, helping and overlapping, where necessary, national strategies and actions.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: - (FI) Mr President, it is important that we set the 2030 targets with sufficient ambition, but still realistic, and, above all, that we take the European energy market in a more efficient, transparent and market-oriented direction. I would now like to raise two issues relating to the Renewable Energy Directive. Firstly, Finland and Sweden are at the forefront of renewable energy in Europe, thanks to their large forest industries, precisely because we use industrial by-products, waste and residues efficiently as renewable energy. Now the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy wants to set new limits on the use of wood for energy. That cannot be considered sensible. It will continue to be good that wood can be used efficiently when it is not fit for anything else - including energy. Another issue relates to sustainable biofuels. We should abandon the approach of listing the permitted raw materials and start with the acceptance of sustainably produced fuels as advanced biofuels. In this way, we would support research, development and innovation in this sector.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: - Mr President, I appreciate the work of the rapporteurs on this very decisive dossier and I congratulate them, but the truth is that in my land, Aragon, mines are closing and fallow is growing, and those who bet on renewables have also ended up ruining themselves. Commissioner, how are we going to guarantee a just transition for the regions and families that live precisely on coal and biomass? Because I absolutely agree to combat energy poverty, but also poverty tout court of the unemployed and excluded, since, for the sake of objectives so ambitious that they force a mortal leap, as deadly as - I remember - we gave in the In the automobile sector, territories and families are thrown into total uncertainty, while neither new jobs nor certainties arrive. With what funds, Commissioner, are we going to ensure that just transition, if we hear that in the new post-2020 multiannual financial framework cohesion and agriculture are going to be sacrificed? With what specific fund can you guarantee it? We need, of course, a just transition with enough funding, both to be credible and for new jobs, and also with enough flexibility in the energy mix so that, while the utopia we believe in arrives, the usual ones do not continue to win. : now in a monopoly, nuclear-based power companies.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - President!Our consolidated agenda is entitled 'Clean Energy' and the aim is to meet the Paris Climate Agreement.At the same time, we want to require Member States to increase their production and use of renewable energy.And we forget that nuclear energy is also clean energy in terms of carbon emissions.Here the illusion lives that we can build as many wind and solar power plants as possible, thus creating jobs and eliminating energy poverty.However, we do not take into account the example that between 2015 and ’16, both wind and solar power output increased in Germany, and the energy produced decreased for both.We want to reduce energy poverty with the most expensive energy, renewable.In 2016, Germany paid € 25.5 billion to support this.You need to set realistic goals.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: - Due to the concern for the environment, we have written in the Paris Agreement that we will make ambitious moves forward in this area, and in the clean energy package, where we are talking about renewables, where we are talking about energy saving, where we are talking about governance in the Energy Union, in this direction. I am convinced that with a compromise that is at the same time realistic, ambitious, that is to say, that we will also have the financial instruments to support innovation, research in this direction, that this is the path we must go. The involvement of citizens, municipalities, the economy is necessary, because this green, clean energy will not be regulated by us deputies, but by the citizens, as well as the economy. An active role of the individual is needed, but at the same time I see in this package an opportunity for the countryside, where we have a huge roof for solar energy, the possibility of wind farms, biomass is created here, both in forests and fields, and we must find this ambitious and realistic goal and achieve this clean package.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank all the honourable Members who have participated in this debate: more than 80 have intervened in this debate. I am pleased to see that Members have acknowledged the importance of these three issues in enabling Europe to drive the clean energy transition. I also reiterate that the three dossiers are strongly inter-linked and that Parliament must remain coherent in its approach, and that the rules that we agree must be ambitious and workable in practice. On governance, I was surprised that some honourable Members expressed the view that the governance initiative will undermine the Member States’ right to choose their energy mix. The opposite is true. The basic rationale of the initiative is to fully respect the principle of subsidiarity and the balance between the European Union and Member States in the area of energy. This is reflected in the approach, which is through national plans set out at national level rather than plans being imposed at European Union level. That is why the governance proposal is such an important proposal. Some of you have also questioned, or raised doubts, on whether this proposal will be strong enough to ensure that the 2030 targets are met. My initial reaction is that the Commission proposal was established in order to achieve those targets, but Parliament has improved the proposal and these gains are to its credit. Parliament has analysed the proposal, has considered the weaknesses it may have, and has reinforced it accordingly. I think that jointly, with the basic proposal of the Commission and the improvements that Parliament has introduced, we have a very important tool to make sure that the targets that we establish are achieved. Because the overall majority has been in favour of more ambitious targets than those proposed by the Commission we are at a very good starting position for the trilogues that are going to be extremely complex. Without our good-governance proposal, all the rest is meaningless. Today I want to thank the rapporteurs for their efforts. They have done excellent work. It is a very difficult exercise, and on Wednesday we will have difficult votes, but lots of work is now behind us, and the Commission wants to give thanks for all the effort made. Coming back to renewables, let me say that overall the compromise text that is emerging in Parliament also represents a very good negotiating position for Parliament in view of the trilogues. Mr Blanco López has done excellent work, as has Mr Turmes and, certainly, Ms Rivasi. I see broad support for a high overall level of ambition for renewables deployment in Europe, including the importance of Europeanising renewables policy and strengthening investor certainty in this context. The regulatory framework that you are putting in place should enable greater cost-effectiveness and the sustained deployment of renewables in our electricity sector, in buildings and in the transport sector. On energy efficiency, I want to reiterate again the importance of maintaining a high level of ambition for Article 7 to enable economically viable energy savings to be made over the next decade. How can we say that we want to do more to encourage energy efficiency if, at the same time, we undermine the best instrument we have, which is Article 7. So there is a contradiction sometimes, and we have to solve that. I expect that Wednesday’s vote will solve these contradictions. The debate on energy efficiency also showed strong support for a high level of ambition for energy efficiency and a strong Article 7. That’s very positive. If you see what happened in the October 2014 Council, when energy efficiency was proposed at a level of 27, the Commission acknowledged that this was not enough and then proposed a binding level of 30. Now you are proposing higher levels, and the trilogues will be complicated and the Commission will act as honest broker to get the best final energy-efficiency proposal. There have been some more comments, particularly Professor Gierek, who consistently drew attention to the need for a life-cycle method to calculate energy use. I agree that this is relevant both for policy analysis and for policies like ecodesign that look at particular products. But if we apply it to the whole energy system it will cause problems such as double counting of energy use, so the Commission prefers to keep the Eurostat method for calculating energy efficiency. Just a final comment to Mr Jávor. It is true that the media has said that there is a draft procedural report, but the final report is going to be released in October 2018. The final IPCC report is a very important input to the Talanoa dialogue and for the preparations in the run-up to COP24 in Katowice. But the Commission will wait to see the final report to take the appropriate conclusions once the report is fully approved. I will just finalise by thanking all of the House for supporting these three pieces of legislation which are central to setting the new regulatory framework for the clean energy transition and for delivering our Paris Agreement commitments. This week’s votes will finalise Parliament’s position on these issues and will be an important point of reference that will establish the pathways to a final agreement with the Council. In the climate package with the emissions trading system, land use change and forestry we have been able to secure very complicated agreements. These future trilogues will be much more complicated, and I count on the good will of the rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs, to try and agree the best possible compromise for the sake of European citizens for the fulfilment of our Paris Agreement commitment and in order to preserve our planet.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: Speaker. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you very much for the important debate we have had. I also want to thank all the people, groups, associations, NGOs, industry, with whom, throughout this time, I have spoken to try to forge an agreement that was based on two premises that have been highlighted here , which were ambition and realism. Ambition and realism is the proposal we have on the table. And I want to say something clearly in the face of some doubts. Decarbonization is not a drag on the economy. On the contrary, it is a factor for growth, competitiveness, job creation and quality job creation. And we have to make this bet at this moment, because, in addition, as Parliament, as the representative of the citizens, we have an appointment with history, which is to bet decisively on the fight against climate change. And knowing, ladies and gentlemen, the Council's proposal, I would like to appeal to further strengthen Parliament's proposal with a clear and forceful vote to overcome the obstacles that we still have to achieve that objective of making a commitment to clean energy, to make a commitment to renewable energy. I already know that we all have nuances, we all have national interests, we all have something to do with a sector that is very important in our country, and we have doubts. But the challenge ahead of us cannot generate any doubts. We cannot follow deniers like Trump, who deny what we have above us. We have to have a high view and we have to respond as Parliament to this appointment with history. That is why I thank everyone, Mr Kelly, Mr Turmes, Mr Henkel, Mr Federley, Mr Tamburrano, Paloma López Bermejo, all the shadow rapporteurs, for the great work they have done. May that great work be matched by a resounding vote tomorrow.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: rapporteur. - I would very much appreciate Commissioner Cañete's helpful speech. We have heard a number of arguments which show the importance of this directive. I think we are all aware of it. We recognize that reducing consumption is essential to ensure the long-term competitiveness of our economy and is key to reducing CO2 emissions. It is also the most effective solution to energy poverty. For these reasons, we should take very ambitious measures to promote energy efficiency. The Energy Committee did so in December last year. It turns out that accepting a 40% commitment will have relatively great benefits for the European economy and businesses, despite the high costs. In the case of buildings, we know that it is in this sector that there is great potential for savings, which we have so far used only 20%. That is why it is important that we keep Article 5. We also need a very strong Article 7, because the amount of exemptions and flexibility that Member States use then brings only 0.75% savings instead of the expected 1.5%. I would like to take this opportunity to thank Professor Gierek and all the other rapporteurs for their very useful and high-quality work in preparing the report of the Committee on Energy, and I would call on all colleagues to support this opinion of the Committee on Energy, Research and Innovation; a directive very important for implementation throughout the energy union.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: rapporteur. - Mr President, I would like to thank all the colleagues who spoke, because the debate was very rich, and I find that, as Mr Blanco López said, "we have a date with history". I've heard a lot about the targets: 35%, 40%, whether it's energy efficiency or renewables. I think we have to be very ambitious on this issue because, on the one hand, there will be a trialogue and we will still come up against positions that can be very different from a Member State to the other, therefore, we must be ambitious, and, on the other hand, we have everything to gain. Indeed, if we are ambitious on renewable energies, we can really have a renewable energy industry in Europe, which means employment and less dependence on other fossil fuels. As for energy efficiency, the more ambitious we are, the more we can respond to innovation, which is still a characteristic of Europe, and to fuel poverty. Therefore, in this discussion on goals, let's be ambitious to respond to COP 21. Then, I find that perhaps we haven't discussed enough about governance itself, because everything is going to depend on national plans. that the States will propose, the evaluation of these plans and the possibility of redressing the situation if, in 2020, we feel that the trajectories will not be up to par. We will have to be very firm on prices so that there is a commitment from the Member States, so that the Commission can assess national plans and that the bar can be raised, if ever it is impossible to achieve these objectives. Also, I hope that on Wednesday we will respond "present" to the appointment with History and that we will not be short of what I would say the world of positioning Europe expects.

name: Claude TURMES
text: Rapporteur. - Mister President! Ambition and realism - Ambition must mean on Wednesday: at least 35% renewables, at least 35% energy efficiency, without the weakening suggested by Mr Pieper that if we do more than ICT, less efficiency would be necessary, or if we do more renewables, too less efficiency, and a strong Article 7. Maybe also an appeal to the PPE, which has already done a good job on renewables, we can get there on efficiency. We need a clear goal in governance. If we tell the citizens and industry in Europe that we want to be at net zero by 2050, then we will create a clear goal. Carlos Moedas, our Commissioner for Research, wants to innovate with a clear goal: Mission Zero - Mission Zero 2050, and that is why I would be happy if the EPP also voted on Wednesday so that we don't have some shaky outlook, which would be: with Paris compatible, but a clear net zero goal. Perhaps one more word to the Commissioner, and also to all of his excellent team: Mr Cañete, you are right! It is this alliance between you as the Commission - which is also prepared to say: our proposal was good, but it can get even better - and us as the European Parliament: if we manage on Wednesday that we have an ambitious and realistic position, Then I am very optimistic that, with the help of a number of progressive member states - Germany, France, Sweden, Luxembourg, Portugal, Ireland - we can then negotiate this text upwards as a whole so that we can send Mr Cañete to Krakow at the end of the year can come up with good news, namely that Europe continues to work properly on climate protection.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 17 January 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. - The report by my colleague Blanco López is extremely important work, especially for the objectives set. Parliament has finally approved new binding targets at EU level, for a 35% improvement in energy efficiency. This minimum target must be achieved with the joint commitment of all Member States, through the definition of new binding national measures, including in the transport sector, which is responsible for around 75% of final energy consumption in the EU. The deployment of renewable energies in the Union is hampered by complex administrative procedures which require long waiting times. Shorter deadlines are therefore needed for smaller projects, the implementation of which does not require the same thorough consultation and assessment as for larger installations. Parliament has reached a broad consensus in favor of considerably higher targets for 2030. This is the way forward in the near future if we are to fight climate change and deliver on the ambitious Paris commitments. I hope that this important milestone will encourage Member States where there are 50 million people, who find themselves in a situation of energy poverty, and where therefore, the use of renewable energies has a fundamental role to play in the development of a new energy system model.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. – The Renewable Energy Directive achieves its aim of establishing a strong framework for enshrining the Paris Agreement in EU law. We must keep the promises we made in Paris on carbon emissions, energy efficiency and renewable energy. We must shoulder the responsibility to fight for future generations. So much remains unfinished. We knew that we would not solve all of our challenges in one year or one lifetime. If we are to achieve the goals we have set out to achieve, then we must collaborate with everyone at all levels. All across Wales, communities have developed innovative solutions for energy-efficient homes, and to reduce fuel poverty. Now we have an opportunity to show the rest of Europe what we have achieved. In order to achieve our high ambitions, we must come together. Now is the time for unity.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing.- Invest more in renewables, bring their consumption to 45% and work for sustainable geothermal energy.According to the 5 Star Movement, to change the pace in terms of energy, we can only be ambitious on the Clean Energy package.For this, we have asked to increase the renewable energy consumption target by 2030, to at least 35%, and to reintroduce the binding national targets.With reference to the regulatory vacuum in the field of geothermal energy, we ask the Commission to take note of this vulnerability, examine the issue and consequently formulate an adequate and sustainable legislative proposal.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: in writing. - The aim of the Commission proposal is to create a regulatory framework for the governance of the Energy Union as part of the simplification and integration of current planning, reporting and monitoring obligations in the field of energy and climate. Another goal is to define a robust political procedure between Member States and the Commission in close cooperation with the other EU institutions to achieve the Energy Union and its 2030 energy and climate goals. I expressed my opposition to this report as there is no agreement on the following: the inclusion of energy poverty legislation in the national energy and climate plans, changes beyond the scope of this regulation in the case of the Effort Sharing Regulation, linear trajectories in the renewable energy sources and the Energy Efficiency Directive, and plans to adopt more ambitious targets in the national five-year growth plans. The ECR group has tabled alternative compromise amendments. Unfortunately, none was adopted and the intention is to resubmit them to key votes.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: written. - The Renewable Energy Directive is one of the most important EU actions to achieve significant emission reductions. We legislators decide on climate action, but the real climate work is done by European citizens and businesses, from small to large. For this reason, climate policy must be coherent and far-sighted. Involving companies in climate work and generating new innovations requires that we do not change the rules of the game every couple of years. One significant part of the renewable energy package is bioenergy produced from wood-based biomass. It is absolutely vital that this Parliament supports the sustainable and responsible use of wood. Sustainability criteria for the energy use of wood must be based on national forest legislation. The market must allow parts of wood to be directed to the most valuable uses within agreed rules and policy objectives. Bioenergy production does not need more EU bureaucracy. The most important thing to keep in mind is that achieving climate goals requires ending dependence on fossil fuels. Europe's forest resources are greater than ever, so we can sustainably increase the use of wood-based raw materials in transport, electricity generation and heating.

name: Jarosław KALINOWSKI
text: in writing. - The drive to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in order to limit adverse climate change is definitely a worthwhile action. Technological progress and the development of biofuel production made it possible to use natural resources more sustainably, created an additional thousand jobs and became a significant industry branch of great importance for the economy of individual countries and the development of agriculture. The amendment to the directive on renewable energy sources (the so-called RED II), which we are going to vote on, introduces restrictions on the production of first-generation biofuels (from arable crops), setting a ceiling for their share in the transport fuel mix at 7% by 2030. palm oil as a raw material for their production until 2021. Giving up palm oil is the best decision - it is a competition for rapeseed grown in Europe, and its production leads to the cutting down of tropical forests. However, reducing the production of conventional biofuels is not a win-win solution for European farmers and producers. The money they spent to meet the production ceiling sufficient to meet the directive's previous target of 10% has not yet returned, and the investment period is still ongoing. Therefore, in my opinion, we should maintain the share of first-generation biofuels in transport at a level sufficient to return the investments made and develop efficient methods of producing advanced biofuels (from non-consumable biofuels).

name: Jaromír KOHLÍČEK
text: in writing. - This directive follows Directive 2009/208 / EC and the October 2014 decision, when the European Council planned at least a 27% share of renewables in EU energy consumption in 2030. The EP asked the Commission to increase this target level to 30%, while current trends continue, the share of renewables in consumption will reach only 24.3% in 2030. The Directive provides for the promotion of renewables through appropriate state aid schemes and other measures, which include, inter alia, cross-border overlap. It is also expected to increase renewable sources in cooling and heating. In transport, a harmonized approach is required with regard to international trade in biofuels. In this context, the governance proposal for the Energy Union is an important coordinating element. This includes planning - here Member States formulate national energy and climate plans, as well as reporting and monitoring, with states reporting on progress in implementing their national plans. Thirdly, adjustments or filling gaps, where in 2025 the Commission will carry out an in-depth analysis of progress in the field of renewables. It is estimated that between € 1 billion and € 1 billion in renewable electricity alone will be invested in the EU between 2015 and 2030 alone. Regardless of the reality of the estimates or targets, it is clear that without a carbon tax, these ambitious targets are not very realistic.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: written.- Climate change is advancing much faster than scientists have been able to model.To tackle climate change and reach the Paris Agreement, Europe and the world need to do twice as much and set twice as ambitious targets.EU climate policy initiatives on renewable energy, energy efficiency and energy union governance will play a key role in Europe's response to this challenge.It is important e.g.a ban on the use of energy from feed or fodder plants and palm oil and the elimination of double counting of pulpwood and tall oil.Strengthening the use hierarchy will help to ensure that raw materials that could first be used for other purposes and then incinerated do not end up being subsidized as bioenergy.

name: Carolina PUNSET
text: in writing. – The Governance Regulation is the umbrella legislation of the Winter Package, covering all dimensions of the Energy Union, and a vital foundation for achieving the overall objectives of the Energy Union and the EU targets set out in the sectorial legislation for Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency. It is the backbone of the Winter Package, which will drive the transition to a renewables-based and energy-efficient economy. To deliver in an accountable and robust way, it is extremely important to have a strong and ambitious governance system in place that will bring about legal certainty and predictability for investors, beyond 2030. This is vital to unlock investments in all sectors, to avoid stranded assets and to increase the EU’s credibility in delivering in a coherent and effective manner the goals of the Paris Agreement. Governance is the key for businesses, for citizens, for the climate, for our future. The EU needs to demonstrate it is serious about the energy transition and turn its commitments under the Paris Agreement into concrete actions.

name: Pavel POC
text: in writing. - I clearly welcome the ambitious recast proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the promotion of the use of energy from renewable sources. I firmly believe that the European Union will learn from its previous mistakes and will not allow its policy in this area to continue to contribute to the deforestation of rainforests around the world, land grabbing, the destruction of biodiversity and the devastation of local communities. In particular, I support the proposal, which stipulates that the contribution from biofuels and bioliquids produced from palm oil will be 0% from 2021. This proposal reflects its resolution of 4 April 2017 on palm oil and rainforest management, in which the European Parliament called on the Commission to take measures to phase out biofuels, but preferably by 2020, the use of vegetable oils, including palm oil. , due to which forests are being destroyed. On the contrary, I cannot agree with Amendments 296 and 346, which require that biofuels, bioliquids and biomass fuels produced from forest biomass do not include stumps and logs. Although the risk of using unsustainable forest biomass production needs to be minimized, such a proposal is too restrictive and does not take into account the use of rotten wood or wood that is, for example, unsuitable for processing in terms of color or quality. I believe that the directive should continue to allow the processing of wood that is damaged in this way.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: in writing. - The energy package on which we are voting was expected and necessary. Let us be clear, this package is essential for achieving the European Union's climate objectives: with it, we must give concrete form to our commitments to make the European Union a leader in ecological transition. We cannot tolerate too many exemptions, too much flexibility and allow mechanisms to develop which generate perverse effects. We must maintain the level of our ambitions and our objectives in order to curb our greenhouse gas emissions. The legislative report on the development of renewable energies should make it possible to significantly engage European policy towards clean fuels. This is about promoting technologies with the lowest carbon footprint. After applauding with both hands the ratification of the Paris Agreement, we must take action. Let us not be spectators of other world powers, let us stop wanting to spare a model which has already shown its limits. It is time, on the contrary, to initiate the change for truly clean energies, in the service of virtuous growth that benefits everyone.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: written. - Parliament has already made many progress in revising the Renewable Energy Directive. Among other things, the report proposes raising the target for renewable energy from the 27% proposed by the Commission to 35%. Ambitious goals like this are essential to curbing climate change. It is relevant what kind of raw materials are used to achieve the target level of renewable energy. Using tall oil as a raw material for biofuels does not make sense for the climate. Tall oil is not a waste but a raw material that can be used for higher value-added products. At the same time, new jobs can be created and economic growth promoted. We should be critical of raw materials that, in direct energy use, release large amounts of carbon into the atmosphere. Hundreds of scientists worldwide have argued for it. I hope that the waste hierarchy will be applied to the use of forest biomass. For example, wood can first be used for higher value-added products, in which case it sequesters carbon longer and only then is it used for energy production or as a biofuel. In a functioning circular economy, the application of the waste hierarchy does not pose any problems. This does not mean that the use of forest biomass for energy and biofuels will be banned altogether, but that the goal must be the sustainable use of forests in terms of carbon emissions.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: in writing.- There is no doubt that we need to improve the condition of the natural environment.That is why the discussion on clean energy is, in fact, about instruments that are supposed to promote energy from renewable sources and improve energy efficiency.In my opinion, it is crucial to adopt the principle that improving energy efficiency does not only refer to energy end-use.This is because energy saving can be stimulated and achieved throughout the entire energy chain.The second problem is that improving energy efficiency will not be the same in every sector of the economy.There are simply less and more energy-intensive sectors of the economy.If we define excessive targets for improving efficiency in energy-intensive sectors of the economy, they will be transferred outside the EU, which will cause a number of social and technological problems.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the report by Gabriel Mato, on behalf of the Committee on Fisheries, on the Proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the conservation of fishery resources and the protection of marine ecosystems through technical measures, amending Council Regulations (EC) No 1967/2006, (EC) No 1098/2007, (EC) No 1224/2009 and Regulations (EU) No 1343/2011 and (EU) No 1380/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council, and repealing Council Regulations (EC) No 894/97, (EC) No 850/98, (EC) No 2549/2000, (EC) No 254/2002, (EC) No 812/2004 and (EC) No 2187/2005 (COM(2016)0134 – C8—0117/2016 – 2016/0074(COD)) (A8—0381/2017).

name: Gabriel MATO
text: speaker. - Mr President, dear Commissioner, my first words must necessarily be of gratitude to all those who during this time have worked so that finally today we are debating this important dossier, many times from totally different points of view, but always with great spirit constructive. It has been almost 21 months of work, 77 meetings and many hours of debate with the Commission, with the Council, with fishermen, with NGOs and with all those who have wanted to join this challenge. Because it is a challenge to face a dossier such as the technical measures that regulate how, when and where fishermen can operate and that has already had two failed attempts to review. And this challenge is complicated when we want a regulation to encompass more than 30 provisions, some of them based on legislation dating from 1998 and which has become over time a complex, impractical and very rigid system of rules. But no one doubts that it is necessary to review technical measures. And nobody doubts that it is necessary and urgent to try it soon, since Brexit is approaching, but also the end of this parliamentary mandate. My goal, and I think everyone's, was simplification, without reinventing rules, but making them more understandable and viable for operators and administrations, through regionalization and results-based management, which gives fishermen greater flexibility and brings decision-making closer to the regions and local specificities, while maintaining the guidelines, so that we offer the sector equal conditions and rules that are adapted to the reality of each fishery and each marine basin, and thus, at the same time, the institutions of the European Union do not lose control of the most important characteristics of technical measures. I believe that all these objectives are reflected in the commitments reached, in which we have taken into account the The hard work that the Commission has had with the Council for a long time, and that is why I ask that during the vote we keep the commitments as they were adopted by the Commission. This is precisely why I believe - because a lot of work was done and I think well - that the package of commitments is very balanced. Regarding the objectives, something that worries the Commission and also us, the compromise that I proposed and adopted in the Committee on Fisheries is ambitious and balanced. It includes a progressive reduction in catches of small fish as the main objective of future regulation on technical measures, leaving it to Member States or the Commission, if Member States do not adopt joint recommendations within a limited time frame, with the best possible advice to establish key fisheries. And, if the reduction in juvenile catches is not accompanied, as some claim, by a percentage of concrete figures, it is not due to a lack of ambition, but rather because of the need to be more pragmatic and take into account the realities of each fishery in a given fishery. basin. Regionalization will play a key role in setting measurable targets and the Commission will be no stranger to this process. Rather than an arbitrary or symbolic figure, the compromise seeks tailor-made, scientifically and operational-based targets, tailored to each fishery. The Commission asserts that the absence of a quantified target will create unequal situations in the various basins of the European Union. I think the main thing is to set realistic goals because there is no greater injustice than imposing the same rules for different situations. Finally, in recent days a new front has been opened that has polarized positions and created divisions in the various groups. An attempt has been made to paralyze the dossier and the debate has been monopolized, leaving aside very important issues, only around electric fishing. There are who try to, thinking of twelve years ago, change what was done then.I believe that it is a controversial issue, that there are defenders and detractors, but regardless of maximalist positions, the amendment or compromise that is offered is a compromise that I sincerely believe meets the objectives.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would first like to congratulate the rapporteur, my colleague Mr Mato, his team and the Committee on Fisheries (PECH) for the work done to achieve the report on our proposal for a new technical measures framework. Regulating technical measures is about setting out how fishermen can go about their work at sea – what gears to use, what specifications to meet and which standards to strive for. It is therefore a key element of how our common fisheries policy operates on the ground. The current legal framework is quite old and no longer in line with the ambitious objectives of our reform policy in terms of greater sustainability, as Mr Mato said.  I welcome Parliament’s position, which embraces key elements of the Commission’s proposal, including a firm rejection of reinstating the existing complex array of technical rules and support for the Commission’s proposal on measures to protect sensitive species and habitats. We also welcome the PECH Committee’s approach on how regionalisation would work in the context of technical measures. However, I would like to take this opportunity to discuss several areas of concern. This is the third attempt to reform technical measures legislation, and our proposal was based on the concept of results—based management and accountability by the operators. This was proposed to deliver simplification and flexibility to amend technical regulations at a regional level, while retaining oversight and minimum standards by setting quantitative objectives. I have to express my disappointment in the fact that the clear and measurable EU targets included in the Commission’s proposals have been deleted in the draft EP’s report. These targets would introduce accountability and be the basic measuring stick for results—based management. It is a fundamental element of the Commission’s proposal, and its deletion risks emptying the proposal of much of its intended purpose. For example, the draft report introduces compromise amendments to regionalise the rules governing the use of different mesh sizes. With no EU quantitative objectives and targets, there is no way to ensure that regional rules will deliver greater sustainability and selectivity in line with the CFP goals. The deletion of EU targets therefore represents a major concern about how regionalisation may work in practice. We no longer have common objectives across Union waters. We therefore run an unacceptable risk of having an uneven application of a common policy between different areas, and of having different level playing fields between our fishermen. This is of significant concern, as it undermines the core principle of the CFP.  My second concern relates to the EU landing obligation. The reform of the CFP aims at gradually eliminating the wasteful practice of discards through the introduction of the landing obligation. This radical change in fisheries management aims to improve fishing behaviour through improvements in selectivity. Amendment 136 essentially introduces a derogation from the landing obligation on the condition that all catches are fully documented. Here I would like to point out that the obligation to fully document catches is already a legal requirement. In effect, this amendment would provide an exemption from a key element of the CFP. If this amendment is passed, it will significantly undermine the incentive for fishermen to improve selectivity.  I am also aware of the discussions surrounding the issue of electro-pulse fishing, and I would like to remind you that the current technical regulations permit the use of electro-pulse fishing on a limited basis. In our proposal we have proposed to remove the five-percent limit, but to retain the geographical restrictions to the southern North Sea. This is based on advice from both the Scientific, Technical and Economic Committee for Fisheries (STECF) in 2012 and ICES in 2016. ICES, for instance, considers that the conventional way of fishing by beam trawling has a negative impact on ecosystems, while electric pulse stimulation, if properly controlled and applied, may offer a more ecologically benign alternative way of fishing by reducing unwanted by-catch, reducing seabed damage and lowering CO2 emissions.  There are other elements in the report that are problematic, such as amendments that weaken existing provisions – to protect sensitive habitats in the Mediterranean, for example – or amendments that dilute measures to protect vulnerable deep—water sharks and other vulnerable species of marine mammals and reptiles, but the specific issues I raised earlier – that is the removal of Union—wide quantitative targets and the blanket derogation from the landing obligation – would seriously undermine the Commission’s original proposal and key elements of the CFP. Therefore, I have to be very clear that Amendments 52—60, 68 and 171 are unacceptable for the Commission, as these would remove common targets. Equally unacceptable are Amendments 130, 131 and 136, as these would undermine the landing obligation. We therefore count on your support to ensure that the CFP delivers on its key objectives through a meaningful revision of the technical measures guiding fishing activities.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in European waters an alarming number of fish stocks continue to be overfished and by-catch levels of non-target species often remain high. It is therefore clear that the current regulatory structure for technical measures has not achieved optimal results. In order to assess the effectiveness of technical measures, specific targets should be set with regard to the levels of unwanted catches, the level of by-catches of sensitive species and the extent of seabed significantly damaged by fishing activities, targets that are compliant to the objectives of the CFP and above all established on a solid scientific basis. Regionalization may make it possible to develop technical measures more suited to the specificity of the various types of fisheries within the regional multiannual plans. Finally, electric impulse fishing, representing a form of unfair competition towards small fishermen and being a non-selective technique, which risks causing enormous damage to the marine environment, is in my opinion a practice to be prohibited at least until more sustainable conditions from an economic and social point of view will be established.

name: Alain CADEC
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs for the enormous work they have done on this very complicated dossier. The regulation on technical measures should determine where, when and how fishermen can fish. It is essential to modernize the current rules to adapt them to the sustainability objectives of the common fisheries policy, while respecting the principle of regionalization. As far as electric fishing is concerned, I would like to reiterate my position, which is also that of the French delegation of the PPE Group: I am against electric fishing and we will vote for banning it. However, in the event that the ban is defeated, I have tabled a fallback amendment against extending this method, which proposes the status quo. The current framework allows 5% of the Member States' fleet, limited to the southern part of the North Sea, to use this method on an experimental basis. If this current framework is maintained, it is imperative that the 5% limit be respected by the Member States present in this basin.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, technical measures are rules that establish how and where fishermen can fish and their main purpose is to ensure the sustainability of resources and economic activities related to fishing. Currently they are contained in over 30 different regulations and this complexity and fragmentation weighs on fishermen, who have been asking for a radical simplification for years. I have always argued that technical measures represent an opportunity to put the principle of regionalization into practice and we have tried to work on this because, unfortunately, up to now regionalization has been more on paper than in the real common fisheries policy. Too often fishermen have perceived European standards as distant and burdensome from an administrative point of view and that is why, Commissioner, we have included this solution on the regionalization of targets, which does not mean reducing the objectives but means making them consistent with the characteristics of the various territories. The complexity of the dossier, it is true, required long negotiations in the PECH committee, and today we have achieved a good result. We need ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Peter van DALEN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - We have a number of spearheads in Parliament. I am thinking of the environment, innovation and European cooperation. But it is possible that tomorrow's vote on Mr Mato's report will completely undermine these three spearheads. What do I mean? A very innovative and environmentally friendly fishing method has been developed in Europe over the past ten years: pulse trawling. Proven advantages of this method: considerably less fuel consumption, considerably less CO2 emissions, considerably less bycatch that is not wanted and considerably less disturbance of the North Sea bed. It is therefore logical that the European Commission now wants to allow this method. But what do we see? Deceived by the Parisian organization Loom, several delegates want to block this success story tomorrow. Bye bye innovation, environment and European cooperation. I would like to thank my colleague Mato for the great cooperation. Colleague Mato has shown to be a reliable European, for the environment and for innovation. His report deserves support! (The speaker addressed a "blue card" question under Rule 162 (8).)

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: blue-card question. – I’d like to ask Mr van Dalen about the 5% figure quoted by the Commission. I understand that the Dutch fishing vessels have now got this up to 28%. Do you think this is playing cricket or do you think this is playing by EU rules?

name: Peter van DALEN
text: "blue card" answer.- Well, this method fully complies with the European rules of the game.So it is not a game, and certainly not cricket!And we see that the European Commission is now saying: let's allow this method.It has been researched enough, it has proven benefits.So you are actually very weird when you block this beautiful innovative method.Hence the heartfelt support for what the Commission is now advocating and for the release of this method, within the existing quota we have, of course.That remains the framework within which we operate.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Ms Briano, I felt in your non-verbal communication that you were disappointed with me for cutting your time. But I do apologise, you had one minute and I am afraid we are well behind schedule. We need to be fair to those colleagues who come after us, so my apologies once again.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, I want to thank Mr Mato, for his work, and Nils Torvalds, who cannot be here. I want to say, regarding this report, that the scientific evidence intelligently combined with the pragmatism that the industry needs should lead this necessary revision of the technical measures for the protection of fishing ecosystems. Achieving the maximum sustainable yield of the activity requires both moving away from utopia and recognizing that fishing activity, including its professionals, must also be seen as part of the system to be protected. The complexity, dispersion and contradictions of the norms that we are reviewing have their origin precisely in a partial vision based on one or another sensibility. Scientists support the establishment of a percentage of juvenile catches and a deadline to achieve it, nuanced with the possibilities of regional adjustments if justified by data, as proposed by my group's amendment. By innovating it is possible to increase selectivity. There is no better stimulus to advance the creation of new fishing gear and techniques than by setting prudent targets. Along these lines, and for the same reasons, I am inclined to maintain the current status quo of electric fishing, that is, a four-year trial period for up to 5% of the fleet, but including the North Sea and guaranteeing the scientific access to vessels, prohibiting the use of complementary accessories such as ticklers and verifying that discards are reduced, reporting areas, captures and voltages. I also support that the measures reflect the diversity of fisheries, but always under a common scheme, that of the objectivity of technical studies and under the supervision of the Commission.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - (NL) Mr President, once again in Europe there is a race to the bottom. A race to the seabed that is. Who manages to empty the seas as quickly and efficiently as possible? Beam trawlers or pulse trawlers? We know that beam trawls have a devastating effect on the seabed and cause a lot of bycatch. We know that the electric pulse trawl is deadly effective for catching tongue and in cod it causes broken vertebrae and bleeding. But we don't know anything about the consequences of pulse trawl for the ecosystem. And we don't know anything about the consequences for sharks and rays, which are very sensitive to electricity. Replacing one devastating fishing method with another is not the solution. Let's put the emotions aside and wait for the scientific results before we lift the pulse trawl ban. In addition, we need to get rid of fishing gear that causes bycatch of seabirds, dolphins and seals. A ban on standing rigging and drift nets is therefore necessary. I also believe that European agriculture and fisheries subsidies should be abolished.

name: Marco AFFRONTE
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the criticalities of this dossier can be understood from the number of amendments (really many) that have been tabled here in plenary. We hope that they will help us, that we need them to improve this file. We also understood this from the speech by Commissioner Vella, who made a specific, numerical list of the amendments that weaken this proposal and make it something ineffective, something that does not allow us to fully apply the common fisheries policy. Regionalization was the time when we had to apply true regionalization, but telling us what regionalization is. Regionalization is leaving the possibility to individual States and individual regions to choose a path, a path for applying technical measures but aiming at common, precise, clear and numerical objectives that are established for the whole Union. They must be numerical because over time we need to monitor whether we are approaching those goals or not. This regionalization, as it is in the file now, is anarchy and not regionalization.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, if the stated aims of the common fisheries policy are to ensure that fishing and aquaculture activities are environmentally and economically sustainable, then why are we proposing to relax the rules on electro-pulse fishing? Electro-pulse is a technique that is blamed for breaking the backs of cod, eradicating molluscs and gastropods, causing internal bleeding and leaving the marine environment a dessert. Already banned in China and other parts of the world for being too damaging to the ecology, electro-pulse fishing must now also be outlawed, as per the 1990 EU ban on fishing with electricity, explosives and poisons. In recent weeks we’ve seen a lot of propaganda outlining the supposed environmental credentials of electro-pulse fishing, but the fact is that little independent non-partisan science has been completed. In the 13 studies conducted since electro-pulse was allowed, only three have looked at the effects on the marine environment. These three studies showed that 50% to 70% of the large cod caught with electricity had their spine broken and internal haemorrhages, that the survival rate of undersize discarded fish is very small, and that electrical currents may result in a weakened immune system for invertebrates. As for the claim that electro-pulse fishing is better for the sea bed, this is also a fallacy. Rather than gliding about the sea bed, pulse trawls are heavy rigs that penetrate the sediment by 6 cm with electrodes blasting 50 volts of electricity of an intensity of 60 amps killing everything in their path. The fact is, other than a small reduction in overall fuel usage there is no environmental benefit. Yet there is growing empirical and anecdotal evidence that electro-pulse fishing is doing catastrophic damage to Europe’s marine environment, fishes and fishing communities. So I urge you, if you put the marine environment above profit and care about the economic and social benefit of … (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, the maintenance of the exemption granted to electrofishing in this regulation is the subject of a great debate, and with good reason. How can this fishery be considered an ecologically viable fishery by the European Union, when it is banned in a large number of countries including China, the United States or Brazil, which often have regulations and less stringent standards than ours? Today, there is no evidence for the sustainability of electric fishing. Authorized by exemption for ten years, it has never been the subject of impact studies.
