Nothing has been done to determine the impact of electric shocks on juveniles, on fertility and on invasive species. The result of this neglect is that sole and plaice are disappearing from the areas where this fishery is practiced. The social impact is significant: many artisanal fishermen have gone out of business, or will do so if this fishery is not prohibited. A few days ago, we learned that the European Commission had used a report from its scientific, technical and economic committee, claiming that it was in favor of this fishery. In fact, this report asserted the opposite. This is the reason why Mr Mato's report should have been referred to the Committee on Fisheries so that the European Commission can explain itself to MEPs.

name: Werner KUHN
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! We see that in Parliament there are very different opinions, especially on the new fishing methods and the associated fishing gear. This also includes pulse fishing. Mr Mato and his shadow rapporteurs have found a very good compromise on the technical measures. The colleague mentioned this to us earlier. It is necessary that new fishing methods and gear are scientifically tested, over a period of four years and with appropriate scientific guidance - we have enough institutes in the European Union that can do this - and that no more than 5% of them the fleet in question. That is an important point so that we can settle the dispute between the Dutch beam trawlers and the French and the German and maybe also the British - I do not know how long they will be around. That is why I think this compromise is so incredibly good and I can only support that we agree to it and, so to speak, get many things back on track.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: - Mr President, first of all, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs on their difficult work and I recognize that there are, in fact, elements of great disruption. But let me be clear, Commissioner, my break point with the European Commission in the context of this dossier is based on Article 4. I support the compromise reached. In my view, a single solution for all European fisheries is neither technically nor politically reasonable. The possibility of a differentiated decision in dialogue with the regional councils is an important and sensible step, and peacefully pacifying, and it does not hurt the PCP, on the contrary. It can, in fact, create credibility for the PCP in relation to the bad side of urban myth and distrust of overly centralized decisions. Another aspect - the accidental capture of sensitive species - has to be reduced and it was with disgust that I saw my proposals for measures to reduce them being disapproved in committee. Therefore, I return to reinforce the protection of sensitive species such as marine mammals, including pinnipeds.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Mr President, the adoption of the Regulation on technical measures represents an important moment in the development of fisheries policies. After many years of misguided approach, the new Common Fisheries Policy and the alignment of legislation with its objectives have created an opportunity for sustainable fishing that respects regional specificities. In this regard, I must congratulate Rapporteur Mother and all fellow shadow rapporteurs on this great Report. This is the first step that will undoubtedly lead us to change the Mediterranean Regulation, which I proposed with my amendment, which was adopted. According to the current regulations, fishing with swimming nets in the Adriatic is not possible due to its specifics, which the regulations do not take into account. Such a situation is discriminatory towards Croatian fishermen who have been facing this problem since the day of Croatia's accession to the European Union. I am satisfied because by adopting this Decree, we are one step closer to a solution that means the survival of Croatian fisheries.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: - Mr President, we have a responsibility to speak for and in place of the speechless fish. The fish, who ask us if we are not ashamed of our barbaric fishing methods. Of this electric fishing which breaks their spine and electrifies the seabed. In fact, a real weapon of mass destruction. The artisanal fishermen ask us how far the predation of industrial fleets will go, which, out of greed, turn the oceans into veritable cemeteries. Artisanal fishermen, who are today threatened in their very existence, because "more fish, more fishermen"; It's as simple as that. This is why we must say no, three times no, to electrofishing which is a disgrace for Europe and for our humanity; that is why we must vote for the amendment that my colleagues and I have tabled, to ban this practice once and for all in Europe, a practice which is already banned worldwide.

name: Yannick JADOT
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, we have a major choice to make on electric fishing. Either we continue and we generalize the electrocution of the seabed which decimates the fish, sacrifices the fishermen, desertifies our coastal territories, or we prohibit electric fishing, this weapon of mass predation, we protect resources, we save artisanal fishing and we have beautiful and good fish on our plates. So yes, we have to vote for the ban and we have to do it despite the European Commission because, Commissioner, like the rest of the Commission, you continue to lie about electric fishing, you lie on the scientific basis of your decisions , you have failed on the derogations - there is no scientific protocol on your derogations - you have failed on the expansion of the derogations which today make it a massive fishery. So for artisanal fishing, for the oceans, for the chefs who support us, for the NGOs who support us, let's ban this fishing. Commissioner, you will be accountable to this assembly.

name: Annie SCHREIJER-PIERIK
text: - (NL) Mr President, pulse fishing is a sustainable, selective fishing technique. An innovation that spares the seabed, the climate and the environment. This is evident from all preliminary research results from Wageningen University and Wageningen Marine Research. And the Commission relied on that. In recent years, Dutch fishing families have invested heavily in this fishing gear with European support and commitments in order to comply with the landing obligation. Unfortunately, on the basis of fake news, a monstrous alliance and front of protectionism, the far right and the far left in this Parliament has been formed to kill this innovation. If their amendments go through, it will mean the deathblow for many Dutch fishing towns such as Urk, Den Helder, Scheveningen, Stellendam and many more, and the deathblow for the Dutch cutter fleet. And above all - and do not forget - the death knell for confidence in scientifically founded and sound European legislation in this Parliament. I call on you all to support Mato. Because it has just been said: some countries are leaving Europe. And the Netherlands, if we continue like this, too!

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, I would like to salute the rapporteur, Mr Mato, and the shadow rapporteurs for the work done on this complex and dense dossier and for having succeeded, above all, in finding for the most part useful compromises to move forward. Of course, there is this question of electrofishing. In 2007, the Commission authorized, by way of derogation, on a segment of 5% of the fleet in the North Sea, this electric fishing. She asked us, today, to generalize it. So, yes Mr van Dalen, we are all in favor of innovation, but it still needs to be verified, scientifically verified that the objective of sustainable management of the resource is being met. However, this sustainable management must be based on the best scientific advice, something the Commission ignored in 2007 - and it was not Mr Vella who was its commissioner - by not respecting the scientific opinion of 2006, which recommended not to grant any exemption. There is no scientific protocol on juveniles and marine ecosystems and scientists persist in alerting us to damage to cod or whiting ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: – Mr President, technical measures are broad sets of rules which govern how, where and when fishermen may fish. They are established for all European sea basins, but obviously they differ considerably from one basin to another, in accordance with their original conditions. It is a highly technical issue, but it is also highly political because, after all, we are trying to combine different interests from different Member States and different stakeholders. The rapporteur is doing a very good job. Mr Mato, you have my full support because of the tailor-made measures adopted for the specificities of each fishery and each sea basin, the reduction of micromanagement and rigid technical rules – adopting a more flexible and result-based management – and, finally, the greater involvement of sector in decisions of the common fisheries policy. This is the way to go and I congratulate you on the very hard work you have done.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: - Mr President, I would like first of all to congratulate the rapporteur for the efforts made to seek compromises and for his attitude of permanent dialogue with the sector. As a Galician I am very grateful to him for this closeness and willingness to dialogue. After several failed attempts in recent years to simplify the more than 30 legislative texts that exist, it is now necessary for the European institutions to review and consolidate this regulation in this term. Fishermen have to know what to expect in this very important dossier and I believe that regionalization, for example, of decisions on the size of the nets and on the establishment of targets to reduce catches of species below the minimum sizes it is the right way. In this way, decisions can be adjusted to the reality of the different fisheries since, in my opinion, the initial proposals of the Commission in these two batteries did not sufficiently take into account the real situation of these fisheries and did not have the necessary scientific support. . The regionalization solution - I repeat - seems to me the right one. It is halfway between the existing disparate positions.

name: Jérôme LAVRILLEUX
text: - Mr President, on the one hand, I hear that there is an absolute need to preserve the resource and, in particular, the juveniles, and, on the other hand, we are preparing to perpetuate or extend the electric fishing, which is not discriminatory, since even the smallest fish in the area concerned, everything will be eradicated. There is an inconsistency here that I cannot explain to myself. This would be equivalent, for other activities such as hunting, to authorizing hunting with a helicopter equipped with several machine guns on the pretext that the game would be injured less. It would be an absolute scandal! Allowing electrofishing is no more and no less than that. We must have a fishery that is discriminatory, which preserves the resource and which allows our fishermen - in particular the artisanal fishermen in my riding, who will be the first affected - to continue to sustain their activity for the good of the development of the local economic fabric and for the future of the generations who want to continue to eat fish one day.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: - Mr. President, I congratulate my colleague Mati on the report and express my satisfaction that the Committee on Fisheries has accepted my amendments for the introduction of flexibility due to the specific conditions of fishing in the Adriatic. After conducting an extensive international study on the technology of fishing with swim nets, the technical characteristics of these nets and their impact on the seabed, it has been proven that when fishing in the Adriatic, the net does not sink to the bottom regardless of depth. Namely, the current provisions of European legislation by restricting the use of surrounding nets at depths less than 70% of the height of the net, and due to the influence of sea currents, but also the changing configuration of the seabed, fishing with these nets would be almost suspended. This would irreversibly endanger 2,000 people working on ships and 15,000 people working in processing and all other ancillary activities, which is not negligible because these are permanent jobs 12 months a year on the Croatian islands and coast. Therefore, the adoption of the Adriatic exemption is particularly important and I thank you for your support.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, is there any area that is more controversial and more difficult to get consensus on than the fishing area? I see that in my own country. I see it here. I see Mr Mato, who is an excellent politician and chairman, coming forward with his speech. Then Commissioner Vella, who is equally sincere, takes issue with some of the points made and I say to myself, when are we going to get all this together? How are we going to convince enough people that we can have a good majority going in the one direction? It seems to me to be very difficult.  One thing that is absolutely necessary is independent, empirical scientific evidence before we do anything, and that doesn’t seem to be available. We get different groups coming forward with different proposals – electro-pulse fishing is an example – to me it seems to go against the grain and against the natural order. Do the fish have any chance if you are going to extend it? Why have it as an experiment if you do not intend to extend it further, and perhaps even eliminate the whole lot of them? So I think that there is a huge job of work to be done by the Commission in relation to PR in all of this.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, the protection of marine ecosystems is essential for the consolidation of sustainable fisheries. The audits of international organizations such as ICCAT, that is, the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas, play an important role. In the Aegean, Turkish fishing vessels, accompanied by vessels of the Turkish Coast Guard, are fishing illegally in Greek territorial waters, committing piracy. In addition, the Turkish Coast Guard, claiming to be acting on behalf of ICCAT, attempted to seize Greek fishing vessels in international waters near Kastelorizo, without, of course, the Turks complying with the specifications, ie having hoisted an ICCAT flag, and without be in the presence of an ICCAT inspector. I ask you, Mr Vella, to look into this complaint. I will send you all the information I have at my disposal. Also, it is not possible to illegally allow the Turks to spawn Greek fishing vessels in international waters, claiming that they are acting on behalf of ICCAT.

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: - I welcome the proposal from the European Commission, which makes it possible to try out new fishing techniques in practice.After a trial period and sufficient scientific research, it is determined whether the new fishing technique may be used by our European fishermen: an admission procedure that is logical and that everyone can agree with.I am therefore stunned that some of my colleagues want to stipulate in advance in law that the pulse short technique may not be used by fishermen.The admission of the pulse trawl is thus made political, instead of independent experts deciding on it.What got into them?Is it an association they make with electric fishing?Do gut feelings play a role or is it purely to do with political-economic reasons and are the forerunners consciously held back?In any case, I think it's a shame that pulse trawling doesn't get the same opportunities as all other new fishing techniques.

name: João FERREIRA
text: - Mr President, despite the promises made during the last reform of the common fisheries policy, this remains a highly centralized policy, which ignores the diversity that characterizes the sector in terms of resource fleets and fisheries. The wonderful regionalization has resulted in a handful of nothing. We continue to have a policy that is out of step with reality, which has created difficulties especially in the small-scale, coastal and artisanal fishing segment. This proposed regulation confirms it once again. It is symptomatic that the greater permissiveness we see emerging from this proposed regulation will fundamentally benefit certain segments of industrial fishing in northern European countries. As for small-scale fishing, with a strong prevalence in countries like Portugal, there are measures that do nothing more than aggravate a very serious income problem whose causes, consequences and the necessary overcoming the European Union seems to despise.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank all of you for your interventions and your valuable views. I have taken due note of this very interesting debate. On a positive note, we all agree on the need to have this review of the technical measures, which is a very good start. Let me now turn to some of the specific points raised by Member States. The first point that I would like to make is that Parliament has focused on electro-pulse fishing, and this is also a good discussion. However, we should not lose sight of the other important elements contained in the proposal, as well as other problematic amendments. Whilst the Commission is aware of the concerns being expressed regarding pulse fishing, it is important that we all recall and keep an eye on the broader perspective as well. Mr Affronte and Ms Briano spoke on the issue of regionalisation, and obviously we are all in favour of regionalisation, but in this specific case an amendment introduces the possibility of regionalising the specific rules governing the use of different mesh sizes, for example. In practice, there would no longer be a common objective across Union waters. One comment with regards to Croatia, which wants to have a special derogation for purse seine nets. This goes against a well-established rule from the 2006 Mediterranean Regulation, and allowing for a derogation would undermine conservation standards in the Adriatic. With regards to the Turkish coastguard issue that to Mr Marias mentioned, I will look into this and come back to him as well. A number of you, and Mr Ricardo in particular, have mentioned the issue of targets and quantitative targets. What I have to say is that the concept of quantitative targets introduced in the Commission proposal is a new approach and is intended to allow for the concept of results-based management and accountability by the operators. This was proposed to deliver simplification and flexibility to amend technical regulations at a regional level while retaining oversight through the setting of quantitative of objectives. This would avoid the need to prescribe and micro-manage the specific details of how, where and when a fisherman operates by focusing on the outcome. The alternative proposed by the Committee on Fisheries (PECH) would mean that quantitative reductions are set by different regional groups, and this could lead to a differentiated approach and divergent standards across sea basins. As I said, most of the speakers spoke about pulse fishing, and we note the concerns raised by a number of MEPs, as well as NGOs outside this House, regarding the use of pulse fishing. Our proposal lifts the current capacity limits on the number of vessels that can use the technique, but we have proposed to limit its use to the southern North Sea, in line with existing provisions. Contrary to what MEP Hookem said, we do have independent scientific assessments, and according to our independent scientific assessments, the conventional way of fishing by beam trawling has proven to have a negative impact on the ecosystem. Thus, it is important to remember what pulse fishing would be replacing, and that is traditional beam trawling. If properly controlled and applied, I underline these words, electric pulse simulation may offer a more ecologically benign alternative way of fishing by reducing unwanted by-catch, reducing seabed damage and lowering CO2 emissions. Following independent scientific advice, the Commission has retained the geographical limitations... (Mr Jadot interrupted and President intervened) So that this fishing technique can only be used in the southern North Sea. I could not accept the comment by Mr Jadot, where he said that I was lying. I can assure you that lying is not in my nature and that I have no interest whatsoever in doing so. If I am lying, that means that our scientific advice is lying as well. In its advice of 2012, the Scientific, Technical and Economic Committee for Fisheries (STECF) concluded that most ecological concerns raised by the International Council for the Exploration of the Sea (ICES) have been adequately addressed. Subsequently, advice from ICES in 2016 concluded that – and I will quote – conventional beam trawling has significant and well demonstrated negative economic ecosystem impacts. If properly understood and adequately controlled, electric power stimulation may offer a more ecologically benign alternative and could reduce fishing mortality on more targets species. This is not what I am saying, that is what our independent scientific advice is saying. Let me reiterate, it is of the utmost importance that in order to move away from the current complexities of technical rules in return for a less prescriptive and results-oriented approach, it is important and it is essential that we retain common measures and objectives. Secondly, it is essential that we do not go back on our commitments under the Common Fisheries Policy to reduce unwanted catches and prohibit discards, as this was a central element of the Common Fisheries Policy that we all signed up for. In the spirit that Mr Kelly mentioned, I look forward to further working with the Parliament in a good spirit of cooperation, and hopefully we can take this file forward.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: speaker. - Mr. president; Thank you very much to everyone, to those who have supported and to those who not so much. In any case, it is very difficult to answer them all in two minutes, but I would like to say that there is something that I share with the commissioner. Dear Commissioner, unfortunately electric fishing has completely distorted this debate. There are very important things in this dossier, even more important or let's say the same. But, of course, I sincerely believe that it has been distorted, and I am deeply sorry. Simply saying without passion that the proposal we have made I think is balanced, that it is not an arbitrary decision, but that it will be based on scientific studies in any case. And, dear Commissioner, as many times as I say that we are going to eliminate the targets, it is not true. Targets are not going to be removed. We eliminate the quantified objectives in advance, subjectively and without a criterion. And we do eliminate those, because, even though you say that good management will be called into question, I believe in good management that comes from regionalization. name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the report by Linnéa Engström, on behalf of the Committee on Fisheries, on the Proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down management, conservation and control measures applicable in the Convention Area of the South Pacific Regional Fisheries Management Organisation (SPRFMO) (COM(2017)0128 – C8—0121/2017 – 2017/0056(COD)) (A8—0377/2017).

name: Linnéa ENGSTRÖM
text: rapporteur. - Mr President! The EU is a contracting party to the Pacific Regional Fisheries Management Organization, SPRFMO, and therefore the binding management and conservation measures adopted by that organization must be incorporated into EU law. I would like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs for their good cooperation. The South Pacific Regional Fisheries Management Organization covers a quarter of the earth's international waters. It does not manage the tuna area. These species are instead covered by other international conventions. The most important species covered are horse mackerel and squid. The organization entered into force on 24 August 2012 and is one of the newest regional fisheries organizations in the world. There are currently 15 Contracting Parties and two cooperating non-Contracting Parties to the Organization: Liberia and Panama. Belize was a contracting party for a few years but withdrew in May 2016. This is the first time that the EU will transpose these rules into EU law. The Commission's proposal aims to incorporate the various conservation and management measures adopted so far, closer to 15. It covers a wide range of issues, from IUU fishing to measures to reduce mortality among seabirds and exploratory fishing. The EU's main activity is regional pelagic trawling for horse mackerel, which has been caught since 1979. After a period without fishing activities, it resumed in 2005 with small catches of less than 10% of the total stock. Vessels from four Member States participate in this fishery, even though they are all linked to a single company. This bill does not specify how much you can fish, but it may be of interest that the fishing catch follows the scientific advice. The Scientific Committee for, among other things, the fishing mortality for horse mackerel was below the FMSY level, while the biomass was below the level that can give MSY, BMSY. The Scientific Committee therefore recommended that the catches be kept for 2017 and 2018 below 493,000 tonnes, where the EU's share amounts to 30,115 tonnes. Overall, the Commission's proposal aims at the full transposition of the conservation and management measures adopted by SPRFMO. Some of these provisions are already included in the Common Fisheries Policy, including the vessel monitoring mechanism, DMS, and certain control provisions. There is therefore no reason to repeat them in the proposal. One important thing is missing in the Commission's proposal of the measures adopted by SPRFMO: CMM 08-2013 introduces a total ban on the use of both large pelagic driftnets and all deep-sea nets or so-called deep-sea nets. The Commission has probably not transposed this measure because there are currently no Union vessels using this type of fishing gear. The ban on deep-sea nets or deep-sea nets is not reflected in other parts of the common fisheries policy. It is an international obligation and therefore the prohibition should be included in this Regulation together with associated definitions of gear. Finally, SPRFMO has adopted many necessary fishing restrictions for both trawls and longlines to prevent the capture of seabirds. This is commendable because the EU action plan for seabirds wants to draw attention to the high mortality among seabirds in connection with fishing around the world. The Commission for the Conservation of Antarctic Marine Living Resources is said to have reduced longline reef-related seabird mortality by more than 90% through relatively simple and efficient technical adaptations of gear and fishing methods. Equally effective measures to prevent seabird deaths must be taken within SPRFMO's Commission area, as well as in other sea areas. The EU, which works according to best practice, must, of course, make the same demands in this regulation. I thank you for your time and look forward to any comments on this regulation.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, again I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Linnéa Engström, and her team for the excellent work, and I would like also to thank the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety and its rapporteur, Ms Vălean, for its opinion. The Commission proposal transposes into EU law the conservation control and enforcement measures adopted by the South Pacific Regional Fisheries Management Organisation, to which the European Union is a contracting party. This is a challenging file because of the high number of conservation measures adopted under the SPRFMO since 2012. The Commission welcomes most amendments proposed by the European Parliament’s Committee on Fisheries (PECH), as they clarify some of the obligations in its initial proposal. However, the Commission is not in a position to support the amendments relating to (a) the provisions to promote artisanal small-scale fisheries, and (b) the definition of ‘fishing vessel’ and ‘IUU fishing’, for the following reasons. Firstly, the provisions on artisanal and small-scale fisheries (I’m referring to Amendments 1 and 12) are inspired by the recent transposition of the International Commission for the Conservation of Atlantic Tunas (ICCAT) recommendations. However, the fisheries’ characteristics and geographical context is not the same in the SPRFMO, where the EU fleet fishing is composed of industrial long-distance factory vessels, including some of the most modern and largest fishing ships in the world. In addition to that, the SPRFMO convention area does not include the EEZs, which are the areas where traditional and artisanal fisheries operate. The European Union fleet fishes solely in the high seas and does not have access to the adjacent EEZs and even less to the territorial waters. Therefore the EU fleet fishing in SPRFMO is unable to promote coastal fishing activities and techniques. Secondly, the PECH Committee proposes, in its Amendment 5, the use of the definition of ‘fishing vessel’ from the SPRFMO. The Commission considers that we should avoid a multiplication of definitions of ‘fishing vessel’ used in different EU legal texts with already-existing definition in the Control Regulation and in the EU IUU Regulation. The preference should be then to keep the definition used under the European Union IUU Regulation, which is the one used in the Commission proposal. Thirdly, as far as the definition of ‘illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing’ is concerned (and I am referring to Amendment 10), the European Parliament proposes to refer only to point 1 of Article 2 of the IUU Regulation. However, it is better to refer to the entire IUU Regulation in order not to lose the individual definitions of ‘illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing’ foreseen in its Article 2. The SPRFMO transposition regulation will also allow a faster and more efficient implementation of future SPRFMO conservation measures, thanks to the derogation of certain well-framed powers to the Commission. I strongly support this practical approach as it will allow the Union to deliver on its international obligation towards the regional fisheries management organisations in a timely manner, providing certainty to Member States and a level playing field for operators. Let me assure you that the Commission will continue working together with the regional fisheries management organisations to ensure better ocean governance and more sustainable fishing. Thank you for your attention and for tabling this important regulation for debate, and I look forward to hearing your views.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, I want to thank Mrs Engström for her constructive attitude. We are facing the transposition of the fifteen measures adopted by the South Pacific Regional Organization for Fisheries Management since its creation in 2012. I have to say that I believe that the transpositions should be as faithful as possible. New elements should not be introduced that could put our fleet at a different level of demand, that is, with more restrictive rules of the game than those that apply to other fleets in the same area. It is necessary to guarantee equal treatment. Our fishermen do not want discrimination with respect to their competitors in the same fishing areas. They were not going to understand the reason for the change. This is the basic principle that has inspired my group in our action in the Committee on Fisheries on this dossier: to achieve - and I think we have generally achieved this - a faithful, clean transposition, that is, without new elements or adhesions. The environmental dimension is very important, but so is the economic and social dimension. The audiences of our standards are fishing professionals and they should be given standards that they can meet, but also standards that they can understand. And discrimination, a transposition that does not take into account this necessary equality, they were not going to understand.

name: Czesław HOC
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr Chairman! First of all, congratulations and thanks to the rapporteur, Engström. A very important and necessary document. It establishes the management, protection and control measures for the Convention Area in the South Pacific which are transposed into European Union law in line with the Union's international obligations. The convention area in the South Pacific Ocean is very important for the deep-sea fleet of Member States, including Poland or the Netherlands, Germany, Lithuania, engaged in fishing, especially Peruvian horse mackerel. The report defines and unifies the relevant issues based on the best available scientific information and the precautionary principle of resource management and the principle of protection of marine ecosystems. They concern, among others vulnerable marine ecosystems in demersal fisheries, sea bird by-catch reduction measures, unregulated fishing, horse mackerel management, exploratory fisheries, etc. We therefore support this report. In general, he is good.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Engström, for her work and her cooperation. The purpose of this report is to incorporate the international law adopted by the South Pacific Regional Fisheries Management Organization into the acquis communautaire. As usual, we have followed, to carry out this work, the principle of not adding specific measures for European vessels. In this way, the Community fleet will work under the same conditions as that from third countries in the same fishing scenarios. Likewise, I support and welcome the inclusion of two contributions in favor of sustainability. The first adds guarantees to comply with the total ban on the use of large-scale gillnets and pelagic drift nets. Although no European vessel uses these gears in the area under the control of this organization, I consider it very useful to oblige Member States to control their vessels when they pass through this area with this type of gear on board. The second encourages Member States to promote selective coastal fishing activities, including techniques used in traditional and artisanal fishing, to contribute to a decent standard of living for local coastal communities.

text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I would logically like to congratulate the rapporteur and shadow rapporteurs for this work and, having intervened in the previous debate, with healthy envy I say that this has been developed without major shocks and that there are no elements of controversy, of which I am glad. text: - Mr President, as has been said, the South Pacific Regional Fisheries Management Organization is a new organization, but it plays a very important role. name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would again like to thank the rapporteur for the general support for the proposal and for the amendments, which clarify and improve the original Commission proposal. In fact, only a few amendments were not acceptable from the Commission perspective. The SPRFMO transposition regulation will, as has already been said by most of the Members, allow a faster and more efficient implementation of new conservation measures in Union law, thanks to the delegation of certain well-framed powers to the Commission. This practical approach will allow the Union to deliver on its international obligations vis-à-vis RFMOs in a timely manner. There was one comment that I would like to comment on. Mr Mato mentioned the need to transpose in good time. However, we have to keep in mind that the SPRFMO is a very young RFMO, and its first annual meeting was held in 2013. After this meeting, the SPRFMO had envisaged a medium-term plan to adopt a comprehensive system of conservation and management measures by 2016. Therefore, it was decided to delay the transposition until the new measures were adopted in order to avoid having to repeat a lengthy and complex transposition exercise twice within a limited time.  The transposition is a complex and time-consuming process. It requires an article-by-article analysis of every SPRFMO conservation and management measure in order to incorporate it into EU law. In most cases, the original provision does not allow for a simple replication. That means we cannot simply copy and paste the text. It is therefore necessary to adapt the provisions to the EU language specificities and actors. My thanks again to the European Parliament for its opinion. We look forward to our discussions in the upcoming trilogues and to the quick adoption of this regulation.

name: Linnéa ENGSTRÖM
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President! I do not have much more to say. This is a fairly simple and straightforward transposition of EU law. I would like to thank everyone who has taken part in the debate and, of course, the shadow rapporteur, with whom we have had very good cooperation for this regulation. Even if it is not relevant at the moment, something that should apply is an international obligation, and should therefore be included in this regulation. name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Andrea Cozzolino, on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development, on the implementation of the Union's macro-regional strategies (2017/2040 (INI)) (A8-0389 /2017).

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: speaker. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, let me first of all thank the Commissioner who is present here to listen to us and to discuss with us and with all the colleagues who have contributed to this work and to produce a text which I believe represents an adequate starting point also for the European Commission itself. An implementation report such as the one we are discussing today is a tool at our disposal to make an analysis of where we have arrived and above all to understand all together what can be the best ways to grow and improve the tools that the Union makes available of its citizens. I believe that we have succeeded in this objective and that is why I ask the Commission and the Commissioner to continue working together, to give a positive follow-up to the work done so far. Coming to the report, we have had the opportunity to understand how, although relatively young, macro-regional strategies have become a consolidated tool and as such they must be treated, leaving the experimentation phase, using best practices to improve governance mechanisms and, above all, , to stabilize forms of financing aimed at strategies on both the European and national sides. This is why we ask for two fundamental things in the report. The first request is addressed to the Member States: we ask for specific commitments, especially in the early stages, at the very moment of the establishment of strategies in terms of financial and human resources. We also ask for the provision, also with the support of the Commission, of forms of incentives or facilitations for actions to implement the strategies. Secondly, we instead ask the Commission to use the forthcoming reforms of the financial framework and cohesion policy both to redefine and better calibrate the targets and objectives of the macro-regions, and to track within the future regulations, a new role, sectors of intervention, also in light of the new priorities that the Union is giving itself, and forms of implementation work, identify specific measures and projects to define certain sources of funding to achieve them. In general, it is necessary to progressively overcome the mechanism whereby the strategies must, from time to time, ask for funding from different programs, effectively reinforcing from the outset the direct link between the actions of the strategies themselves and the sources of EU funding. As for the "three no" rule (no to new structures, no to new rules and no to new funding), I believe the time has come to open a reflection, or to understand how and in what way, after ten years from the first strategies, it must be declined to continue to have a sense that we understand, and it does not become just a ballast. This is why we ask the Commission that in the next report it can also provide us with the analysis of the impact of the three no's on the implementation of strategies and on the realization of projects. Finally, governance, probably the most delicate point. We agree that the implementation of strategies can no longer be entrusted solely to national governments but must be shared and implemented with the consent and close cooperation of local, regional and above all civil society levels. In fact, too often - and I would like to conclude on this point - strategies sin by lack of ownership and suffer from this lack. The national level is too distant and probably too little attentive; for this reason it is essential to bring ownership of strategies closer to citizens, giving back to local autonomies and regions an active and decisive role in the planning and implementation phase. These seem to me to be the points on which we have reached a broad consensus in the report and I hope that the debate can confirm this.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: membre de la Commission. – Madame la Présidente, bonne année. Madam President, let me start by thanking Mr Cozzolino for his report. The Commission welcomes all the efforts to provide an analysis for all the EU macro—regional strategies – the Danube, the Baltic, the Alpine and the Adriatic—Ionian. I believe your work complements the report published by the Commission one year ago, and indeed we share the same belief that the success of all four macro—regional strategies requires continuous commitment and, of course, the active participation of all the relevant actors and administrations. I sometimes have the impression that the steering wheel is still in the hands of the Commission, but when it comes to implementation, you know very well that the ball should be in the court of the participating countries. It is a question of political ownership. This means pooling together, as we said, all efforts and resources, be they human, administrative or financial, to translate the commitment into delivery of concrete projects on the ground. It is therefore crucial that participating countries and regions take political ownership of their respective strategies. Having said that, I think we can all agree that over the last few years the four macro—regional strategies have started to instil a true culture of territorial cooperation. That is what I felt every time I was involved, because I participated in all the annual forums of the macro—regional strategies. Last November I was in Munich at the Annual Forum of the EU Strategy for the Alpine Region. I witnessed the willingness of all actors present to make a true difference through their cooperation. So it gave me hope that macro-regions can improve the implementation of European Union policies and territorial cohesion. This means that we need to make sure that the objectives of each macro—regional strategy are embedded into national priorities. For example, for the Alpine Region, 80 cohesion programmes cover the Alpine territory. These programmes can support the objectives of the Alpine strategy, but they are often implemented in isolation. So I call upon you, Honourable Members of the European Parliament, to pass on the message in your respective countries and constituencies that all programmes should go in the same direction. As rightly underlined by Mr Cozzolino in his report, macro—regional strategies can only thrive if they are rooted in a long-term process. Thank you for your attention. I am ready to respond to your comments and requests.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Thank you for the floor, thank you also to my colleague Cozzolin for his excellent cooperation in preparing the report. The four macro-regions, namely the Baltic, the Danube, the Alpine, the Adriatic-Ionian, are macro-regions comprising 18 Member States of the European Union and also 8 non-EU countries. It is important that such rich countries are united here, there are a number of such countries in the Alpine region, as well as those of the poorest regions in the Western Balkans. The Baltic is the longest-running strategy and we can learn from it that we need to continue and empower countries to be truly fully involved in the work of these macro-regions, together with the regions, municipalities, people, but also to focus on achieving the objectives and, on the other hand, to determine whether a new macro-region is still needed.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to thank our rapporteur Cozzolino first of all for his very precise report, very punctual and with interesting proposals. name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Club. - Madam President, this Report has shown how important macro-regional strategies are for the development of the European Union, but not only of the European Union but also of all countries in the neighborhood of EU Member States. What we need to pay special attention to and what is emphasized in this Report is that it is very important to plan a smart budget for the period after 2020, especially in the area of ​​cohesion policy. name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, almost 10 years after these macro-regional strategies were put into practice, there are still difficulties in implementation due to the different involvement of states, in terms of funding, resources and political support. name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank Mr Cozzolino for his work and dedication in this report and Commissioner Crețu for being with us tonight. This Union was built out of the ruins of Europe but was made possible with the strong will of each and every citizen of that continent. The time to pay back that honour and trust has come. name: Tonino PICULA
text: - Madam President, the Macro-Regions Project is largely complementary to the fundamental values ​​of the European Union, it represents a framework for cooperation between the countries of a region to solve problems that they cannot solve satisfactorily on their own. text: - Madam President!Ladies and gentlemen!Undoubtedly, macro-regional strategies have the potential to increase economic development as well as bring the citizens of the Member States closer together.Therefore, I am pleased with the results achieved by the four functioning strategies, especially with regard to issues related to environmental protection, energy, transport development and tourism.I believe that it is worth continuing to implement these strategies, while focusing on increasing their effectiveness.To achieve this, it is essential to define the long-term political perspective of the macroregions and the full involvement of both regional and local authorities as well as civil society and private actors.At the same time, regional strategies need to be able to adapt quickly and efficiently to emerging challenges, hence increasing their flexibility.
