text: - Ms. President!Macro-regional strategies have been set up with the important aim of tackling common problems affecting each macro-region through cross-border cooperation, thus accelerating territorial, economic and social cohesion, which is one of the EU's fundamental objectives.In particular, I would like to emphasize the importance of the Danube Strategy in the Central and Eastern European region, which also includes three countries from the Western Balkans that want to become members of the European Union.The Danube Strategy is an excellent opportunity for Serbia, Montenegro and Bosnia and Herzegovina, together with nine EU Member States, to participate in identifying regional problems and potentials and putting priorities into practice.That is why I support the maintenance and financing of macro-regional strategies after 2020, and at the same time I suggest that we make it possible to increase their effectiveness.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: - Mrs Crețu, a decade after the first macro-region, macro-region strategies are a long-term investment aimed at complementing countries' choices and maximizing cooperation. The idea is really promoted. Especially in areas with a history of tensions, such as the Balkans, which are not only made up of European Union Member States, it is also challenging because it leads to cross-sectoral and cross-sectoral cooperation. Tourism, transport, the environment, energy cooperation are areas in which we work in the Adriatic-Ionian macro-region, and the Commission has honored me by awarding me a pilot project to tackle energy poverty, for which I thank you very much. It is necessary, however, to give macro-regional strategies the framework for the next step. Given the lack of resources, it is necessary to lead macro-regions to develop projects in high value-added sectors by minimizing local competition.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, macro-regional strategies represent a major innovation in European cohesion policies, insofar as they provide a platform for wider inter-sectoral, regional and cross-border interaction between EU Member States and neighboring countries. However, the limits of this tool are evident from the experiences gained. Multi-level governance, with an appropriate role for the regions, must become a fundamental element of the macro-regional strategy. More effective forms of collaboration, both vertical and horizontal, must be put in place between the various public and private actors, universities and NGOs, between the international organizations operating in this field and the various policies at the European Union, national level, regional and local. I would like to point out once again, however, that the Mediterranean still lacks a macro-regional strategy despite representing a single cultural and environmental basin. It is only a question of political will if the Commission has so far not been able to offer an action plan to address the common challenges of the Mediterranean, but it is an issue that needs to be remedied.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, macro-regions are a new form of multi-level governance. The regions participate, the municipalities, the private sector, the civil society participate. They must, of course, operate in a transparent manner, make use of resources and have effective funding mechanisms. The macro-region of the Adriatic and the Ionian is very important, it concerns 70 million inhabitants and 7 states. It should be noted, however, Mrs Crețu, that Albania, which participates in the macro-region, must finally respect the rights of the Greek national minority in the Northern Epirus. Because there is a violation of the rights of this minority, at the same time churches are being demolished, Greek properties are being demolished and I do not think that a process of the Adriatic-Ionian macro-region can proceed with this behavior on the part of the Albanian authorities, on the part of Mr. Rama and his company.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: - Madam President, with regard to the Cozzolino report, what Mrs Crețu told us on behalf of the Commission serves a message of strengthening macro-regional strategies beyond 2020. What is needed now is for us all to become more effective, to move from declarations to In practice, everyone can and must do more, both the Commission and Parliament, implementing effective monitoring, but also the regions and the Member States and the private sector. Because there can be great benefits to the environment and energy and transport and tourism from the synergy of the Member States' regions. In particular, the Adriatic-Ionian Strategic Partnership serves another great goal: the enlargement of the European Union to the Western Balkans, which is good for both the European Union and the Western Balkans, and for peace in the region.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, our assessment of regional strategies is positive. They provide a platform for better regional and cross-border interaction between EU Member States and neighboring countries to promote cooperation and improve the integration of different political partners. There are enormous challenges at stake, I am thinking for example of the Adriatic-Ionian macro-regional strategy, and I wish for greater attention to be paid to biodiversity protection, climate change mitigation, waste treatment and integrated coastal zone management. In this regard, I agree with paragraph 30, where the use of green public procurement is encouraged to stimulate eco-innovation, the bioeconomy, the use of secondary raw materials and therefore the circular economy, so as to achieve high levels of health protection. and the environment and create close links between producers and consumers. On the other hand, however, we must oppose the European Commission's condescending policy towards gas multinationals, which are devastating marine and coastal ecosystems, favoring the affairs of corrupt lobbies and dictatorial countries, as in the case of TAP.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: - Madam President, in conditions when we have clearly defined sources of funding, we see in practice that there are problems in implementation, say in cohesion policy, in implementation we often face a lack of administrative capacity, unresolved property relations, issues of public procurement and allthe rest.In macro-regional strategies, in addition to all this, we also have multilevel governance, meaning not only at local and national level, but also among different Member States, and with complex governance we have problems with undefined sources of funding.If we really want macro-regional strategies to be implemented and for projects to really see the light of day, then at the level of the European Union, we must provide funding in the European budget using both transnational programs and cohesion policy and thus help countries.

name: John HOWARTH
text: – Madam President, the stated aim of the macro-regional strategy is to provide a platform for transnational cooperation between Member States, as well as with third countries. The North Sea and the North Atlantic area has not needed a macro-regional strategy, because it has had a thing called the European Union. Regrettably, that is likely to change. Despite the United Kingdom’s intended departure, issues will remain: environmental, transport, Ireland, and – as we saw in the debate earlier this evening – issues related to marine communities. A regional forum of some description, such as a macro-regional strategy, would be particularly helpful in ensuring that the United Kingdom doesn’t disengage and the problems don’t get worse.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Madam President, I also agree with my predecessors that these development strategies are indeed a platform for transnational cooperation. It is important to look for synergies, it is important to cooperate, coordinate your activities. However, I am also in favor of what the rapporteur said in his report and in his speech that he has doubts about the quality of implementation. It is necessary to demand the strengthening of personnel and administrative capacities as well as the strengthened role of local and regional authorities in the implementation of these macro-regional strategies. This was also emphasized by my colleague Breso. I think that macro-regional strategies should not further weaken cohesion policy, they should complement it well. Then I also support them in this sense. Should there be fragmentation or duplication, I don't think it deserves this support. I agree with Commissioner Creţu that these macro-regional strategies will flourish if they are part of a long-term process.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, I thank the rapporteur, our colleague, who summarized the four strategies very well. Thank you for being here tonight and not only because you are here, but also because you have understood extremely well what regional development means and because you support the strategies, obviously. Macro-regional strategies are useful tools for development, but also for making the benefits of European cooperation visible to citizens. The rapporteur has shown very well what has been achieved through these strategies. I would like to dwell on the Strategy for the Danube Region, where the rapporteur makes concrete proposals, which I also support - the reopening of a strategy center for the Danube Region, which could contribute to a better implementation of the strategy. Sure, I could say that I agree with the three, but I would be happy to have a macro strategy for the Black Sea region, as we have for the Baltic Sea and the Adriatic Sea. In any case, I hope to continue after 2020, not to confuse. Macroregional development strategies help cohesion.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: –Madam President, macro-regional strategy is probably one of the most effective policy tools the Commission and EU have to maximise the effect of their policies. I would like to see a greater emphasis on clean transport, clean energy, the fight against climate change and concrete actions on the circular economy. A good example of this scale of projects is the Tallinn tunnel, in the Baltic region, that will link Finland to the rest of Europe via railway. That’s why I hope that the funding could be geared more on these kind of macro-regional efforts and joint projects in the future.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, thank you for your interventions and your comments. We are all going in the same direction, and we are all willing to show our commitment to strengthening these macro-regional strategies and their roles and capacities. The next multiannual financial framework will be submitted by the Commission in May and will provide us with a window of opportunity to introduce macro-regional strategies in the EU policy landscape. Macro-regional strategies are, as we said here, without any doubt one of the flagships of territorial cooperation. As you said, it is one of the most tangible expressions of the EU added value. Many of you, including Mr Picula, Ms Bresso, Mr Bogovič and Mr Jakovčić, underlined the political importance of these macro-regional strategies. This is the only framework that we have now in European policies to put EU Member States and non-member states on an equal footing with equal rights, sharing experiences and best practices. It is very important for the hopes for enlargement and for the hopes of those countries. But as Mr Cozzolino underlined in his report, as well as during this discussion, macro-regional strategies provide the relevant framework for improving the results of EU policies and first and foremost, as you said, of cohesion policy. Now more than ever, we need to show that we can establish concrete cooperation to help us to be stronger in addressing the serious challenges that we are all facing. The Commission will consider very carefully its proposal on how to guarantee better coherence between the macro-regional objectives and those that will be supported through our programmes. We are ready to seek better links with cohesion policy, and we are aiming for the coherence of the whole policy framework.  I would like to conclude by assuring you once again that we will remain a fervent supporter of macro-regional strategies. I admit that we have not been successful at all times, and we have to call upon the Member States to do their part. The European Commission is a facilitator, but when it comes to selecting a project, the only strategy that has introduced this transnational cooperation concept is the Baltic one, and it is an example for other macro-regional strategies. To be honest, as I said I am a great supporter of this. Sometimes I don’t understand why for so many years the Minister of Foreign Affairs fought for these macro-regional strategies, and then when they are adopted and in place, there are no projects. They don’t come up with common projects. It is therefore really important to bring together the Ministry of Finance, the Ministry of European Funds and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in the same countries and have this cross-border cooperation project. Nonetheless, we continue to encourage all the stakeholders to participate. We will continue to disseminate good practices so that each of the four macro-regional strategies learns from the three others. We will also continue to communicate on the benefits of these strategies in order to raise citizens’ awareness. You raised this Mediterranean and Black Sea issue. As I said, these macro-regional strategies are voted on by the Council at the request of the Member States. If they are adopted by the Council, the Commission would be ready to be a facilitator.  I would like once again to express my gratitude to you, to the European Parliament and, in particular, to Mr Cozzolino and all the people who worked on this very important document, to the REGI Committee in particular for your support of the macro-regional concept as a valuable tool to improve our collective action. I am also very glad – I see that Mr Novakov is no longer here – that the Bulgarian Presidency has designated cohesion policy a priority for the next six months. I therefore rely on you to fight together to preserve this policy, which the most tangible policy that improves the lives of citizens and has visible results in our European Union to fulfil the discrepancies and gaps that we still have. Thank you once again. I wish you good luck, and it will be a pleasure for me to come to the Committee on Regional Development and maybe to talk about each strategy individually.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: speaker.- Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a broad consensus and a truly positive comparison are confirmed.Now the intervention of the Commissioner confirms the positivity of our comparison.I believe we can say that the strategic strengthening of tools and governance is the first major goal that we set ourselves.Bringing macro-regions to be more and more protagonists of the new challenges that Europe faces: immigration, climate change, transport and sustainable mobility, great confrontation between cities, states and regions on a civil and cultural level.Finally, it is important to strengthen the existing one, these ten years, and not to exclude the need to identify new macro-regions and new tools that will allow us to better face the challenges that Europe has before it.I believe that the work we have done, the debate, is very auspicious, and I hope that tomorrow there will be a broad consensus on the report.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place on Tuesday 16 January 2018. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing.- Macro-regional strategies are of vital importance for the development of the territory, as evidenced by the fact that for the 2014-2020 programming period, they have been integrated into the European Structural and Investment Funds.In this context, it is important that development is properly addressed, for example through adequate recognition of the high potential of renewable energy sources and full adherence to the objectives of the Paris Agreement, climate and so-called "blue growth.", with particular attention to the environmental challenges caused by the need to combat waste at sea and to promote biodiversity and sustainable tourism.To this end, greater involvement in the decision-making process of stakeholders and local communities is absolutely necessary.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: in writing. - Currently, 19 Member States and 8 non-EU countries are cooperating in the framework of the Union's four macro-regional strategies, with some Member States participating in several macro-regional strategies. Although macro-regional strategies are based on the "three sexes" principle and do not receive separate EU funding, their added value is huge, as cross-border cooperation enhances cooperation between Member States to improve the economic development and social conditions of the countries concerned. The debate on the main lines of cohesion policy after 2020 has already begun, so it is important that we also start thinking together about the future role of macro-regional strategies. The process of globalization has further highlighted the interdependence of individual countries and the need to find common solutions. Political commitment and the ownership of the strategy by Member States and citizens are key to the future of macro-regional strategies. This issue can be closely linked to measurable results, to specific, quantifiable goals achieved by macro-regional strategies. I believe that the commitment and the belief in the added value of macro-regional strategies can be effectively helped by the concrete results and the achievement of the set goals. I therefore consider it very important that, when thinking about the future of macro-regional strategies, we take stock of the results achieved and evaluate existing macro-regional strategies before developing any new ones.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing. - Four macro-regional strategies have been developed in Europe, bringing together regions crossing the borders of several Union countries. Their role is to intensify and more effectively cooperate in achieving the goals of their socio-economic development and better living conditions and to build a European identity with regard to regional and national identity. Slovakia is involved in the EU Strategy for the Danube Region, whose main tasks are to build transport and energy infrastructure, support mobility, tourism and cultural development and protect the environment. In order to fulfill the meaningful position of these strategies, it is essential to align their objectives with those of the EU strategy in all common areas. This also requires the creation of conditions to simplify funding, administration and procedures for drawing on several financial mechanisms, but in particular from the Union's Structural Funds.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The next item is the debate on the question with request for an oral answer to the Commission on the implementation of Regulation (EU) 2015/1839 as regards specific measures for Greece by Iskra Mihaylova, on behalf ofthe Committee on Regional Development (O-000100/2017 - B8-0001 / 2018) (2018/2501 (RSP)).

name: Iskra MIHAYLOVA
text: author. – Madam President, I am here to put the question on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development (REGI), because of the real interest among the Members of REGI on the implementation of these extraordinary special measures which have been taken because of the Commission proposal adopted on 17 July 2015 – a legislative proposal to amend the common provision regulation in respect of specific measures for further financial assistance to Greece. This was a very strong reaction after the Greece crisis, and at that time we believed, together with the Commission, that we could support Greece in the efforts of the country to get out of the crisis and succeed in the efforts to complete and implement the successful projects. The goal of this proposal was two-fold: to provide additional pre-financing for 2014-2020 cohesion policy operational programmes under the investment for growth and jobs goal and for programmes financed from the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund in Greece, and secondly, to allow for the ceiling for the cumulative pre-financing and interim payments to be 100% and to increase the co-financing rate for 2007-2013 operational programmes for the convergence and regional competitiveness and employment objectives in Greece to 100%. In the European Parliament, the decision was taken to deal with this revision on CPR under the simplified procedure (it was the decision of the REGI Committee), so we adopted this proposal as quickly as possible in order to allow a greater stimulus effect to make sure that the Greek authorities could make full use of European Union funding available for the cohesion policy under the previous financial period. The REGI Committee appointed a standing rapporteur to follow the implementation of the new regulation – later on he will take the floor here in the debate. But on several occasions, including during a joint hearing organised by the Committee on Regional Development and the Committee on Budgetary Control on the implementation of the priority projects list initiative in Greece on 4 December 2017, Members of Parliament expressed their regret at the near absence of communication between the Commission and Parliament on the implementation and performance of these CPR amendments. The lack of reporting information made available by the Commission and the Greek authorities on the result of the special measures adopted for Greece should be emphasised. More specifically, there has been no reporting on the real effects on the application of the maximum cofinancing rate of 100% to the eligible expenditure of Greek operational programmes for the growth and regional competitiveness in employment objectives. In this respect, the first part of our question will be: what conclusions does the Commission draw from the report provided by the Greek authorities in May 2017 on the implementation of the specific measures in Greece? And further on, how this mechanism, which is an extraordinary mechanism, has helped further progress in the priority projects in Greece in their implementation and progress of these 181 priority projects. And on how infrastructure investments and European Union structural investment funds have contributed to the improvement of overall competitiveness of Greece. It is very important to implement today these discussions to hear the answer of the Commission, because we made these together to support Greece in the country’s efforts, and now we are very interested to see how our measures have been implemented in reality in Greece and what the results are after these extraordinary measures.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I apologise to the honourable Members at the beginning, but there were so many questions and I will take a bit longer, because I do not like to be criticised as we are always very open. First I would like to thank Parliament for giving me this opportunity to talk about these specific measures for Greece which we adopted together, as we said, in October 2015. I am very grateful to the Committee on Regional Development and in particular to the Chair, Mrs Mihaylova, and to Mr Arimont for their continuous support in promoting these measures. I would also like to thank the Committee on Budgetary Control (CONT) – they are not here – for their constant interest, in particular in implementing the priority project list, as we said, which was launched in 2011 by my predecessor, Commissioner Hahn. As you know, we have together adopted extraordinary measures for extraordinary times, as you said, Madam President. The impact of these specific measures in favour of Greece shows to what extent cohesion policy has played a decisive role in relaunching the Greek economy. They are also a vivid expression of the solidarity of cohesion policy, and I hereby confirm that the Commission stands by the Greek authorities to assist them in boosting jobs and growth. I think it is important to recall, first of all, the extraordinary nature of these specific measures. As you well know, in 2015 the Commission proposed to amend the Common Provision Regulation because Greece was desperately in need of liquidity. The purpose of this revision was to frontload existing EU funds for investment in growth-enhancing projects with two objectives in mind: to help implement the 2007-2013 programmes and to kick-start investments under the new programming period. In total, approximately EUR 2 billion were paid to Greece in 2015 and 2016. This included EUR 1 billion for the 2007-2013 period, linked to two measures: first, the increase of the EU cofinancing rate to 100%, which meant that no national contribution was needed; second, the early release of the last 5% of remaining EU payments, normally released only at the closure of the programmes. To maximise the impact of these additional amounts, Greece undertook the commitment to channel them via a ring—fenced account. The other EUR 1 billion was made available by increasing the rate of initial pre-financing for 2014—2020 programmes. Measuring the impact of the specific measures on the completion of individual projects is not an easy task, as cohesion policy assistance is provided at programme level. But what is certain is that without these measures there would have been many more uncompleted projects and Greece would have had serious trouble financing their completion. The report provided by the Greek authorities indeed shows that, thanks to these specific measures, the number of uncompleted projects was drastically reduced for 2007-2013, and only 79 projects are yet to be completed out of more than 50 000. One of the most striking examples is the completion of the five highway concessions. The liquidity provided for the specific measures was a prime contributor to their finalisation. Regarding the priority project list, I believe that the outcome of the exercise has been satisfactory. It includes over 180 projects in a wide range of sectors. To date, close to 120 projects have been completed, while 18 projects are being completed with national funds. 24 projects are being continued in the current period. The whole mechanism has worked as a trigger for the Greek Government and local and regional authorities to take ownership and action when projects were not moving ahead as they should. Overall these specific measures have brought Greece back on track for the benefit of the Greek citizens. The high amount of liquidity injected in a short period of time relaunched investments in the Greek real economy. According to the 2017-2018 edition of the Global Competitiveness Index, Greece scores particularly well on infrastructure and ranks 38th out of 137. As regards the increased competitiveness of Greece, when we compare the 2017-2018 edition of the Global Competitiveness Index with the 2012—2013 one, Greece has improved notably in own infrastructures, technological readiness and innovation. These are typically sectors for which structural funds have provided extensive support in the past decades. These measures were extraordinary. I think they are the epitome of what cohesion policy should be: solidarity in action and not only in words. It is a policy that delivers, adapts to circumstances, helps concretely and has a tangible impact on the daily lives of millions of Europeans. I would like to conclude by underlining that the Commission will continue to provide all the information to Parliament. I am ready to hear your point of view and to respond.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner! In summary, it is about two billion euros that Greece received in 2015 in order to be able to invest in projects more quickly and easily. We did that at the time because it was a special case and we also took a special measure - only on the condition that Parliament can also exercise a special control, a check on whether the money was used efficiently and whether the projects were for have contributed to the economic recovery of Greece. I have been waiting for this report from the Greek government since March 2017. I have written several times to the Commission, written to the Greek Government, and on December 4th I was only sent a version of this report, which I have to carry out an evaluation, in Greek. I don't speak this language and then expected to be conveyed to me in a language that I understand and can also evaluate. I have actually waited until today and I am glad that we are making this interpellation today, because today - oh wonder - I received this text in German. I regret this, firstly because the citizens of Europe have the right to know whether this money has been spent correctly and secondly because I would also like to use this report to prove and prove that cohesion policy is important, that it represents European added value and should also exist beyond 2020. (The speaker agreed to answer a question about the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: question with blue card. - You know the exception given to Greece in October 2015 was a recognition of the impact that the prolonged political uncertainty had on funding. But everything went well. The closing of the 2007-2013 season went very well, the start of the 2014-2020 season went very well. So I would like to ask Mr Arimont what the debate is about today. It has undertaken to collect data on the course of resource absorption in Greece. If it has information that we do not know, and which the Commission has not provided, we should know. If not, he maintains his stereotypes even unwittingly. And finally when will we have the result of his research.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- I can really only answer that: on the one hand, the absorption rate in Greece seems to be high, and if I use the word 'seems', it is because I actually did not receive this report, or in a language that I understandis not known.And a final assessment of whether the absorption rate is actually that high, whether the money has gone into sensible projects, whether that has contributed to an economic upswing, unfortunately I cannot give at this point in time.I heard what the Commissioner said.She told us it was all okay.I would like to read this once, with facts, figures and arguments from the Greek government.As long as I do not have that, or as long as I do not have this report in the language I understand, unfortunately I cannot give a specific answer to this question.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Due to the accumulated delay, I will no longer be able to take “blue card” questions.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, two and a half years after the introduction of the exceptional measures for Greece, guaranteeing the financial instruments necessary to start the implementation of the programs, we still know little about how effective this has been. I find this discussion really useful, because the one with Greece is generally the largest rescue operation in history. Greece has now entered its seventh year of economic reforms requested by international creditors but the Greek government, under pressure from creditors, has approved several measures, some contrary to the intentions announced and, after the strikes and protests, we are now all asking ourselves that what will happen in Greece in 2018, where the economic and social situation is really critical. I thank Commissioner Crețu for her report, thank you for informing us and for the data presented. Therefore, continue monitoring and follow development, follow the progress in the use of the Structural Funds. Only in this way will we be able to increase the confidence of citizens and the very concept of European cohesion, only in this way will we be able to demonstrate the effective usefulness of what has been done.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President, the implementation of Regulation 2015/1839 regarding special measures for Greece has not yielded the well-publicized results and certainly has not been able to make a decisive contribution to the creation of thousands of new jobs and the strengthening of small and medium-sized enterprises. At the same time, the Juncker plan has only done for Greece to facilitate foreign state multinationals to consolidate their position in the Greek economy. Thus, Fraport, which was borrowed by Greek and foreign banks with 688 million euros to seize 14 Greek regional airports, was borrowed with 280 million euros by the European Investment Bank, in order to fulfill its contractual obligations, which was the investment of infrastructure amounting to 400 million. In addition, Cosmote, a subsidiary of state-owned Deutsche Telecom, received 150m euros from the project, which will increase to 400m euros through leverage. Therefore, the multinational and not the small and medium Greek companies were strengthened.

name: Matthijs van MILTENBURG
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - In 2015, great pressure was exerted on the European Parliament to agree to the amendment of the Common Provisions Regulation. Exceptional measures were taken to help Greece in the form of additional pre-financing and a co-financing rate of 100%. It is therefore very important that the European Commission communicates proactively and transparently about the effects of these measures. Because if that does not happen, doubts could arise about the effectiveness of these specific measures. I think it is good that we are having this debate, that we are starting to find answers to questions. But I still have questions, questions that remain. For example, which projects were finally 100% funded after the amendment of the regulation and what was the effect on Greece's competitiveness? I still feel in the dark about that, even today. So I think it would be good if the Commission would nevertheless present a report to the European Parliament on the effectiveness of the measures, in addition to this debate.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - The data presented to us by Commissioner Crețu show, ladies and gentlemen, that Regulation 2015/1839, which we adopted by a large majority in July 2015, has borne fruit. Greece is recovering and most of the projects, which in July 2015 were unfinished while they should have been completed in 2013, have been completed, are being completed and are progressing. Productivity is increasing. Greece has returned to growth. Unemployment is falling. So instead of some claiming that they do not know, they are called, Mr Arimont, to take the data and use it as proof that what we have been approved by a large majority in the European Parliament and the Commission works and works. And if you do not listen to me, listen to Mrs. Spyraki who belongs to your political group.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam president; Commissioner, I think it is clear that the regulation worked well and was a good measure to help a country in difficulties. The only thing that is true to note is that there was a lack of coherence in the European Commission throughout all these years, because while Greece was being helped through cohesion policy, in a correct way, it was also they imposed draconian programs of adjustment that stifled her. And therefore, there was a total lack of coherence that must be noted. However, cohesion policy played its role: the measures taken were good; The data that you have given us on the absorption capacity of the financed projects are absolutely good - those that you have presented to us. And I also have to say, regarding the doubts that some colleagues raise about whether Greece used or did not use these funds well, that data must be provided to make these accusations. And the ones we have, which the European Commission has given us, are good and they are the ones we have to stick to. Therefore, I would like to point out that we must continue with cohesion policy as it has been followed up to now in Greece and continue to help those countries in difficulty, when necessary.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is important for the Commission to report on the results of the measures taken by Parliament in October 2015 in favor of Greece. The combination of the three measures avoided the risk of 2 billion being lost and provided liquidity for 2 billion, but I think it is equally right to remind everyone of the disastrous situation that the troika has caused in the country. Cohesion policy does what it can, but concerns remain about the situation of extreme social and economic fragility. Since 2010, Greece has lost a third of its GDP, half a million people have emigrated, housing problems and health needs have increased, affecting one in four people. The reduction in purchasing power impoverishes families, small and medium-sized enterprises disappear, the unemployment rate is at 21%. The Greek people continue to pay off sins that are not their own, but it is shown that the southern regions are welcoming to migrants who continue to disembark while other countries of Northeast Europe continue to not act and are opposed to any hypothesis of sharing responsibility.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - The European Union, one of the main people responsible for the destruction of the Greek economy and the impoverishment of the lives of Greeks, has adopted emergency financial measures to have liquidity and to cover the deficits of public resources. However, these measures were not effective because, as already mentioned here, the European Parliament and the European Commission could not be coordinated. Greece's economic problem is artificial. It has been deliberately created to save the euro and to rob the creditors of the rich energy reserves that exist in the subsoil and in the underwater space of our country. In order to solve this problem, the reasons that caused it must disappear. And these reasons are: the implementation of the memoranda, the lending on interest-bearing terms, the imposition on the country of an illegal and abhorrent debt, and, in addition, the destruction of primary production. Finally, it is turning the country into a vast camp of illegal immigrants, in which humanitarian Europeans have left these unfortunate people living in miserable conditions. So these reasons must disappear. Everything else is half a meter. It is the aspirin with which the European Union is trying to cure an incurable disease that it has caused.

name: Lambert van NISTELROOIJ
text: - (NL) Madam President, the question is why we are here. We are not here to come back to something we loved to do: help out in a very difficult situation. But the point is - the Commissioner just said - that it is an extremely extraordinary situation. name: Miltiadis KYRKOS
text: - Commissioner, I would like to thank you publicly for the Commission's crucial intervention regarding the special measures for Greece. Without these data you presented, the deep Greek crisis would have been deeper. But the overall picture is unfortunately bleak. The Greek economy, which has been uncompetitive for decades and has relied on debt and the state of corruption, inevitably led to the 2010 crisis that wiped out 27% of GDP. In the competitiveness index you mentioned, we are, in total, in the eighty-seventh place. The Commission's excellent intentions will have very little impact on the competitiveness and viability of the Greek economy without the extension of public debt repayment, the reduction of tax evasion, the radical reorganization of public administration, the cessation of pluralism incubating corruption, the acceleration of administration of justice. And, most importantly, if we do not accept that the customer system is no longer viable. You do not wonder why 7 years were not enough for Greece to get out of the memoranda.

name: Manolis KEFALOGIANNIS
text: - Madam President, in Greece we have been experiencing the biggest crisis for 70 years. The crisis has caused serious liquidity problems in the public and padlocks in the private sector. text: - Commissioner Creţu, I come back to remind you that those times were indeed of prolonged uncertainty and that, fortunately for all of us, the measures taken had a positive effect on both the effective closure of the programs of the first 2007-2013 period and the start of the period. 2014-2020. name: Corina CREȚU
text: Membră a Comisiei. – Doamnă președintă, nu cred însă că mă pot încadra în două minute pentru a răspunde, pentru că aș vrea, în primul rând, să-mi exprim întreaga mea solidaritate față de poporul grec, atât de greu încercat, așa cum ați spus, în ultimii ani. Știți foarte bine că eu cred că rolul nostru în Uniunea Europeană este de a ne arăta solidaritatea, mai ales în momente dificile.  Cele mai multe vizite le-am făcut în Italia după ce această țară a fost atât de greu încercată de cutremur, apoi în țările care au fost încercate de incendii și, bineînțeles, în Grecia, unde am fost în acea primă fază, când, într-adevăr, așa cum am spus, guvernul era într-o disperare totală, după care, încet, încet, am încercat să ajutăm și am venit în fața dumneavoastră, împreună cu aceste măsuri extraordinare pentru o situație extraordinară. The Commission services sent their comments in August 2017, and the Greek authorities answered in those comments with the revised closure document in December 2017. So the final assessment is expected to be concluded in the first half of 2018. This is in accordance with the procedure set out in the Common Provisions Regulation that applies to all Member States. The Commission will provide all information, as foreseen in the regulation. As regards information on what Greece did with this EUR two billion, it is up to the government, not us, to provide that. We have received this and are now translating it – with a slight delay, and we apologise for that – but you will receive this report. Following all your interventions I would like to be very clear that the specific measures for Greece have had a far-reaching impact that goes, in my view, beyond the liquidity issues. As a result of these measures, Greece has been the first Member State to reach full absorption of available funds under 2007-2013. Greece is also among the best-performing Member States regarding the implementation of 2014-2020 programmes. These promising results echo all the efforts we, the Commission and European Parliament, have made together, to support Greece and encourage it in tackling its challenges. I say to Mr Marias that we have created so many jobs, and it is not fair to say that only the multinationals are creating jobs for the younger generation in Greece. I do not share this view. It is very important to share this news and go beyond this way of thinking, because it is really important to know exactly what we are doing. We can provide you with details of exactly what we have done for the younger generation of Greek people. We have also provided support in rural areas and also in the most deprived areas. You know very well that we are providing as much help as we can to all the islands, which have been much hit migratory problems. Assistance to the tune of EUR 20 billion for 2014-2020 from the structural funds is helping Greece regenerate its economy and boost its competitiveness by promoting a new model based on innovation and entrepreneurship. You can see very well, as I said at the beginning, in all the indicators and statistics. I am very confident that in the current period Greece will make ever greater achievements, thanks especially to the concentration of resources and efforts in selected productive sectors, in line with the national and regional smart specialisation strategies, as well as the necessary structural reforms for the modernisation of the public sector. With the ongoing support from the European Parliament, I hope that you will continue to help Greece thrive. Things are not as good as we had hoped, but we hope that together we will help the Member States most in need. Greece was in this situation, and I am very proud that we have achieved all these things for the Greek people in the last three years.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for the debate on the report by José Inácio Faria on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on international ocean governance: a program for the future of ouroceans in the context of the 2030 Sustainable Development Goals (2017/2055 (INI) (A8-0399 / 2017)).

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: reporter. - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the seas and oceans represent 70% of the planet's surface and its water accounts for 97% of the world's total water. The seas provide food, energy, mobility, medicines and leisure, and are a source of economic growth. Oceans, along with coastal and marine resources, play an essential role in human well-being and economic and social development worldwide. According to OECD estimates, ocean-based industries represent a gross world-wide added value of around 1.3 billion euros, which could double by 2030. The oceans are also home to rich, fragile and, to a large extent, biodiversity. , untapped, which offers a variety of important ecosystem resources and services. Marine and coastal economies are developing worldwide, but their success depends on better sustainability. The oceans also play a key role in regulating the climate system, supplying half of our oxygen, absorbing about 25% of the CO2 emissions produced and redistributing heat across the planet. The oceans are, in fact, our greatest allies against climate change and have been included in the Paris Agreement. However, our oceans are extremely vulnerable to overexploitation, climate change, such as global warming of the oceans, environmental degradation, water acidification due to emissions resulting from human activities, pollution and a decrease in biodiversity. Some of these more urgent global challenges, including climate change, poverty, safe and sufficient food for a population projected to reach 9 billion by 2050, can only be addressed effectively if the oceans are safe, clean and managed sustainably. To address all of these challenges, better international governance is needed in order to strengthen efforts at regional and global level. These challenges were recognized globally at both the Rio + 20 summit and the UN 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, which identified the conservation and sustainable use of our oceans as one of the 17 sustainable development goals and as part of an agenda highly interconnected. The joint Communication of the European Commission and the High Representative in 2016 on the international governance of the oceans, which is an integral part of the European Union's response to the 2030 Agenda, was based on a broad consensus on the need to strengthen the governance framework of oceans, reduce the pressure on them, exploit them in a sustainable way and that, to that end, greater knowledge of the oceans would be necessary, proposing for this purpose 50 actions to ensure safe, clean and sustainably managed oceans in Europe and the world. world. The international governance of the oceans is concerned with three areas of action for the European Union: sustainable development, growth and employment and Union intervention in the world. For Europe, the maritime economy and international competitiveness are, in this context, of particular importance given the increasingly worrying state of the oceans and the impact that human activities have on them. In either case, the success of management is a challenge to be overcome worldwide. The Union and the Member States must act more firmly and together. This report, which will be voted on tomorrow, encourages the Commission to develop partnerships in the field of the oceans with the main players in this field, as a means to achieve better international governance of the oceans. The way we deal with the oceans is crucial for our survival as a species and, in Malta, Commissioner Vella mentioned, during the “Our Ocean” Conference, that the oceans are the blue heart of the Earth and that it is up to us all us the task of keeping that heart beating. It fits- we now have the urgent task of acting in defense of the oceans and creating a new and ambitious international governance of the oceans.And for all this, ladies and gentlemen, I hope to be able to count on your favorable vote tomorrow during the vote.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank my colleague, Mr Faria, for his excellent report. I would like to repeat my earlier position that the EU definitely has to be in the lead in creating better international ocean governance and an internationally binding convention that is system-wide and covers different fields. It would cover overfishing of fish stocks, marine conservation areas, action needed to preserve biodiversity, combat acidification and chemicalisation of the seas. Of course, action is needed on safer precautionary principles, not forgetting micro-plastics, which is one of the most urgent and newest challenges. There is a lot to tackle in the future, but best of luck and courage to the Commission in starting this as soon as possible.

name: Linnéa ENGSTRÖM
text: - Madam President! Thank you to the rapporteur, Mr Faria, for very good cooperation and a very good report. The challenges we face with our oceans and the task of regulating their activities are enormous. Climate change is affecting marine ecosystems and fishing is putting significant pressure on marine ecosystems. Transnational fishing companies have the greatest responsibility, but I am very concerned about a new activity in the oceans that is emerging, and that is deep-sea drilling. No one yet knows what consequences it will have for marine ecosystems, fish stocks and marine health in the future. We demand more transparency in the process where the international seabed authority makes decisions on international waters to states for test drilling and very soon for commercial extraction. International water is owned by no one but must be managed by others for the well-being of future generations. I demand a transparent process with proper environmental investigations, greater transparency for civil society and a public accountability for those who represent us in the International Seabed Authority.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: - Mr President, I would also like to thank Mr Faria for his excellent report. We know that marine litter is one of the biggest and growing environmental problems and that plastic is a big factor in that. 95 percent of the world’s plastic is used only once and then thrown away. Much of it ends up in the terrain or the sea. Tons of plastic waste end up in the sea every year, and there are large batches of plastic bottles and plastic bags. Work needs to be done globally to reduce these. It is good that plastic bags are now widely available in Europe or that efforts are being made to reduce them. The bottle deposit system also needs to be developed. My own country, Finland, is a good example of this. We have had a market-based bottle deposit system for decades, as a result of which 92 percent of plastic bottles are returned for recycling. This needs to be extended across Europe. One concrete step, of course, will be to clearly ban microplastics in hygiene products. Therefore, the Commission's plastics strategy to be announced this week will be a really important need.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - I want to join my predecessors in assessing the crisis that may be taking place in the area of ​​our seas, our oceans. I will recall Article 14 of the UN Agenda, which states that we should protect and sustainably use the seas and oceans, while industrial fishing itself is indeed a disaster for biodiversity and precisely the standard of living in the oceans. At the same time, I would like to draw attention to the journal Science, which issued a very warning at the beginning of this year: the space that can be described as dead zones in our seas and oceans has increased 4 times. These are mainly coastal areas. At the same time, scientists say that it is possible to face this danger with good cooperation with local companies, especially farmers. I think we should make that commitment. I still wanted to comment on the problem of emissions from maritime transport, which are set to rise by up to 250%, but I do not have time for that.

name: Brian HAYES
text: – Madam President, thank you for your forbearance and I apologise for not coming in earlier. I would like to congratulate my colleague on the report. I think it is very important that Europe should lead in this area, in terms of governance of our oceans, not least because of our responsibilities in delivering on sustainable development goals. If we cannot do it no other part of the world will, and it does require from our side a very clear leadership role. We know huge progress has been made in recycling in recent years but much of that progress has been made on the development of markets in other parts of the world. Where those markets are not there in the future, or diminish in the future, that should not in any way reduce our resolve to make sure that recycling rates continue to grow here within the European Union. If we cannot lead on this issue, as I said, no one else will follow us. That is why it is so important when it comes to our seas, be it in the area of industrial fishing, plastics, the whole question of pollution, that the European Union has to lead on this issue. This report challenges those of us within the 28 Member States to do much more in terms of leadership.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, first of all, I would like to thank the two rapporteurs, Mr Faria and Ms Monteiro de Aguiar, as well as the shadow rapporteurs, for their valuable work. I very much welcome the European Parliament’s own-initiative report on international ocean governance, as well as your support for the general objectives of the Joint Communication and its actions. I would like to thank all the speakers for your valuable comments as well. This Joint Communication is a major step forward, as this is the first time that the Commission and the High Representative have issued such a policy statement on the oceans. With this Communication, the European Union is taking the lead as a global actor in strengthening international ocean governance.  The success of the ‘Our Ocean Conference’, which was hosted by the European Union three months ago in Malta, confirms our engagement to be at the frontline to tackle global ocean challenges.  The Joint Communication on international ocean governance is an integral part of the EU response to the United Nations 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), in particular SDG 14. It sets out 50 concrete and tangible actions in three priority areas for safe, secure, clean and sustainably managed oceans.  Our first priority is to improve the international ocean governance framework. A globalised world needs a more cooperative global governance. We believe in the power of diplomacy, rules and international institutions, but there is no real global governance without a cooperative oceans governance. As a matter of fact, the European Union is deploying the necessary efforts through our cooperation on multilateral, regional and bilateral level, as well as concrete projects and programmes. In the same direction, promoting maritime multilateralism is a strategic priority for the EU. In line with the EU global strategy, secured and protected seas and oceans can only be achieved through collaborative efforts. In this regard, I very much welcome last month’s decision by the UN General Assembly on a resolution to convene an Intergovernmental Conference to elaborate the text of an internationally legally binding instrument under United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS), on marine biodiversity beyond national jurisdiction, which the European Union has championed for many years.  Our second priority is to further engage in international action to reduce the pressures and their causes on the oceans. Pressures and causes such as marine litter, the consequences of climate change, such as a rise in sea level, warming and acidification, as well as ensuring the sustainable use of the oceans and their biodiversity, merge into this priority. This also depends on the appropriate planning and management of human uses. Promoting maritime spatial planning and our marine environmental legislation at regional and global level is key in this regard, and I am very pleased to see your support on this issue. In addition, the upcoming plastic strategy will further complement our fight against marine litter. Oceans are also very important for many developing countries as a potential source of food, of jobs and revenue. We are working with several countries on programmes that support sustainable fisheries, marine protected areas and coastal zone management, climate mitigation in the maritime shipping sector, harbour infrastructure and even maritime security. Ongoing programmes amount to some EUR 590 million, and more are in preparation under the 2014-2020 programing.  Finally, we are working to further advance our knowledge of the oceans. We shall therefore keep investing over EUR 260 million per year in marine and maritime research projects. Modern technologies are opening up new possibilities and we should make the most of them. Another aim is to step up ocean observations and to create a worldwide marine data network which is open to all. We will further develop marine research and science partnerships with key international partners. These actions, whether they are stricto sensu related to the ocean governance framework, or to pressures on the marine environment, marine security and research, are all part of a holistic approach. There is a logic to this approach. The pressures that the oceans are facing are not only global, but also interconnected, as are the solutions. Yet the success of EU action depends not only on us, but also on our international partners. In this respect, your support on establishing ocean partnerships with key ocean players is highly appreciated. This will provide the opportunity to bring issues of common concern and interest on ocean governance to the table.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. – I would like to congratulate the rapporteur for the outcome of this very important report, which constitutes an ambitious response to the Joint Communication and puts forward key guidelines for efficient and effective ocean governance at international level in order to deliver on the commitments of the Paris Agreement and achieve the 2030 Agenda.
