Therefore, I fully welcome the proposed actions within the report, which reflect the EU’s commitment towards the objective set out in SDG (Sustainable Development Goal) 14 of the UN 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, that of achieving the conservation and sustainable use of oceans, seas and marine resources, and to the fulfilment of which, we as a champion of the fight against climate change, have an essential contribution to bring.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written. - Extremely important importance of the sea and ocean, it is becoming even bigger every day. The oceans are actually our biggest allies in the fight against climate change. The seas are a source of food, energy, mobility, medicine and rest, they regulate our climate, give us half of our oxygen and take up a significant proportion of the carbon dioxide we emit. In addition to the many problems caused by global warming, one of the fastest growing threats to the health of the world’s oceans is the accumulation and spread of marine litter. Microplastics are of particular concern because, due to their insignificant size, they are available to a wide range of organisms (seabirds, fish, mussels, sandflies, and zooplankton). The staggering figure of 150 million tonnes of plastic that has accumulated in the world’s oceans is causing serious environmental and economic damage, including coastal communities, tourism, maritime transport and fishing. In this context, we need an ambitious circular economy package with targets for reducing marine litter in the European Union from 30% by 2025 and 50% by 2030, and larger targets for plastic packaging recycling. The oceans transcend borders, so strong regional and international cooperation between governments in all maritime regions and a wide range of interdisciplinary expertise are needed to ensure the sustainability of shared resources and the proper management of the oceans.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on the report by Linnéa Engström, on behalf of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, on women, gender equality and climate justice (2017/2086(INI)) (A8-0403 / 2017)

name: Linnéa ENGSTRÖM
text: Rapporteur - Madam President! I am very proud to stand here today and present the first report in the European Parliament on climate justice. A big thank you to all the shadow rapporteurs for an excellent collaboration. In this report, the European Parliament recognizes the fact that the effects of climate change are unevenly distributed and not gender neutral. They affect women, children and indigenous peoples disproportionately much more. The UN estimates that 70 percent of the 1.3 billion people living in poverty worldwide are women, often living in the countries most at risk of floods, rising sea levels, droughts and storms. Women and children are also 14 times more likely than men to die in natural disasters. Climate justice aims to protect the most vulnerable and ensures a fair distribution of burdens and benefits of climate change and its effects. Women are just as important actors as men and can play a crucial role in developing our climate policy. Therefore, women must be represented equally in the decision-making process and the implementation of climate policy. The report also contains an important reference to the fact that climate change is a driving force for migration. The developments we are seeing in parts of Africa and the Middle East are likely to contribute to political instability, economic strains and an escalation of refugee flows and migration. Around the year 2050, the UN estimates that the world may have up to 200 million people displaced from their homes due to climate change. This is a future perspective that we cannot continue to ignore. We need to develop the UN system of migration and existing definitions and tools, so that they include this category of refugees. At the most recent climate summit in Bonn, the first gender equality plan was adopted under the Paris Agreement. All Member States should now choose a contact point for work on gender equality and the climate - a major step forward for an issue that has been so downgraded and opposed. In the UN system, work is underway to include climate refugees in the global migration strategy, and in that work we call on the EU to be proactive. The EU's refugee policy is a failure and a fatal failure in terms of legal security and accountability. With the forecast of an even more unjust world, lack of resources and rising global temperatures driving people to flee, politicians across the political spectrum understand that something must be done. People who have lost everything through floods and droughts today have no rights and are increasingly becoming climate refugees. Climate refugees are about rising temperatures and water levels, but when we talk about climate justice, we are often talking about people in other parts of the world, in the countries hardest hit by these consequences. But even in my country, Sweden, in the north, the consequences of climate change are noticeable in a dramatic way. The reindeer herding Sami in Norrland live in the front line of climate change. 300 reindeer went through the ice when they were to be herded to new pastures last year. It should not really be able to happen, but the winters are getting warmer and the old paths where the Sami have herded their animals for generations and where the ice has functioned as a route no longer hold. This creates huge problems for people and animals in the north. Entire ecosystems are now changing rapidly before our eyes and that is why it is so important to raise the issue of justice. Most vulnerable are those who are discriminated against and marginalized in our societies, not to mention how animals are affected. In two years, an ecosystem as large as the whole of Italy has disappeared on the seabed. These are unique coral reefs in the Great Barrier Reef off the coast of Australia. I do not think there is a clearer example of the rampant climate crisis. The answer to all these challenges is about stopping and adapting to climate change and protecting the most vulnerable through an inclusive and feminist climate agenda.With this report, we will have adopted a common definition of what climate justice actually is and a range of tools that can channel resources to those who need it most.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - This report states that climate change, in particular weather fluctuations, droughts, floods, is having a greater negative impact on the lives of those who are in some way at risk of poverty, illiteracy or their dignity. So they are mostly women. This report sets out important facts that we should take into account when we want to find a solution, such as the fact that women are most affected by the effects of all climatic fluctuations, as they usually run the household and care for its members. On average, women in the world carry out more than 70% of all water supply activities in areas affected by climate change. 70% of all women in the agricultural sector work there, but women are usually not involved in economic or environmental policy decisions. Also, the situation where 781 million people aged 15 are illiterate and 2/3 of them are women shows that there is a need to get involved in this matter.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, as a feminist I am very happy about this report because it underlines the gender aspects of climate change, and encourages the Commission and the Member States to take them into account. I am happy to see that the report highlights the fact that women are indeed more affected by climate change than men, especially when it comes to displacement. More than 50% of the current refugee and migration flow comprises women and children and many of them are climate refugees.  Women are highly dependent on natural resources, particularly in rural areas, and play a significant role ensuring food security for their communities. I remember visiting a flooded community in Malawi with CARE International 18 months ago, and it was the women who were rebuilding that community. So I would also like to underline that involving women in decision-making on climate change is absolutely necessary if we are to find efficient solutions. Putting women in charge is more than a diversity concern: it is about having better policies for everyone.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Madam President, there are many conclusions and recommendations in this Report that I could challenge because I believe that this is a very ideological view of important global challenges. However, I would like to highlight the recommendation that special attention be paid to migrant women and girls who have been exposed to violence during their travels to Europe. Of course, this is something we should do, but I'm afraid it's just about calming our own conscience. There is, therefore, an awareness that a large number of migrant women are subjected to various forms of violence and this, as we see, is taken for granted, as if there is no alternative to illegal migration and the organized crime that benefits from it. No one is asking how much of our guilt is that these women die at the hands of smugglers, and many of them in Europe end up in a chain of prostitution. It is amazing that a good portion of colleagues still do not understand that our insane migration and asylum policy is the main reason why these women even go on the road that way and why they put their destiny in the hands of criminals who often ruin their lives.

name: Florent MARCELLESI
text: - Madam President, after Hurricane Katrina, in the United States, two-thirds of the people who lost their jobs were women.During the terrible heat wave of 2003, which cost thousands of lives in France, a vast majority of deaths were also women.Climate change affects men and women differently across the planet.That is why I am delighted that a report on climate justice and gender equality is being adopted for the first time, at the initiative of my political group, the European Greens.Women can and must play a crucial role in climate policy.For this, it is essential to focus on gender when talking about decision-making, financing and investment on climate change, combating deforestation, agriculture, education, access to energy and entrepreneurship in the energy transition.Equality and ecology are two sides of the same coin.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: - Madam President, women and girls are vulnerable to climate change and the effects of climate change exacerbate existing inequalities in society, especially women from rural areas, as they depend on natural resources because they are engaged in agricultural work and perform a large number of unpaid households. jobs so I advocate that this is exactly what changes and that their work is recognized and paid for. It is certainly a worrying fact that women and children die 14 times more than men in the event of natural disasters. Women are still underrepresented in climate change decision-making bodies, so I support stronger involvement of women in the implementation and enforcement of environmental policies at the national local level. I also join calls on the Commission to include climate change in development programs and to find solutions to these problems as well as to their financing. I support the initiative to focus women on entrepreneurship related to clean energy and thus help them in self-employment.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, on behalf of the Commission, let me thank Parliament for preparing this important report on women, gender equality and climate justice. Let me start by emphasising that gender equality matters in its own right, and that it matters for effective climate action and sustainable development. This is rightly recognised in the report. Women are disproportionately vulnerable to the impacts of climate change, where their rights and socioeconomic status are not equal to those of men, and where they have less voice and influence than men in shaping policies and prioritising how climate finance is used. The empowerment of women is an important ingredient in building climate resilience and, as pointed out in the resolution, women are primary agents of change and effective risk managers. The European Union is already committed to promoting a gender perspective in climate policies, both domestically and internationally, and to supporting women’s engagement and gender equality in the international negotiations under the United Nations Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC). The European Union’s stance in climate negotiations has been, and continues to be, that the full and equal participation of women in climate negotiations and in the design of climate action is key. The EU delegation in climate talks also comprises over 50% women, and two out of three leading EU negotiators are women. Moreover, the Commission has been directly involved in shaping the development of a gender action plan under the UNFCCC. We have not only been participating and contributing to a round of informal consultations on the development of the gender action plan, but also are one of the few organisations providing dedicated funding to the UNFCCC secretariat’s work on gender activities. This support is critical for the continuation of the work that the UNFCCC is doing on gender. At COP 23 in Bonn, the European Union played an active and enabling role in the negotiations leading up to the adoption of this gender action plan. By supporting the implementation of gender—related decisions and mandates under the Convention, this gender action plan seeks to advance women’s full, equal and meaningful participation and promote gender—responsive climate policy and the mainstreaming of a gender perspective in the work of parties. It sets out five priority areas: first, capacity-building, knowledge sharing and communication. Second, gender—balanced participation and women’s leadership. Third, coherence; fourth, gender—responsive implementation and means of implementation. And fifth, monitoring and reporting, all supported by a list of proposed activities such as workshops for policymakers on gender—responsive policies and holding a dialogue with the standing committee on finance on its work to improve gender—sensitive access to climate finance. The empowerment of women and upscaling climate action are also central in our development cooperation efforts. We implement targeted measures to tackle gender inequalities and climate change issues in our partner countries, while also mainstreaming gender equality and climate change perspectives into all aspects of our development policy. Gender equality and the empowerment of women and girls are recognised as a cross-cutting driver for sustainable development in the new European consensus on development and the EU gender action plan 2016—2020. We can already see concrete results of this approach. The EU’s Global Climate Change Alliance Plus flagship initiative supports climate action in different areas, including by empowering women and addressing gender issues in the context of climate change and climate-induced migration. Half of the initiative’s partner countries recognise women as a particularly vulnerable group in their nationally determined contributions. The Global Climate Change Alliance Plus is embarking on further gender mainstreaming in its programmes and taking a leadership role for other EU climate funding instruments. Other positive examples include the Evergreening Africa with Trees project, the Forest Law Enforcement Governance and Trade action plan and the SWITCH to Green initiative. At the same time, we are ready to further increase our efforts on the ground to promote the equal rights of women in our partner countries to participate in, and directly influence, decision—making processes on climate and environmental issues as well as resilience building. Closely linked to these is the key role women have in sustainable energy. They are actors of change, but are regrettably at the centre of the negative impacts of non-sustainable energy consumption. The EU’s new action, Women and Sustainable Energy, worth EUR 20 million, will foster women’s active role in sustainable energy, specifically through actions promoting women’s entrepreneurship, training and economic empowerment in the sustainable energy sector in developing countries. Finally, as most of you have noted, the report also refers to the increased migration that may occur as a result of climate change. The EU has politically supported the establishment by COP 21 of the task force on displacement. At this stage, the task force will map existing relevant policies and institutional frameworks that deal with migration. After mid—2018, it will move to the phase of developing recommendations for approaches to avert, minimise and address displacement related to climate change impacts. The Commission is aware of the importance of also mainstreaming gender in its internal climate policies. This summer, the Commission will publish an evaluation highlighting the results of its work on adaptation since 2013, setting the basis for further development of the EU adaptation strategy. Due consideration of vulnerable groups, including women, will be part of these discussions. We welcome the suggestion made in the resolution to support the development of indicators and collect gender—disaggregated data when planning, implementing, monitoring and evaluating climate change policies, programmes and projects. We will also reflect on how to address this issue further in a concerted effort with all relevant Commission services. Last but not least, let me once again welcome this report by the European Parliament and congratulate the rapporteur, Ms Engström, on her work on this important topic of climate change and gender equality.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place on Tuesday 16 January 2018. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. – Gender equality is still an unsolved problem in the European space. I congratulate the rapporteur and I will vote on this report because even in climate change we unfortunaelty see a difference between women and men. Women are the ones who care for children in the event of climate calamities and climate change. I have often analysed the gender difference, in payroll, in office, in administration, and in politics. We have to watch, and I ask the Commission to do so, to ensure that the new regulations that apply here are taken up in national legislation.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing. - Climate change and global warming are creating climate refugees. Of these, women are the most vulnerable population precisely because of the lack of measures to consolidate gender equality. For this reason, climate justice requires measures to be taken to achieve social, employment and wage equality for men and women. It is well known that gender equality remains the greatest challenge of our time. The gender gap has narrowed significantly in recent years, but progress varies between Member States, and inequalities persist in many areas. An extremely large number of women continue to be discriminated against, without equal opportunities in education and the labor market. Particularly in the developing world, where women are particularly affected by climate change, although the vast majority work in agricultural work, very few of them own agricultural land. In addition, access to water in the same countries is particularly difficult and those most affected in this case are also women who, among other things, are in charge of household chores and food preparation.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for one-minute interventions on important political issues (Rule 163 of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen. I want to comment on the annual alternation of summer and winter time. What may have seemed an advantage or a saving 100 or 50 years ago is now more of a nuisance to our citizens. The annual change of time is an anachronism in the age of the digital economy, much like a steam engine. The argument that daylight saving time saves electricity also fails, because in Indiana, for example, when daylight saving time was introduced, there was a 1% increase in electricity instead of savings. The shift in time also has a negative effect on human health. According to research from Sweden, the number of heart attacks in the week after the switch to summer time will increase by 5% and the number of traffic accidents even by 7%. Another team of scientists found that the number of accidents at work will increase by 5.7% during this period. People are simply disoriented, they don't sleep, which is reflected in their attention. So there are really many arguments, and I believe that we will address this issue soon in the interests of our citizens, their health and safety.

name: John HOWARTH
text: – Madam President, the Schengen area is the embodiment of the principle of freedom of movement in the European Union. Around a million United Kingdom citizens live outside of the UK, mostly in that area. These are people who have chosen to make their lives in the European Union, and it is a life choice that is about a great deal more than work. These UK citizens have been badly let down by the lame agreement that the United Kingdom Government has negotiated for their futures. While European Union citizens in the UK will enjoy their continued freedom of movement rights, UK citizens in the Schengen area will see their rights severely limited. Ironically, these are the UK citizens most likely to be young, least likely to have the five years’ residential qualification, and most likely to identify themselves as European. So to Mr Barnier, I would say look on them favourably—and to the UK Government, I would say work harder.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Madam President, the border dispute between Croatia and Slovenia has been burdening relations between the two countries for too long.In 2009, when the arbitration agreement was signed, it seemed that the dispute would finally be resolved, but the Slovenian side, with the unprecedented contamination of the arbitration proceedings, made sure that we were at the beginning again.If the Commission wants to save the face of international law, then it should be understood that the application of the Decision, which is the result of an unprecedented act of corruption, is not an option here and that a new solution must be reached through discussion.What is crucial is that both sides refrain from unilateral moves that would make life difficult for citizens.Unfortunately, Slovenia is already harassing Croatian fishermen by writing them draconian penalties, thus showing its unwillingness to resolve this issue in the European spirit.I ask the Commission to examine the legality of these punishments, which is a serious existential problem for people who have done nothing wrong.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Madam President, the principle of subsidiarity was introduced by the Lisbon Treaty, Article 5, but is its application very successful?Well, I would not say - we have a number of, as we see, member states that do not respect the principle of subsidiarity or, better said, decentralization at all.Of course, the most famous conflict at the moment is the Catalan conflict, however, we have a lot of situations in the European Union, in member states, where member states simply do not want to respect regional specifics, but rather want to go into conflicts and further centralization and "show muscle".We have a number of examples, but I will still point out one positive example that has happened recently, and that is the Italian situation in which Veneto and Lombardy held a referendum legally and I think maybe the Italian model could be something that could be interesting for subsidiarity inEuropean Union.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: - Madam President, we hear that we are in the economic recovery phase, but the reality is that workers do not see its effects on job creation. On the contrary, precariousness and insecurity are installed due to losing jobs. This is the situation that exists in the province of Jaén and in towns such as Linares, the city with the most unemployment in Spain in the province with the most unemployment in Spain. The industry has been destroyed and workers at companies like Aeroepoxy Composites struggle every day to keep their jobs. To this is added an isolation in communications due to the abandonment of the railway. The consequences of the neoliberal policies that are adopted are unemployment, depopulation, inequality. But this situation can be reversed by betting on the configuration of a territorial initiative integrated with European funds and with the participation of the different social agents, which serves to generate an industrial production model, recover the railway and strengthen the agri-food sector. In short, to generate quality jobs. Jaén, Linares and its people - our people - have a future. And from Europe it is our obligation to contribute to this.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: - Madam President, every time we ask the European Commission a question about the situation in Catalonia, they tell us that they trust Rajoy a lot. Well, in our country, in Catalonia, it is not like that. In the Catalan elections, imposed by Rajoy, his party came in last, with fewer votes than the anti-capitalists, despite being their elections, having illegally taken over our institutions, having invented many lies, for example, about our economy, and despite that we had candidates in prison and in exile, which is a true European scandal. Despite all this, Rajoy and his allies - I must also say the Commission - continue to clash with reality: that in the Parliament of Catalonia elected with the most participation in history there is still a majority in favor of the Catalan Republic. To support Rajoy is to support failure, it is to support state nationalism that is seen with carte blanche to threaten basic rights, state nationalism that European integration should stop. To continue with this attitude is a failure for the whole of Europe.

name: Jörg MEUTHEN
text: - Madam President! If the colleagues of the CDU, CSU and SPD parties in the EP have their way, the country in which the applicant's relatives already live or in which the asylum seeker pretends to be caregivers will be responsible for the procedure of an asylum seeker in the amendment of the Dublin Treaty to have. In plain language: The countries that are already hosting a particularly large number of immigrants will then experience massively more immigration, especially Germany. In Berlin these parties are currently promising an upper limit of a maximum of 220,000 people per year and a limit on family reunification to a maximum of 1,000 people per month. Neither of these works with this regulation, and they know that. Martin Schulz already says: If more are coming, then more will come. More will come then, a lot more in fact, but they don't care. This is an unbearable scandal and nothing less than a brazen lying to the population. If someone wanted to come up with a master plan on how to systematically ruin a country through more and more social migration, it could look like this.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: - Madam President, as soon as he was elected President of the French Republic, Emmanuel Macron wanted democratic conventions to be organized in all the States of the European Union. He has just revived this idea. Officially, the aim is to strengthen European democracy but, in reality, the real objective is to carry out an oriented consultation of the most Eurolatrous citizens to legitimize the great Macronian project of transforming the Union into an omnipotent federal state. Florent Banfi, president of the Union of European Federalists, has openly admitted this. Of course, it is a question of carrying out this infamy behind the backs of the peoples of Europe, for the function of democratic pseudo-conventions is to replace referendums. This is the scandal I want to denounce today. European states have fortunately resisted Macron for six months and I encourage them to continue, because the peoples of Europe want referendums, not bogus democratic conventions.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Madam President, the European Parliament is currently preparing a report stating that the fundamental values ​​of the Union have been seriously jeopardized in Hungary. The main reason is Hungary's migration policy - although the prevention of illegal immigration is an EU obligation and is based on laws passed by a two-thirds majority. At the same time, we hear little about those in power using independent state institutions against their political opponents. The State Audit Office has imposed a series of financial sanctions on opposition parties. The punishment of the strongest, Jobbik, is equivalent to nearly a year and a half of state support. The decision is not supported by a numerical, substantive justification, there is no possibility of legal redress. And let’s add: the president of the State Audit Office, from a representative of the governing party, became the head of the theoretically independent organization. It is not the government's migration policy, but such procedures that abolish the rule of law in Hungary.

name: Brian HAYES
text: – Madam President, it is 2018 and the EU still has not found a solution to the European Court of Justice’s (ECJ) Vnuk ruling of 2014, a ruling that has had such a profound effect on motor insurance across Europe. If anyone wanted to discredit the EU’s decision-making process, the Vnuk case is a prime example. The Commission has itself acknowledged on several occasions that the ruling adopted by the ECJ is a problem and that it requires a quick solution, but the Commission has tiptoed around providing a solution. In the meantime, citizens all over Europe who use motor vehicles on private land will have no clarity about whether they require third-party liability cover for their vehicles. Likewise, insurance companies will take advantage of the Vnuk ruling. Vnuk is the law until it is changed. My country, Ireland, along with other Member States, has not changed domestic law, as it is required to do if this issue is not challenged. We now have a legal limbo, which must be addressed quickly by the Commission, otherwise it will have dramatic consequences for farmers, the construction industry and indeed motor sports enthusiasts, who will pay a hugely unfair price for a hugely unfair ruling.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, I want to bring before you a gesture of unprecedented aggression against Romania. On the night of January 12 to 13, the Romanian Embassy, ​​territory of Romania, was attacked by Hungarian citizens, the symbols, the coat of arms of Romania, were desecrated and vandalized, over which a flag with insignia unrecognized by the Romanian state was placed. The embassy is not protected, international treaties on diplomacy and diplomatic immunity have been violated. As the National Coalition for the Modernization of Romania, the largest coalition in Romania, sent an open letter to the Hungarian institutions, I also ask the European institutions to ask for explanations from a member state that is attacking another member state. We want a good neighborhood with all the states, and with Hungary. We are a country that respects minorities, but we want the Constitution and the laws of Romania to be respected.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: - Madam President! (The speaker shows a photo.) This is Agnes Gereb, Hungarian gynecologist, psychologist and midwife - an impressive woman whom I got to know at my European midwife reception here in Strasbourg. A woman who has accompanied pregnant women for decades, who has given birth to almost 4,000 newborns, including a home birth if mothers wanted it. A few days ago she was convicted and sent to prison in Hungary. Imprisoned for respecting mothers' right to self-determined birth. Imprisoned because experience has given her far fewer problems and fewer stillbirths than many clinics. Imprisoned for respecting the rights of expectant mothers. I do not want to question national case law here. But often we talk about reproductive health here - where are the voices now? It's about the right to self-determined birth, it's about starting life in a human environment. I would like to raise my voice here for Agnes Gereb, for her and the rights of expectant mothers across Europe - a cry for life.

name: Jozo RADOŠ
text: - Madam President, European funds have an important role in achieving cohesion, regional and social policy, but they are not optimally set to achieve their goals.Due to their complexity and bureaucratization, funds from these funds often do not come where they are intended, and especially not to those who need them most.Therefore, in general, general efforts should be made to simplify the use of these funds, and in particular for rural, remote, mountainous and island areas, special measures should be introduced, such as the creation of standard projects specifically tailored to these funds and direct access,regional and state authorities, so that these small communities can access the funds in a simpler way.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: – Madam President, journalism is a cornerstone of democracy, holding those in power to account. The appointment of Editor-in-Chief of Independent News & Media, Stephen Rae, to the EU Expert Group on Fake News beggars belief.  Mr Rae talks of the widespread damage done by the wilful dissemination of false information and social media platforms. What about the damage done by Mr Rae's sacking of a journalist for trying to uncover the quashing of penalty points for influential people, including possibly himself, or the damage done by his newspaper when its reporting aided a vicious fake news smear campaign against a Garda whistleblower, or how about the damage done to another journalist who is hampered from writing about the now Commissioner Phil Hogan? And more still is the damage done to democracy by his paymaster, Denis O’Brien, who is reported as having a chilling effect on news-gathering and reporting in the public interest.  It is behaviour like this that damages trust in mainstream media and aids the spread of fake news. I am calling on Commissioner Gabriel to reconsider Mr Rae’s appointment.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: - Madam President, in the midst of a state of exception, elections to the Catalan Parliament were held on December 21. The independence forces won them again with an absolute majority, despite having eight candidates in prison or in exile, a democratic aberration. This highlights at least two things. First, that the strategy of the Government and the Rajoy judges does not work and that it is an absolutely ineffective strategy, as well as miserable. Second, that the Government and the judges of Rajoy focus on formalities on whether the winning candidate, President Puigdemont and the other seven elected prisoners can go to Parliament or not. What is truly serious is not the physical presence of the elect, but their situation. They are in exile or in jail, without trial and without any criminal justification, and the state of exception will continue. How long will the European institutions and this Parliament be complicit in the repression in Catalonia with their silence and even with their applause? It is very ashamed that under these circumstances we dare to speak of a better future for Europe.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Madam President, the congratulations of the European Union, the IMF and the United States and, of course, the employers in the SYRIZA-ANEL government for their dirty work, forcing the other bourgeois parties to compete over who does best in it, confirms that it is fair growth in capitalism means more wealth for fewer and more poverty for more. The third evaluation of the memorandum is a prelude to the new measures of the fourth evaluation with tax exemptions on capital, redistribution of poverty, electronic auctions of Banks and the State even for 500 euros. No protection of public housing, criminalization of reactions, new slaughter of pensions and salaries, endless surveillance and any debt agreement, means new measures, as stated by the working group "Eurogroup". Prerequisite of the prerequisites, the intimidation of the workers. Crown of the memoranda, the legislation of the substantial abolition of the right to strike. They sow winds, they will reap storms. It will not pass! Workers' struggles, antitrust, anti-capitalist with social alliance will send the laws and their inspirers to the junk of History.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Madam President, we just had the debate about climate change, climate justice and women, and as shadow rapporteur of the report, I would like to underline two facts that were raised in the discussion already.  Firstly, climate change is not gender-neutral. Women are affected more. Women are living in more vulnerable areas and in poverty, but there is another side of the coin, and that is that women are half of the planet. They are a huge resource in solving climate change issues. What we need to do is empower women, and that means carrying out gender-impact analyses in all the climate and economic policies, developing the concept of climate justice, ensuring parity in decision-making, be it by delegations or other decision-making areas in climate change, and then of course in their private lives in their consumption choices.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for voting in favor of non-citizens of Latvia and Estonia during the plenary session in December 2017. I would like to show you the card made by the three of us, MEPs.Yana Toom and Tatjana Ždanoka and myself - yours truly, Andrejs Mamikins.This card will be distributed by all deputies who voted for non-citizens.It represents the real passports of these people.You will see "Alien's passport" on it.We absolutely must end this shame of massive non-citizenship.We must therefore give these people the right to vote in the next European elections in 2019.

name: Yana TOOM
text: – Madam President, firstly, like my colleague Mamikins, I would like to express my gratitude to those of you who supported non-citizens in Estonia and Latvia during the last plenary vote. Secondly, I would like to draw your attention to the debate regarding the resolution on protection of minority rights. The problem is the same: voting rights of so-called aliens. I would like to counter disinformation that is spreading in this House. Some colleagues argue that, according to the Constitution, the right to vote in Estonia is an integral part of citizenship. This is not true. The Estonian Constitution was adopted 12 years before we joined the European Union. There is not a single word about European elections in this document. It speaks only about elections to the national parliament and referendums. The second argument is that citizenship is an exclusive competence of Member States and there is no ground for us to intervene in this case. This is not true either. The fact that today we do not have an efficient tool to solve the problem cannot be an excuse for not taking a position on an issue which is so important for more than 300 000 non-citizens living in the Baltic States.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: – Madam President, recently we have come across media reports that the Government of Malta is selling Maltese citizenship to rich Russian oligarchs for money, a practice that we have condemned here in this House many times. First, it puts at risk the integrity of the Schengen system. Second, it allows foreign individuals covered by international sanctions to circumvent the existing ban on entering the territory of the Union. Third, it also undermines the reputation of Malta. Among those who have been granted Maltese passports there are over 700 Russian nationals, including various oligarchs. Thanks to such golden passports, they can avoid sanctions linked mainly to the aggressive actions of Russia in Ukraine. I call on the European Commission to once again look into schemes for buying Maltese citizenship. While respecting the right of EU Member States to grant citizenship, the EU should not be seen as a supermarket where passports can be bought by criminals.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Madam President, I would like to call this House’s attention to the British government’s terrible handling of the Carillion crisis. Carillion, one of the UK government’s biggest private contractors, based in my constituency, has collapsed today threatening the jobs and pensions of more than 43 000 employees. Despite three warnings last year, the government still decided to award two billion of new contracts to this organisation. Over the last 16 years, the company continued to pay increases to its shareholders. Unfortunately SMEs and other suppliers and the UK taxpayer, were not so fortunate.  This reminds me not just of the Enron crisis but also of the last financial crisis, an example of where profits were privatised and the losses nationalised. Therefore, across Europe, privatisation of key public services has to be reconsidered. For now, we must prioritise securing the jobs and pensions of the Carillion workers affected in my constituency and elsewhere.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Madam President, the border dispute between Croatia and Slovenia is relevant not only for the two countries involved, considering the recent growing tensions between them. It is also a concern for the entire Western Balkan region, especially now when we are expecting the Commission Strategy for enlargement in the Western Balkans to be released in February. Why? Because we cannot promote the idea of including countries from the region that are still unstable, so the border dispute will hit hardest those countries that are trying to do their best to move towards the Union.   There has been a ruling in the arbitration court, so what are we debating here? Why are we not demanding that these countries implement the judgment? And how can we tell the candidate countries that they have to improve respect for the rule of law before they can become part of the EU when other Member States are not respecting it? These double standards are damaging our credibility.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: - Madam President, from the very beginning, Croatia has insisted on resolving the border dispute with Slovenia in the spirit of good neighborly relations, respecting international law. However, after Slovenia fraudulently contaminated the arbitration process and the Court's corrupt practices were proven, the legitimacy of the arbitration proceedings was irreversibly destroyed. Therefore, Croatia withdrew from the Agreement, respecting the legal procedure based on the Vienna Convention. Nevertheless, after the termination of the Agreement, the Croatian side unilaterally decided to continue its work, and various other pressures are being put on Croatia to accept the arbitral award, which is neither legitimate nor legally valid for it. Cooperation between member states should be based on dialogue, and not on gross violations of signed agreements, threats and blackmail with the blockade of Croatia's entry into Schengen and the Eurozone. The political pressure to which Croatia and the Croatian people are exposed is contrary to the values ​​of the European Union, so I once again call for resolving this bilateral dispute by continuing dialogue and necessary cooperation.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, around 120 000 migrants landed in Italy in 2017. Despite a 34% drop compared to last year, thanks above all to the excellent work of the Italian government and Minister Minniti, it is clear that until Europe reforms the Dublin Treaty it will be difficult to deal with the immigration emergency. The principle of the state of first landing, signed for my country in 2003 by the Berlusconi government, must be reviewed as soon as possible. This Parliament has worked tirelessly to modify that treaty, not without facing obstacles represented by preconceptions, national selfishness, ideological positions or simply sterile opposition to any change. The risk now is that, with the Bulgarian Presidency first and then with the Austrian one, a sacrosanct reform will not come to light before the end of 2018. This must not happen: the principle of solidarity on which the European Union is based demands it and Italy does not deserve it, left alone to defend the dignity of that Europe universally recognized as the cradle of civilization.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Madam President, I do not think it is possible in the history of the European Union for the Prime Minister of a Member State to threaten to hang a group of its own citizens. As we all learned, this is exactly what happened last week in Romania, where Social Democratic Prime Minister Tudose threatened the badges of one of the symbols of the Hungarian minority in the country, the Szekler flag, with the words: “if the flag flies in the wind, responsible ”. The definition of hate speech can be debated, but if the prime minister of a country allows such words and this is not considered unacceptable by any parliamentary party leader, nor by the head of the Romanian head of state or any state authority, it is certainly suitable for intimidation and discrimination against the minority. social acceptance of expressions of temper. Although Romania regularly claims to exemplify the rights of national minorities, we can see how seriously these claims can be taken if there is a death threat from the mouth of a head of government who has otherwise resigned today for using a symbol.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: - Madam President, the European Union is built on values, respect for human dignity, civil rights and national identities. It is not enough to whip up European values, to enshrine them in political programs, they must be carried in the minds and souls of all politicians. Nevertheless, the Prime Minister of my country, Romania, has trampled on the fundamental rights of my community, the Hungarian national community, when it has seriously threatened those who express their national identity with their own symbols. The Szekler flag is a symbol of my community, its ban on use is ridiculous and absurd. The Prime Minister’s statement was shocking, all the more so because a few hours earlier, he had made a surprising statement about the death penalty in another context. After such statements in Europe is not worthy of his office as a prime minister. Such a serious, hurtful and threatening statement cannot go unpunished, which is why I welcome your resignation announced tonight.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - I want to share with you one experience and one piece of information. The European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) is an impartial investigative body and its activities may involve a high level of policy. Such a situation exists in Hungary and also in the Czech Republic, where it is the project Stork's Nest of Prime Minister Babiš. I have no doubt that OLAF's investigations are independent and professional. That is why, in the case of politicians, the speed of investigation and transparency is in the public interest. In this particular case, there was no reason to keep the final report secret, which the media eventually obtained and published anyway. The OLAF report shows that fraud has taken place. It will therefore be a test for the rule of law of the Czech Republic, whether everyone is equal before the law. And also instructions for national and European Union authorities to be more transparent next time. To the end, Madame the President, allow me to share with you personal information. name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - First of all, I would also like to congratulate my new grandmother, Mrs Šojdrová. In my one minute, I would like to comment on the issue of unanimity in the European Council's decisions. In my opinion, the foundations of this requirement are really sensible, and this principle of unanimity in the European Council's decision-making can be central to our future and the cohesion of the EU. It is important to use this principle, for example, when assessing the issue of mandatory permanent quotas, and I want to distinguish them fundamentally from those that were one-off in favor of Italy and Greece. I feel that this is a great policy and that this policy threatens the unity of the EU. Decisions should also be made on these issues. However, we must accept this principle of unity, even with regard to Poland. The Polish Government should blunt this dispute precisely in relation to the Commission, because the rule of law has common features. The Commission should then consider more whether there is still room for a better agreement than to use tougher practices.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
